questions.text: According to the biomedical waste disposal guidelines, the used cotton swabs should be disposed of in the __ colored bag.
questions.solution:
The used cotton swabs are disposed of in the yellow-coloured bags after use.

The biomedical waste management rule applies to all those who collect, receive, store, dispose and treat biomedical waste. The wastes are categorised and segregated at the point of generation of waste. A colour coding system with 4 colours namely yellow, red, white, and blue is used for waste segregation. 

The segregated waste is then disposed of by various methods. They are: 

  • Incineration - this is a dry oxidation process done using high temperatures. The types are rotary kiln, pyrolytic incinerator, and single chamber incinerator.  
  • Chemical disinfection - chemicals are added to waste to kill or inactivate the microorganisms. Mostly used for treating liquid wastes.
  • Wet and dry thermal treatment - shredded infectious waste is exposed to high temperature, high-pressure steam and it resembles an autoclave sterilization process.
  • Microwave irradiation - microorganisms are killed using high-frequency microwaves. Its efficiency should be checked routinely.
  • Land disposal - either municipal disposal sites or sanitary landfills are used.
  • Inertization - waste is mixed with cement and other substances before disposal to reduce toxicity.

Disposal by deep burial is permitted only in rural areas that lack common bio-medical treatment facilities. Permission from the concerned authority is needed and guidelines issued by the central pollution control board should be followed. 

Cytotoxic and biohazard materials will have separate non-washable and visible symbols as shown below:

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication for the device shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The device shown in the image is of a CuT 380 A(IUD) and vaginal bleeding of unknown etiology is an absolute contraindication. 

Contraindications for IUD usage include:

Absolute contraindications

Relative contraindications
  • Suspected pregnancy
  • PID
  • Vaginal bleeding of unknown etiology
  • Carcinoma cervix /uterus/adnexa /other pelvic tumors
  • Anemia
  • Menorrhagia
  • History of PID since the last pregnancy
  • Purulent cervical discharge
  • Distortions of the uterine cavity due to fibroids
  • Uterine malformations
  • An unmotivated person

questions.text: According to WHO, what is the minimum number of antenatal visits?
questions.solution:
According to WHO, the minimum number of antenatal visits is 8. 

The WHO increased the minimum number of antenatal visits from 4 to 8 visits to reduce perinatal mortality.

WHO suggests the first visit at 12 weeks of gestation followed by visits at 20,26,30,34,36,38,40 weeks of gestation.

The ideal number of antenatal visits is 12-14.

The antenatal visits should ideally be:

  • Monthly visits up to 28 weeks
  • Two weekly visits between 28-36 weeks
  • Weekly visits from 36 weeks onwards

Note:

The minimum number of antenatal visits according to MCH(Maternal and Child Health Program) is 4.

questions.text: A 20 year old female with a history of recent sexual intercourse presents to the  Suraksha clinic of the local Primary Health Centre with complaints of vaginal discharge and lower abdominal pain. Based on the syndromic management of sexually transmitted infections which of the following kits will you prescribe to treat this patient?
questions.solution:
The symptom that the woman  presents with is lower abdominal pain and hence the yellow kit has to be prescribed for her. 

Yellow kit/Kit 6:

Patients who have been prescribed the yellow kit predominantly present with lower abdominal pain. Other symptoms that are seen are

  • Fever
  • Vaginal Discharge
  • Menstrual irregularities (heavy, irregular vaginal bleeding)
  • Dysmenorrhoea, dysparenunia, dysuria and tenesmus
  • Lower backache
  • Cervical motion tenderness

Contents and course: 

Tab. Cefixime 400 mg OD stat + Tab. Metronidazole 400 mg BD X 14 days + Doxycycline 100 mg BD X 14 days

Male partner(s) is additionally treated with the Grey kit/Kit 1

The patient is asked to follow-up on the 3rd , 7th , and 14th day.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

questions.text: The minimum requirements of a health worker job are given:  should be a woman, a resident of the village, 25 to 45 years old, and have a formal education till 10th standard. What is this health worker called?
questions.solution:
The requirements of being a woman, a resident of the village, 25 to 45 years old, and having a formal education till 10th standard is for an ASHA(Accredited Social Health Activist) worker. 

An ASHA is a trained female community health activist and a resident woman of the village with a formal education of at least up to 10th grade. . This may be relaxed upto 8th standard only if no suitable person with this qualification is available. She should preferably be in the age group of 25 to 45 years (married/divorced/widow) and have qualities such as good communication skills and leadership skills. The general norm of selection recommends having one ASHA for 1000 population, but in tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm could be relaxed to one ASHA per habitation.

 Roles of ASHA:

  • To create awareness and provide information to the community on determinants of health such as nutrition, basic sanitation, and hygienic practices.
  • To counsel women on birth preparedness, the importance of safe delivery, breastfeeding and complementary feeding, immunization, and contraception.
  • To counsel women on the prevention of common infections including reproductive tract infections/sexually transmitted infections.
  • To mobilize the community and help them in accessing health and health-related services.
  • To arrange and escort pregnant women and children requiring treatment/admission to the nearest pre-identified health facility.
  • To inform the sub-centre/primary health centre about the births and deaths in her village and any unusual health problems/disease outbreaks in the community.
  • To promote the construction of household toilets under the total sanitation campaign.

Other options:

Option A: An Anganwadi worker is a community-based health worker in India, primarily responsible for providing maternal and child health services, nutrition, and education. They work under the Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) program to support the well-being of children and mothers.

Option B: A nurse is a healthcare professional responsible for providing patient care, administering medications, and assisting with treatment plans. They play a crucial role in promoting health, preventing illness, and supporting recovery across various healthcare settings.

Option C: A midwife is a trained professional who specializes in assisting women during pregnancy, childbirth, and the postpartum period. They provide prenatal care, support during labour, and postnatal care for both the mother and newborn.

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA is an Accredited Social Health Activist.

An ASHA must be a woman, a resident of the village, 25 to 45 years old and have a formal education till 10th standard preferably if they are in good numbers. This may be relaxed upto 8th standard only if no suitable person with this qualification is available. She is part of the primary health care at the village level.

National norm: In rural areas, a population of 1000 should have at least 1 ASHA, but in remote areas, one ASHA per habitation is the norm. In urban areas, 1 ASHA worker is assigned to a population of 1000-2500. This norm is also mandated by each state, differently, according to their requirements. 

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

questions.text: The pregnancy test kit launched by the government is called:
questions.solution:
Nishchay is a pregnancy test kit introduced by the government.

NIKSHAY is a web-based solution for monitoring of TB patients. (The word is a combination of two Hindi words NI and KSHAY, meaning eradication of TB)

Nikusth is the web-based solution for monitoring of Leprosy patients.

Axshya is the project that works to improve access to quality TB care and control through a partnership between government and civil society.

questions.text: The best method of teaching an urban slum about ORS is ________.
questions.solution:
The best method of teaching an urban slum about ORS is by demonstration.

  • Demonstration is a carefully prepared presentation on how to perform a certain task or skill or procedure.
  • It shows the step by step process of a task.
  • Demonstration arouses interest and incites ‘learning by doing,’ and ‘seeing is believing’ philosophies.

questions.text: An 8 months old baby on examination shows signs of Vitamin A deficiency. What is the dose of Vitamin A to be administered to the baby?
questions.solution:
The vitamin A dose for an 8 months old baby with clinical signs of deficiency is 100,000 IU orally.

Treatment of children with Vit A deficiency:

  • 100,000 IU orally or 50,000 IU IM for a child < 12 months and
  • 200,000 IU of vitamin A orally or 100,000 IU by intramuscular injection for a child above 12 months.

The same dose of Vitamin A is repeated the next day and on the 14th day.

Related Pearl: Vitamin-A supplementation & treatment of Vitamin-A deficiency

Target group

12 to 59 month of age (1yr to 5yr)
Dose
100,000 IU (oral)
200,000 IU (oral)
Frequency
Once
Every 4–6 months

 

Note: A total dose of 17 lakh IU given as per the following schedule:

  • 100,000 IU is given with measles vaccine at 9 months
  • 200,000 IU is given with DPT booster at 15–18 months
  • 200,000 IU is given every 6 months (till 5years of age)

 

Treatment of vitamin A deficiency
Age < 6 months 6-12 months > 1 year
Dose 50,000 IU 100,000 IU 200,000 IU

 

Note: Route of administration is oral, in the form of retinol palmitate.

questions.text: To avoid overcrowding, what is the maximum number of people allowed to live in a house with 2 rooms?
questions.solution:
Maximum of 3 people are allowed to be living in a house of 2 rooms to avoid overcrowding.

Note :

  • Baby under 12 months is not counted
  • Children b/w 1 to 10 years is counted as half a unit

Overcrowding:

Overcrowding is considered to exist if 2 persons over 9 years of age, not husband and wife, of opposite sexes are obliged to sleep in the same room.

The accepted standards against overcrowding are as follows.

No of rooms  No of persons
1 room 2 persons
2 rooms 3 persons
3 rooms 5 persons
4 rooms 7 persons
5 rooms 10 persons (1 rooms for every 2 additional persons)

The floor space standards against overcrowding are as follows.

Area No of persons
110 sq. ft. and more 2 persons
90 – 100 sq. ft. 1 ½ persons (Children from 1 – 10 are counted as a half unit)
70 – 90 sq. ft. 1 person
50 – 70 sq. ft. ½ person

questions.text: In controlled tipping, the amount of land required for the trench method to be practiced for a population of 10,000 is:
questions.solution:
In controlled tipping, one acre of land is required by trench method to be practiced for a population of 10,000.

It is also known as sanitary landfill. It is the most satisfactory method of refuse disposal where suitable land is available. In this method waste material is placed in a trench or other prepared area. Then it is adequately compacted and covered with earth at the end of the day.

Methods used in this are:

  • Trench method: Done in places where level ground is available
  • Ramp method: Well suited where the terrain is moderately sloping
  • Area method: Used for filling land depressions, disused quarries and clay pits

questions.text: Re-infection with which of the following will lead to catastrophic symptoms even in the presence of antibodies?
questions.solution:
Re-infection with Dengue virus will lead to catastrophic symptoms even in the presence of antibodies.

The DENV-1/DENV-2 sequence of infection has a 500-fold risk of DHF than primary infection.

DENV-3/DENV-2 sequence has a 150-fold risk and DENV-4/DENV-2 has a 50-fold risk of DHF.

This shows that multiple infection with different serotypes of the dengue virus leads to severe forms of dengue such as DHF/DSS.

Recent update: Dengvaxia is the WHO endorsed first ever vaccine for dengue fever, which is currently licensed in twenty countries. 

Other options: Re-infection with Yellow fever, Japanese encephalitis and Zika will not cause catastrophic symptoms in the presence of antibodies.

questions.text: Which of the following is used to reduce the selection bias in a clinical trial?
questions.solution:
Randomization is done to reduce the clinical error and selection bias in a study. 

Randomization:

  • Randomization is a statistical procedure wherein the population is grouped into study and control groups.
  • It is done so to know whether any intervention is needed to be given or not.
  • This is done to reduce the bias and to allow comparability between the individuals.
  • Randomization is the "heart" of a control trial.

Related Pearl: Randomized Control Trials

Randomized controlled trials are a type of experimental studies.

General Design of an RCT

Steps of an RCT

  • Drawing up a protocol
  • Selecting reference and experimental population
  • Randomization
  • Manipulation or intervention
  • Follow-up
  • Assessment of outcome

Types

  • Clinical trials
  • Preventive trials
  • Risk factor trials
  • Cessation experiments
  • Trial of etiological agents
  • Evaluation of health services

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for maintaining the births and deaths in India?
questions.solution:
The Sample Registration System is responsible for maintaining the births and deaths in India.

SRS was initiated in the mid-1960s to provide reliable estimates of birth and death rates at the National and State levels. It is a dual-record system where there is continuous registration of births and deaths and a 6-month independent survey by an investigator-supervisor. It provides reliable health information, age-specific fertility and mortality rates, infant mortality,under-five and adult mortality. 

Other options:

Lay reporting is defined as the collection of information, its use, and its transmission to other levels of the health system by non-professional health workers.

questions.text: If Bajra is mixed with black seeds, what is used to separate them?
questions.solution:
20% saltwater is used to separate bajra from grains or seeds. They can also be removed by hand-picking and air floatation.

Note:

Food items like bajra, rye, sorghum, and wheat have a tendency to house the ergot fungus called Claviceps purpurea.The safe limit for ergot alkaloids in grains is 0.05 mg per 100 grams.

questions.text: A patient presents to an ESI hospital for treatment. Under the ESI Act, he/she is treated under which benefit ?
questions.solution:
Under the ESI Act, medical benefit is not given as a cash benefit. It is provided in the form of consultations, investigations and treatment by means of the ESI hospitals or ESI dispensaries.

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding

  • Defense 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage 
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- no cash benefit, full medical care is provided.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of daily wage for a duration of 91 days in one year 
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years for 34 specified diseases 
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
  • Maternity Benefit – Benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy
  • Dependance Benefit– is at 90% daily wages, lifelong for the spouse and parents and till the age of 18 years for any dependant's child, however, the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter is married earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits – temporary disability – is as long as the person is disabled at 90% daily wages. Permanent disability – the lifetime pension 
  • Funeral Benefit – Rs.15,000/-
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs. 10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from workman compensation act 
  • Exemption from maternity benefit act 
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.

Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition (Page no: 877)

https://www.esic.nic.in/information-benefits.

questions.text: Lung malignancy is most commonly associated with?
questions.solution:
Asbestosis is most commonly associated with Mesotheliomas,  pleural malignancy. 

Asbestos-related diseases include:

  • Localized fibrous plaques or diffuse pleural fibrosis
  • Pleural effusion
  • Parenchymal interstitial fibrosis (asbestosis)
  • Lung carcinoma
  • Mesotheliomas
  • Laryngeal, ovarian and colon carcinomas

Asbestosis:

  • Asbestosis is a type of pneumoconiosis that occurs after 5-10 years of exposure to asbestos. However, once established, it progresses even in the further removal of the worker from its contact. Asbestosis affects the basal part of the lung causing diffuse peribronchial fibrosis.
  • Asbestos is of 2 types i.e Serpentine/Chrysolite variety and Amphibole type
  • Amphibole type has the following varieties:
    • Crocidolite(blue)
    • Amosite(brown)
    • Anthrophyllite(white)
  • Sputum shows asbestos body, which are asbestos fibres coated with fibrin.
  • They present with cough and exertional dyspnoea and predominantly affects the lower lobes of the lung, in contrast to other forms of pneumoconiosis, which affect the upper lobes.
  • Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis typically shows a restrictive pattern with a decrease in both lung volumes and diffusing capacity.
  • X-ray shows peripheral reticular opacities predominantly in the lower zones. HRCT shows subpleural fibrotic lines, irregular opacities, traction bronchiectasis and honeycombing. Lung parenchymal involvement occurs after years of exposure (at least 10 years).
  • The complications that can occur are
    • Pulmonary fibrosis 
    • Carcinoma of the lung 
    • Malignancy of the Gastrointestinal tract
    • Mesothelioma of the pleura

Preventive measures:

  • Using a safer type of Asbestos (chrysolite and amosite)
  • Substituting other insulants like glass fibre, mineral wool, calcium silicate, plastic foams etc
  • Dust control
  • Periodic examination of workers
  • Continuing research

questions.text: You are a doctor in a village. A 1 yr old child who is not taking feeds, presents with fever and cough for 2 days. On examination, he is calm, with a respiratory rate of 51 breaths/min, and stridor is present. According to IMNCI (Integrated management of neonatal and childhood illnesses), how is he classified?
questions.solution:
This child is classified as having a very severe disease/severe pneumonia. 

Signs of very severe disease are:

  • Stridor in a calm child
  • Not able to drink
  • Convulsions
  • Abnormally sleepy or difficult to wake
  • Severe malnutrition.

In any of these cases, an urgent referral is very important.

questions.text: Which of the following terms refers to instilling a particular point of view in people’s minds and inhibiting their independent thought?
questions.solution:
The act of instilling a particular point of view in people’s minds and inhibiting their independent thought is referred to as Health propaganda.

When information is used to spread a particular systemized doctrine it is called health propaganda.

The difference between health education (option A) and health propaganda is given below:

  Health education  Health propaganda
Knowledge Actively acquired Instilled in the mind
Skills Actively acquired Instilled
Primitive desires Disciplined Aroused
Action Reflective behaviour; trained to use judgement before acting Reflexive behaviour; Aims at impulsive action 
Emotion  Does not appeal to emotion but appeals to reason Appeals to emotion
Behaviour The process is behaviour centred  The process is information centred

 

Four approaches to health education:

  • Regulatory approach: Governmental intervention, direct or indirect, designed to alter human behavior. It may range from prohibition to imprisonment.
  • Service approach: Providing all health services needed by people at their doorstep on the assumption that people would use them to improve their own health.
  • Health education approach: People must be educated through planned learning experiences on what to do, and be informed, educated, and encouraged to make their own choices for a healthy life.
  • Primary health care approach: Full participation and active involvement in planning and delivery of health services based on principles of primary health care viz community involvement and intersectoral coordination. 

Other options:

Option C: Health awareness is a crucial component of public health strategies aimed at promoting positive health behaviors and reducing the burden of disease through education and preventive measures.

Option D: Health promotion is a mode of intervention in primary prevention and is the process of enabling people to increase control over and improve health. Health promotion may be achieved through health education, environmental modification, nutritional interventions, or lifestyle changes.

questions.text: A diabetic patient comes to you for advice regarding his diet. You advise him to include foods with a low glycemic index in the diet. Which of the following would you advise him for the same?
questions.solution:
The patient should be advised to take papaya since it has a low glycemic index.

The Glycemic index (GI) is the area under the two-hour blood glucose response curve (AUC) following ingestion of a fixed portion of test carbohydrate as a proportion of the AUC of the standard (glucose or white bread).

The classification of foods according to Glycemic index (GI) is as follows,

  • Low GI foods (GI = 55 or less): Most fruits and vegetables (except potatoes, watermelon, and sweet corn), whole grains, pasta foods, beans, and lentils.
  • Moderate GI foods (GI = 56 to 69): Sucrose, basmati rice, and brown rice.
  • High GI foods (GI = 70 or more): Corn flakes, baked potatoes, white bread, candies, and syrupy foods.

Related Pearl: Treatment Goals for Adults with Diabetes

Index

Goal

HbA1c*

< 7 %

Preprandial capillary plasma glucose

80–130 mg/dL

Peak postprandial capillary plasma glucose

<180 mg/dL

Blood pressure+

< 140/80 mmHg

*Note that most diabetes associations recommend the target HbA1c must be individualized to the patient. A target of <7% is reasonable in most individuals.

+ Blood pressure: Harrison's 20th  edition,(based on ADA) recommends the target blood pressure goal of <140/90 mmHg for adults with diabetes. It further adds that for younger individuals the target blood pressure is <130/80 mmHg. But the "AHA/SPRINT TRIAL recommendations" recommend that the goal of blood pressure in patients with diabetes mellitus is less than 130/80 mmHg.

Dyslipidemia: Although not a treatment goal, ADA recommends to intensify lifestyle therapy and optimize glycemic control for patients with elevated triglyceride levels (≥150 mg/dL [1.7 mmol/L]) and/or low HDL cholesterol (<40 mg/dL for men, <50 mg/dL  for women). Treatment with statins would depend on the overall cardiovascular risk (ASCVD) rather than specific LDL/HDL cholesterol level.

questions.text: Highest Sodium content is present in which of the following foods:
questions.solution:
Highest Sodium content is present in Canned Soup.

Packaged, processed, store-bought, and restaurant foods have highest amount of sodium in the form of salt added as a preservative to the canned foods.

Other options: Sugar cane, Barley, Fresh fruit juices all have less sodium content when compared to canned soup.

questions.text:
An elderly woman presented with symptoms of confusion, thirst, and abdominal pain. On examination, she had pallor and thoracic spine tenderness. Her lab investigations showed the following findings. An X-ray of her skull is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
  • Hb - 6.9g/dL
  • WBC 4000/cm3 with normal differential count
  • Serum calcium 13mg/dL
  • Creatinine 2.3mg/dL
  • Total protein 9g/dL
  • Albumin 2.4g/dL
  • Urinalysis: positive for Bence-Jones proteins
questions.solution:
The given clinical features along with hypercalcemia, elevated creatinine suggestive of renal failure, anemia, osteolytic bone lesions (CRAB features), hypoalbuminemia with elevated total proteins and Bence Jones proteinuria make multiple myeloma the most likely diagnosis.

Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell dyscrasia with the proliferation of plasma cells derived from a single clone. It is associated with an increased osteoclast activity with suppression of osteoblast activity, causing punched-out lytic lesions in the bone and hypercalcemia.

Signs and symptoms

  • Bone pain is the most common symptom
  • Pathologic fractures
  • Recurrent bacterial infections
  • Renal failure
  • Normocytic normochromic anemia, elevated ESR, Hypercalcemia, normal ALP (ALP is a marker of bone growth and hence is not increased in multiple myeloma)
  • Radiography: Punched-out lytic lesions on X-ray
  • Electrophoresis: Monoclonal elevation of one immunoglobulin
  • Urinalysis: Free kappa and lambda light chains (Bence Jones proteins)
  • Bone marrow biopsy: 10 to 20% plasma cells (normal is < 5%)
  • Peripheral smear: Rouleaux formation (High level of M proteins in myeloma causes red cells in the peripheral blood smears to stick to one another in linear arrays, a finding referred to as rouleaux formation)

Revised International Myeloma Working Group criteria for the diagnosis of multiple myeloma:

Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥10% (or) Biopsy-proven bony or extramedullary plasmacytoma

Plus

Any one or more of the following myeloma-defining events:

  • Evidence of end-organ damage attributable to the underlying plasma cell proliferative disorder, specifically:(CRAB features)
    • HyperCalcemia: Serum calcium level >1 mg/dL higher than the upper limit of normal or >11 mg/dL
    • Renal insufficiency: Creatinine clearance <40 mL/min or serum creatinine >2 mg/dL
    • Anemia: Hemoglobin level of >20 g/L (2gm/dl) below the lowest limit of normal, or Hb <10 g/dL
    • Bone lesions: One or more osteolytic lesions on skeletal radiography, computed tomography (CT), or positron emission tomography (PET)/CT.
  • Any one or more of the following biomarkers of malignancy:
    • Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥60%
    • Serum involved/uninvolved free light-chain ratio of 100 or greater
    • >1 focal lesion on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) that is at least 5 mm or greater in size.

Note:

  • The presence of at least one of these markers is considered sufficient for a diagnosis of multiple myeloma, regardless of the presence or absence of symptoms or CRAB features.
  • Each of these markers has been shown to be associated with an approximately 80% or higher risk of developing myeloma-related organ damage within two years.

Primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT) is usually due to a solitary parathyroid adenoma and is not associated with anemia and hypoalbuminemia. It is characterized by hypercalcemia and low serum phosphorus in presence of elevated PTH levels. 24-hour urine calcium should be checked which will be normal or elevated in PHPT but will be decreased in familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia. Prior neck irradiation is the only known risk factor. The clinical features are known as the "bones, stones, abdominal groans, and psychic moans" which include:

  • Renal: renal stones (most common clinical manifestation), nephrocalcinosis, UTI, renal insufficiency
  • Musculoskeletal: Osteitis fibrosa cystica, osteopenia causing osteoporosis, proximal myopathy
  • Gastrointestinal: constipation due to hypercalcemia, peptic ulcer disease, and rarely pancreatitis
  • Neuropsychiatric: decreased concentration, fatigue, and depression

First-line treatment includes bisphosphonates and calcitonin is usually used as a bridge until sustained action of bisphosphonates is seen. Surgery is the definitive management for PHPT and Sestamibi scan is the most accurate and reliable investigation for imaging parathyroid glands prior to surgery. Elevated ALP  levels are seen in concomitant bone diseases, and such patients may develop postoperative hypocalcemia due to hungry bone syndrome.

Milk alkali syndrome occurs on ingestion of large amounts of calcium and vitamin D supplements. It results in hypercalcemia, alkalosis, and renal impairment leading to nephrocalcinosis and nephrolithiasis.

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Plasma Cell Neoplasms

Plasma cell neoplasms and variants

Plasma cell myeloma
  • Non secretory: No secretion of Ig, No M component.
  • Smoldering: M protein in serum ≥ 30 g/L and/or ≥10% clonal plasma cells in bone marrow, and no related organ or tissue impairment.
  • Plasma-cell leukemia: >20% plasma cells in the peripheral blood or Absolute plasma cell count of >2 X 109/L.

Plasmacytoma
  • Solitary plasmacytoma: Localized tumour of monoclonal plasma cells with no clinical features of plasma cell myeloma.
  • Extramedullary(extraosseous) plasmacytoma: Localized plasma cell neoplasms that arise in tissues other than bone.

Monoclonal immunoglobulin deposition diseases
  • Primary amyloidosis: Tumor secreting light chains that are deposited as beta-pleated sheet structure (amyloid light chain).
  • Systemic light and heavy chain diseases: Secrete abnormal light or heavy chain or both, which do not form beta pleated sheet, stain Congo Red or contain amyloid P component.

Plasma cell neoplasms with associated paraneoplastic syndrome

POEMS syndrome- Polyneuropathy, organomegaly, Endocrinopathy, Monoclonal gammopathy, Skin changes.

TEMPI syndrome

questions.text: If all Extraocular muscles are paralysed ,where would you suspect the lesion?
questions.solution:
If all Extraocular muscles are paralysed , the lesion can be suspected in Midbrain and Pons.

 

All the extraocular muscles (including inferior oblique) are innervated by the oculomotor (III) nerve except:

  • Lateral rectus which is supplied by abducens (VI) nerve
  • Superior oblique which is supplied by trochlear (IV) nerve

The nuclei of Cranial Nerve 3, 4 arises from Midbrain and Cranial Nerve 6 from Pons.

There are seven extraocular muscles present in the eye. They are:

  • Levator palpebrae superioris - Which elevates the upper eyelids
  • Four recti muscles - Superior, inferior, medial, and lateral recti
  • Two obliques - Superior and inferior oblique

The muscles originate from the back of the orbit in a common tendinous ring called the annulus of Zinn and are inserted into the sclera.

questions.text: An elderly obese man was brought to casualty with complaints of severe chest pain for the last two hours. He has also had profuse sweating, pain in the left arm, nausea, and one episode of vomiting.  On examination, his pulse rate is 58 per minute and blood pressure is 90/60 mm of Hg. ECG was done and it shows the following finding. Cardiac biomarker showed elevated troponin levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given presentation of chest pain, and elevated biomarkers depict that the patient has a myocardial infarction. In the ECG, there is elevation of ST-segments in leads II, III, aVF, with reciprocal change in lead aVL. This depicts inferior wall MI. It mainly occurs due to blockage of the posterior descending branch of the right coronary artery.

The table below gives localization of MI and probable vessel involved based on ECG findings.

Location of MI Leads Affected Vessel Involved ECG Changes
Anterior wall V2 to V4 Left Anterior Descending artery (LAD)
– Diagonal branch
  • Poor R-wave progression
  • ST-segment elevation
  • T-wave inversion
Septal wall V1 and V2 Left Anterior Descending artery (LAD)
– Septal branch
  • R-wave disappears
  • ST-segment rises
  • T-wave inverts
Lateral wall I, aVL, V5, V6 Left Coronary Artery (LCA)
– Circumflex branch
  • ST-segment elevation
Inferior wall II, III, aVF Right Coronary Artery (RCA)
– Posterior descending branch
  • T-wave inversion
  • ST-segment elevation
Posterior wall V7 to V9 Left Coronary Artery (LCA)
– Circumflex branch

 

Right Coronary Artery (RCA)
– Posterior descending branch
  • Tall R waves
  • ST-segment depression
  • Upright T waves

Patients with pericarditis also present with severe chest pain and ST-segment elevations. However, this ST-segment elevation has upward concavity with depression of PR segment.

Below image- ECG in pericarditis

Related Pearl: Localisation of MI based on ST elevations in different leads

Extensive anterior - I, aVL, V1-V6

Lateral - I, aVL

Inferior - II, III, aVF

Anteroseptal - V1-V4

Anterolateral - I, aVL, V3-V6

Posterior - ST depression and tall R in V1-V4

questions.text: A 54-year-old man was brought to the casualty with fever, headache, focal seizures. EEG shows focal temporal lobe spikes.  CSF sample analysis shows 50 cells with 90% Lymphocytes and 10% Neutrophils. What would be the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and investigations are suggestive of Encephalitis for which the drug of choice is intravenous acyclovir. The treatment is effective only if it is started early.

The clinical hallmark of encephalitis is the acute onset of fever and focal neurologic signs and with hemorrhagic necrosis especially the temporal lobe if there is HSV encephalitis. The most sensitive investigation is HSV DNA demonstration in CSF by PCR. 

Related Pearl: CSF findings in meningitis

questions.text: What is the diagnosis if the axis is on the mark "?" from the diagram shown below?
questions.solution:
The image shows the cardiac axis greater than +100 degrees and thus it shows right axis deviation. 

The cardiac axis represents the mean QRS axis (direction of mean depolarization vector).

The normal adult QRS axis is directed downward and to the left, which is between -30 degrees and +100 degrees.

The position of lead aVF is at +90 degrees (shown in the image below). If the cardiac axis is also at +90 degrees, it would be in the same direction as lead aVF and hence aVF would show maximum R wave amplitude.

If the mean axis is:

  • More negative than –30 degrees- left axis deviation
  • More positive than +100 degrees- right axis deviation
  • Lies between -90 to +180 degrees- extreme axis deviation

The image below shows the position of lead aVF with respect to the normal cardiac axis and the axis deviations.

questions.text: Identify the rhythm in the following ECG rhythm strip.
questions.solution:
The above ECG strip shows normal sinus rhythm.

The features in this ECG that suggest this diagnosis are as follows:

  • The QRS complexes are narrow (<120 ms or 3 small squares) which implies that the impulse is supraventricular and is conducted via the normal conduction pathway.

 

  • Each QRS complex is preceded by a P wave. This means that all the atrial depolarizations that arise in the sinus node are conducted to the ventricles.

 

  • The PR interval is constant for all the impulses and is normal(<200 ms) in duration.

 

  • The RR interval is constant which implies a regular rhythm.

questions.text: An intern observed that a patient was unresponsive, and an ECG which was performed urgently showed an arrhythmia as below. DC shock was delivered but the arrhythmia persisted and the patient is still unresponsive. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient is in cardiac arrest and the rhythm shown is ventricular fibrillation. Since one defibrillation is given and the patient is still unresponsive, CPR has to be given for 2 minutes after which the rhythm will be assessed again. 

The management of ventricular fibrillation and pulseless ventricular tachycardia is the same. Chest compressions are to be started following defibrillation.

Defibrillation involves delivering an electrical current between two pads placed on the chest so as to interrupt the disorganized cardiac activity and restore an organized cardiac rhythm. The energy that must be applied is

  • Monophasic defibrillator: 360 J
  • Biphasic defibrillator: 120-200 J

It is of utmost necessity to defibrillate at the earliest because the chances of survival decrease by 7-10% every minute without defibrillation.

 

Related Pearl: Adult Basic Life Support (BLS) Algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

Related Pearl: High quality CPR for adults

  • Push hard: 5-6cm depth
  • Push fast: 100-120/min frequency
  • Allow for complete chest recoil
  • Minimize interruptions in compressions <10 seconds
  • Avoid excessive ventilation
  • Rotate compressor every 2 min or earlier if fatigued
  • If no advanced airway, 30:2 compression-ventilation ratio

Attempt to improve CPR quality if :

  • Quantitative waveform capnography - PETCO2 <10mmHg, 
  • Intra-arterial pressure - If relaxation phase (diastolic) pressure <20mmHg

questions.text: Which of the following drug is not used for a patient diagnosed with sarcoidosis with multi organ involvement?
questions.solution:
The drug that is not used in the treatment of multisystemic sarcoidosis is Fludrocortisone.

The first-line drug for sarcoidosis is prednisolone. 

Management of sarcoidosis:

  • Asymptomatic patients- monitored for disease progression
  • Localized/ limited cutaneous and ocular lesions- treated using topical steroids
  • Multisystem involvement:
    • Systemic steroids
    • Other drugs like hydroxychloroquine, methotrexate, and infliximab are considered when the steroids are ineffective or not tolerated

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic alcoholic is brought to the hospital due to fever and abdominal pain. He was diagnosed to have a cirrhotic liver 2 years back. The ascitic fluid shows a neutrophil count of 360 cell/ microliter. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s clinical features are suggestive of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). The drug of choice in this patient is cefotaxime.

SBP is characterized by spontaneous infection of the ascitic fluid without an intraabdominal source. It is commonly seen in adults in association with liver cirrhosis. The pathogens involved are Escherichia coli, streptococci, enterococci, and pneumococci. 

In a patient with ascites, SBP presents with fever and acute abdominal pain. On examination, tachycardia, tachypnea, and signs of peritonitis are seen. Hepatic encephalopathy and gastrointestinal bleeding may also occur. 

Diagnosis is by paracentesis and an ascitic fluid neutrophil count of >250/mm3 is suggestive of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. Ascitic fluid culture may reveal pathogenic organisms.

Management is mainly by third-generation cephalosporins such as cefotaxime. Albumin infusion can be given as it decreases the risk of renal failure and improves patient survival. Early diagnosis and treatment improve the prognosis. In patients who have had an episode of SBP and recovered, once-weekly administration of antibiotics is used as prophylaxis for recurrent SBP.

questions.text: Tall and tented T waves, wide QRS, and absent P wave are features of:
questions.solution:
Hyperkalemia produces a sequence of changes usually beginning with narrowing and peaking (tenting) of the T waves. Further elevation of extracellular K+ leads to:

  • AV conduction disturbances.
  • Diminution in P-wave amplitude.
  • Widening of the QRS interval.

The ECG changes that can be seen in hyperkalemia depend on the extent of hyperkalemia. 

S. No. Serum potassium level ECG change
1 5.5 - 6.5 mEq/L tall, peaked T waves with 'tented' or 'pinched' shape
2 6.5 - 7.5 mEq/L loss of P waves
3 7.0 - 8.0 mEq/L widened QRS complex
4 > 8.0 mEq/L sine wave

 Severe hyperkalemia eventually causes cardiac arrest with a slow sinusoidal type of mechanism("sine-wave" pattern) followed by asystole.

The most common cause of hyperkalemia is kidney failure. Drugs that cause hyperkalemia include angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers, potassium-sparing diuretics. 

Treatment of hyperkalemia involves the following

  1. Administer intravenous calcium gluconate which raises the threshold and reduces excitability. It is cardioprotective
  2. Administer regular insulin with dextrose. The insulin will reduce the serum potassium concentration by causing an intracellular shift. The dextrose will counteract the hypoglycemic effects of insulin.
  3. Remove potassium with calcium-based resins, diuretics, or hemodialysis.

questions.text: A patient comes with a blood pressure of 160/100 mmHg and left-sided facial paralysis and weakness for 8 hours. Her CT is shown below. What would be your next step?
questions.solution:
This patient with sudden onset hemiparesis and a normal CT could have a transient ischemic attack or an ischemic stroke. The next step for this patient would be observation and monitoring.

Non-contrast CT(NCCT) is the imaging modality of choice in patients with acute stroke. CT may appear normal for the first few hours and the infarct may not appear until 24-48 hours. Diffusion-weighted MRI(DWMRI) is more sensitive to detecting early brain infarction. 

Initial treatment of acute ischemic stroke includes maintaining the patient's airway, breathing, and circulation. Complications such as hyperglycemia, hypoglycemia, or fever should be treated if present.

Thrombolysis with alteplase is the first-line therapy for acute ischemic stroke and should be initiated within 4.5 hours of symptom onset. Since this patient arrived 8 hours later which is outside of window period, the appropriate management would be observation and monitoring. Endovascular mechanical thrombectomy is done in patients who do not respond to thrombolytic therapy or in whom thrombolysis is contraindicated. Oral aspirin is recommended for the acute treatment of ischemic stroke.

Labetalol, nicardipine, and clevidipine are the first-line anti-hypertensive agents used in the acute phase of stroke. If the patient is to receive thrombolytic therapy, maintain BP ≤185/110mmHg. If not, BP should not be treated acutely unless it is more than 220/120 mmHg. BP should be lowered cautiously by only 15% in the first 24 hours in order to preserve perfusion to the ischemic penumbra.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient presents with cold intolerance, dry skin, constipation, and on examination slow ankle jerk with a TSH level of 15 IU/L and low T3, and T4. Of the following, the next best step in the management of this patient is to:

choices.text: Order a thyroid radionuclide uptake and scan

questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is hypothyroidism. Thyroid hormone replacement with levothyroxine should be started immediately after diagnosis.

Laboratory investigations in a patient with hypothyroidism would show low levels of total and free T3, T4, and rT3, with high TSH levels and normal combined protein levels.

Normally, the thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) is released by the hypothalamus. It stimulates the pituitary gland to release the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), which in turn stimulates the thyroid gland to produce T3 and T4 hormones. Elevated TSH with a low level of free T4 is suggestive of primary hypothyroidism.

In the case of secondary hypothyroidism, TSH levels may be low, normal, or even slightly increased. The latter is due to the secretion of immunoactive but bio-inactive forms of TSH. The diagnosis is confirmed by the detection of a low unbound T4 level. 

Patients with hypothyroidism often present with tiredness, weakness, dry skin, hair loss, difficulty concentrating, poor memory, constipation, cold intolerance, and weight gain with poor appetite. On examination, they may have cool peripheral extremities, puffy faces, hyporeflexia, bradycardia, and peripheral edema.

The best outcomes occur when levothyroxine therapy is started immediately after diagnosis. The clinical effects of levothyroxine replacement are slow to appear. 

If there is no residual function, the daily replacement dose of levothyroxine is usually 1.6 μg/kg body weight (typically 100–150 μg), ideally taken at least 30 minutes before breakfast.

TSH responses are gradual and should be determined 2 months following the initiation of treatment or change in dose. Once the full replacement is achieved and TSH levels are stable, TSH measurement is recommended at annual intervals.

In patients who have developed hypothyroidism following treatment of Graves' disease, lower doses are needed for replacement. This is because there is often underlying autonomous function, necessitating lower replacement doses (typically 75–125 μg/d).

Related Pearl: Causes of hypothyroidism:

 

Primary (Low T3, T4 > Raised TSH levels) Secondary (Low TSH levels > Low T3, T4) Tertiary ( Low TRH > Low TSH > Low T3,T4 )

Hashimoto’s thyroiditis

RAI therapy for Grave’s disease

Post thyroidectomy

Excessive iodine intake - Wolff Chiakoff effect

Subacute thyrioditis

Medications: Antithyroid drugs, lithium

Iodine deficiency, dyshormonogenesis

Pituitary tumour

Pituitary resection or ablation

Hypothalamic insufficiency

Resistance to thyroid hormone

questions.text: _______ excreted in the urine are used as a screening test for pheochromocytoma.
questions.solution:
Urinary metanephrines and VMA excreted in the urine are screening tests for pheochromocytoma.

Vanillyl Mandelic Acid is the end product of the catabolism of catecholamines, whereas metanephrines are the byproducts in the catabolism of catecholamines and are excreted in the urine in patients with pheochromocytoma.

  • VMA is the urinary product of both epinephrine and norepinephrine.
  • In pheochromocytoma and neuroblastoma, there is an excessive synthesis of catecholamines which causes the enhanced synthesis of VMA and its excretion in the urine.
  • It is a good screening test for pheochromocytoma and is also used to diagnose and follow up neuroblastoma and ganglioneuroma.

Option B: Albumin is excreted in Nephrotic syndrome.

Option C: 5-HIAA (5-hydroxy indole acetic acid) is excreted in Carcinoid syndrome.

Option D: Glucose is excreted in Diabetes Mellitus.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of COPD presents with sudden onset increased shortness of breath. His ABG analysis reveals pH - 7.24, pCO2 - 60 mm Hg, pO2- 52 mmHg, and HCO3 - 27 mmol/L. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
This given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute exacerbation of COPD with ABG showing respiratory acidosis. The next step for this patient would be to start non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV).

Initial management of acute exacerbation of COPD includes:

  • Bronchodilators: Inhaled beta-agonists and muscarinic antagonists.
  • Antibiotics
  • Supplemental oxygen
  • Non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV)

If initial NIPPV fails, then, invasive PPV may be provided. However, during the invasive PPV, the tidal volume is reduced to prevent damage to the alveolar structures. This decrease in minute ventilation causes progressive hypercapnia, which is however permitted to a certain extent for the benefit of the patient (commonly known as permissive hypercapnia).

The severity of COPD assessed by Global Initiative for Lung Disease (GOLD) is classified as:

GOLD Stage

Severity

Spirometry

I

Mild

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥80% predicted

II

Moderate

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥50% but <80% predicted

III

Severe

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥30% but <50% predicted

IV

Very severe

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 <30% predicted

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with excessive fatiguability towards the end of the day that improved with rest. He also gives history of ptosis, difficult in speech and swallowing. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has symptoms of fatiguability that worsen with repetitive movements but resolve after rest along with oculobulbar symptoms such as ptosis, dysarthria, and dysphagia. From the given clinical picture, myasthenia gravis is the most likely diagnosis.

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular junction disorder that is characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles.

It is due to the autoantibody-mediated destruction of the acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at the post-synaptic membrane. This consequentially leads to a decreased transmission at the neuromuscular junction. Failure of transmission results in muscle weakness.

Females are more commonly affected than males and the disease tends to occur in middle age.

Clinical features of myasthenia gravis:

  • Muscle weakness and fatiguability increase with repeated use or during late in the day and may improve following rest or sleep. Limb weakness is proximal and asymmetrical
  • Cranial muscles particularly the lids and extraocular muscles are involved early in the course - diplopia, ptosis
  • Facial weakness - snarling expression on smiling
  • Weakness in chewing
  • Speech with nasal timbre due to the weakness of palate and tongue
  • Difficulty in swallowing
  • Deep tendon reflexes are intact
  • Myasthenic crisis - acute exacerbation of muscle weakness especially intercostal and diaphragmatic muscles resulting in ventilatory failure. It is most commonly due to infection and anticholinesterase medication overuse.

Myasthenia gravis is associated with thymoma and other autoimmune diseases such as Hashimoto's thyroiditis, Grave's disease, neuromyelitis optics, systemic lupus erythematosus, etc.

Diagnosis:

  • Ice-pack test - application of ice pack over the eyes improves ptosis (decreases activity of acetylcholinesterase, this increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft and increase transmission)
  • Antibodies associated with myasthenia gravis: Anti-AChR antibodies, Anti-MuSK antibodies, Anti-LRP4 antibodies
  • Repetitive nerve stimulation test shows a decremental response.
  • Edrophonium chloride or Tensilon test - improvement of symptoms occurs on injecting edrophonium. Edrophonium is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor. This increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft and improves transmission.

Treatment:

  • Anticholinesterase drugs - Pyridostigmine.
  • Thymectomy.
  • Immunosuppression therapy with glucocorticoids, azathioprine, tacrolimus, rituximab, etc.
  • Plasmapheresis and intravenous immunoglobulin.

Other options:

Option B:

Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) is an autoimmune disorder affecting the presynaptic membrane at the neuromuscular junction. It is due to the autoantibodies against the P/Q-type calcium channels at the motor nerve terminal which results in the impaired release of Ach from the presynaptic nerve terminal.

Patients present with proximal muscle weakness of the lower limbs, ptosis, and diplopia. However, symptoms might improve after brief exercise. Deep tendon reflexes are absent or reduced. They also experience autonomic dysfunction and present with dry mouth and impotence. It is most commonly associated with small cell lung cancer. 

Repetitive nerve stimulation test shows an incremental response at higher rates.

Treatment involves plasmapheresis, immunotherapy, and drugs such as 3,4-Diaminopyridine (3,4-DAP) and pyridostigmine.

Option C:

Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is X-linked muscular dystrophy due to mutations in the dystrophin gene. It most commonly affects boys in their childhood. 

Patients initially present with proximal muscle weakness predominantly of the lower limbs. Calf muscle hypertrophy is a cardinal feature. Other features include mental retardation, cardiac failure, and myoglobinuria.

Elevated serum creatinine kinase levels and genetic testing are diagnostic of DMD.

Option D:

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disease that most commonly presents with arthralgia with early morning stiffness. It predominantly occurs in middle-aged women. Other important features of SLE include malar rash, discoid rash, photosensitivity, oral ulcers, pleuritis, pericarditis, and  lupus nephritis.

Anti nuclear antibodies, Anti-dsDNA antibodies, anti-smith antibodies are positive in SLE.

 

Related Pearl: Auto antibodies in a few disorders

Auto-antibodies in myasthenia gravis:

i) Anti-acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies

ii) Anti-muscle-specific kinase (MuSK) antibodies

iii) Anti-low density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 4 (LRP4) antibodies

Anti-C1q antibodies are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and membrane proliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN). 

Anti-Smith antibodies (Anti-Sm) are associated with SLE.

Anti-lysosome associated membrane protein-2 (LAMP-2) antibodies are associated with certain types of vasculitis.

questions.text: A patient came to casualty complaining of a severe headache. On examination, there was no focal neurological defect. However, neck rigidity was present. The casualty medical officer ordered an emergency CT which revealed the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH).

The most common cause of SAH is trauma. The most common spontaneous cause of SAH is the rupture of berry aneurysms.

It clinically presents as a thunderclap headache with neck rigidity, transient loss of consciousness and no focal neurological deficit. Non-contrast CT shows blood in the basal cistern.

Although sudden headache in the absence of focal neurological symptoms is the hallmark of aneurysmal rupture, focal neurological deficits may occur.

Related Pearl: Intracranial Hemorrhage (ICH)

Extradural hemorrhage (EDH): 

  • Source: Arterial bleed
  • MC- Middle meningeal artery 
  • Cause- Trauma 
  • Clinical features: Lucid interval is characteristic 
  • CT – Lentiform opacity 
  • Treatment: A large or rapidly evolving EDH requires surgical evacuation

 

Subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous bleed 
  • Bridging dural veins 
  • Causes: Trauma, anticoagulants, antiplatelets, alcohol abuse, shaken baby syndrome 
  • Clinical features
    • Acute SDH: may be associated with lucid interval
    • Chronic SDH: drowsiness, headache
  • CT- crescentic opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH)

  • Source: Arterial bleed 
  • Causes:
    • MC – Trauma
    • 2nd MC – Rupture of berry aneurysm
  • MC sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery 
  • Clinical features: Thunderclap headache with neck stiffness +/- FND 
  • Investigations:
    • Non-contrast CT brain,
    • CSF xanthochromia (peaks in 2 days and subsides in 2 weeks) 
  • Treatment:
    • Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm,
    • Triple H therapy – hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution to prevent vasospasm 

 

Intraparenchymal hemorrhage- (MC type of ICH)

  • Source- Arterial bleed 
  • Causes:
    • MC – hypertension
    • Trauma, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, bleeding disorders, neoplasms, vascular malformations 
  • MC sites:
    • Putamen (basal ganglia)
    • Thalamus
    • Cerebellum
    • Pons 
  • Treatment:
    • Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP or fresh platelets as required
    • Surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoms >3 cm in size

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presented with weight loss, decreased appetite, and iron deficiency anemia. Chest X-ray was done and given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray depicts multiple large, well-circumscribed, round pulmonary metastases that look similar to cannonballs. Hence it is known as cannonball metastasis that is seen in lung metastasis.

The most common primaries to result in pulmonary metastases in adults include:

  • Breast carcinoma
  • Colorectal carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Uterine leiomyosarcoma
  • Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma

questions.text: A 55-year-old construction factory worker presents with dyspnoea. He has been working in this industry for the past 25 years. Which is the most specific malignancy that we can expect in this patient?
questions.solution:
Construction factory workers show an increased risk of exposure to asbestos. The most specific malignancy in a patient with asbestosis is malignant mesothelioma.

Malignant mesothelioma is a rare malignant tumour of the pleura, associated with heavy asbestos exposure. The lifetime risk of developing mesothelioma in heavily exposed individuals is as high as 7% to 10%.

Asbestosis is a diffuse interstitial fibrosing disease of the lung. Characteristic findings include:

  • Irregular or linear opacities - Pleural plaques that are usually first noted in the lower lung fields are the chest radiographic hallmark of asbestosis.
  • An indistinct heart border or a “ground-glass” appearance in the lung fields may be seen.
  • Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis reveals a restrictive pattern with a decrease in both lung volumes and diffusing capacity along with mild airflow obstruction (due to peribronchiolar fibrosis).
  • Lung cancer is the most common asbestos-related cancer.
  • Mesothelioma (pleural and peritoneal) is the most specific asbestos-related cancer.

Adenocarcinoma of lung is still the most common malignancy seen in patients with asbestosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient comes to your clinic with 8-month history of shortness of breath and non-productive cough. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes for the past 30 years. On physical examination, clubbing is seen and fine crackles are heard on both sides during inspiration. You perform pulmonary function tests and it shows an FVC of 78% and FEV1/FVC ratio of 92%. You request a CT scan of the chest. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pulmonary fibrosis is the most likely diagnosis in this patient given his symptoms such as shortness of breath, persistent nonproductive cough,clubbing, bilateral inspiratory crackles, pulmonary function tests, and imaging findings.

The image shows the presence of honeycombing (black arrows), traction bronchiectasis (white arrow), and a reticular pattern (black dotted arrows). The lesions are typically located along subpleural regions.

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is the most common cause of interstitial lung disease (ILD) of unknown cause. Usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) is the typical pathological finding in patients with suspected idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF).

Patients with UIP typically present in their sixth and seventh decades. Men are affected more commonly than women. PFTs in patients with pulmonary fibrosis show a restrictive pattern. High-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) demonstrates a characteristic pattern of peripheral (subpleural), bibasilar reticular opacities associated with architectural distortion, including honeycomb changes and traction bronchiectasis.

Classification of ILD:

Based on the histopathological pattern on lung biopsy-

Histologic pattern Clinical syndrome
Usual interstitial pneumonia Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis
Desquamative Interstitial Pneumonia Desquamative interstitial pneumonia
Acute interstitial pneumonia Hamman–Rich syndrome
Bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP) Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia
Non-specific interstitial pneumonia Non-specific interstitial pneumonia
Respiratory bronchiolitis associated lung disease Respiratory bronchiolitis associated interstitial lung disease

questions.text: What is the most commonly seen pattern in chest CT of patients affected with COVID-19?
questions.solution:
Ground glass opacity (GGO) is the most commonly seen pattern in chest CT of patients with COVID-19. 

Some of the typical features seen in the CT scans of COVID-19 patients include:

  • Ground glass opacities
  • Consolidation
  • Air bronchograms
  • Interlobular septal thickenings
  • Visible intralobular lines (crazy-paving pattern)
  • Reversed halo sign 

The image given below shows an axial CT scan with multiple patchy areas of pure ground-glass opacities bilaterally. GGO are hazy areas with slightly increased density in lungs without obscuration of underlying bronchial and vascular margins. 

The image given below shows a CT scan with bilateral GGO in the lower lobe (red frames) and air bronchogram (white arrow) in the left subpleural area. Air bronchograms appear like air-filled bronchi within a highly attenuated parenchymal background. These are dilated bronchi filled with mucus plugs and do not truly contain air. 

The image given below shows a CT scan with multiple consolidation areas and interlobular septal thickening (arrows) in both the lungs. The pulmonary interstitial structures such as interlobular septa and intralobular lines can thicken and manifest as small linear opacities. 

The image given below shows a CT scan with crazy-paving pattern (black circled areas). It is defined as the presence of GGOs with superimposed interlobular septal thickening giving the appearance of irregular paving stones.

The image given below shows a CT scan with multiple lesions with reversed halo sign(arrows). The reversed halo sign or atoll sign is the presence of a ring-like area of consolidation with a superimposed rounded GGO.

questions.text: Following gastrectomy, the patient is most likely to have which of the following?
questions.solution:
After gastrectomy, the patient is likely to have vitamin B12 deficiency.

Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the ileum. Vitamin B12 binds to intrinsic factor, a protein secreted by the parietal cells of the stomach, and the complex is absorbed across the ileal mucosa. Hence after gastrectomy IF-B12 complex is not formed and there is impaired absorption of vitamin B12.

Folic acid is absorbed mainly in Jejunum.

Gastric ulcer does not occur following gastrectomy.

Constipation is not common after gastrectomy. 

Related Pearl: Major Sites of Absorption of Hematopoietic Factors

  • Duodenum + upper jejunum: Iron
  • Jejunum: Folate
  • Terminal Ileum: Vitamin B12

Mnemonic - Dude Is Just Feeling Ill Bro

Related Pearl: Causes of Megaloblastic Anemia

Vitamin B12 Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Vegetarianism
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Intrinsic factor deficiency
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Gastrectomy
    • Malabsorption states
    • Diffuse intestinal disease (e.g., lymphoma, systemic sclerosis)
    • Ileal resection
    • Ileitis
  • Competitive parasitic uptake
    • Fish tapeworm infestation
    • Bacterial overgrowth in blind loops and diverticula of bowel

Folic Acid Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Alcoholism
    • Infancy
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Malabsorption states
    • Intrinsic intestinal disease
    • Anticonvulsants
    • Oral contraceptives
  • Increased Loss
    • Hemodialysis
  • Increased Requirement
    • Pregnancy, infancy
    • Disseminated cancer
    • Markedly increased hematopoiesis
  • Impaired Utilization
    • Folic acid antagonists
    • Unresponsive to vitamin B12 or folic acid therapy
    • Metabolic inhibitors of DNA synthesis and/or folate metabolism

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents with chronic back pain, easy fatigability, and a history of multiple urinary tract infections over the past 3 months. His ESR is elevated, and a skull X-ray is shown below. Which of the following investigations would be useful for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is indicative of multiple myeloma, and a useful diagnostic test would be serum electrophoresis.

Multiple myeloma involves a malignant proliferation of plasma cells, resulting in excessive production of abnormal immunoglobulins, causing a spike called the M band in Serum Electrophoresis.

The given image demonstrates a sharp peak ("church spire” or M band) in the gamma globulin region. This is characteristically seen in a patient with multiple myeloma.

 

Certain common diseases and their electrophoretic pattern:

Condition  Electrophoretic pattern
Chronic infections Smooth increase in gamma globulins
Multiple myeloma Gamma globulin part is increased (M BAND)
Liver cirrhosis Reduced albumin and compensatory increase in globulin
Primary immune deficiency Gamma globulin reduced
α1 antitrypsin deficiency α1 band is thin and even lost sometimes

 Multiple myelomas: 

  • Malignant neoplasm of plasma cells characterized by:
  • Presence of monoclonal immunoglobulin or light chains in the serum and urine
  • Bone destruction (lytic lesions)
  • Disease of older adults, with a peak age of incidence of 65 to 70 years
  • Signs and symptoms
    • Hypercalcemia
    • Pathologic fractures/lytic bone lesions
    • Renal failure
    • Anemia
    • Radiography: Punched-out lytic lesions on X-ray
    • Electrophoresis: Monoclonal elevation of one immunoglobulin
    • Urinalysis: Free kappa and lambda light chains (Bence Jones proteins)
    • Bone marrow biopsy: 10 to 20%plasma cells (normal is < 5%)
    • Peripheral smear: Rouleaux formation (High level of M proteins in myeloma causes red cells in the peripheral blood smears to stick to one another in linear arrays, a finding referred to as rouleaux formation.)
  • Plasma cell tumors are positive for CD138

questions.text: A man was working in a field and he suddenly collapsed on a hot summer afternoon. On examination, there were no physical signs of dehydration but radial pulse was present.  His serum electrolytes level was normal. The doctor found that the body temperature was 106 degrees Fahrenheit. Which of the following should be given as first aid in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette in a patient with no signs of dehydration and body temperature of 106oF is highly suggestive of heatstroke. The first step among the following options is to cover the patient with a cool damp sheet to reduce body temperature. 

The following are the first aid measures to be done for heatstroke:

  • Move the person to a cool environment.
  • Remove any restricting clothes to dissipate the heat.
  • Try cooling the patient by blowing air using a fan, spraying water using a hose or sponge, using cool damp sheets or blankets, immersing the patient in a tub of water or shower, ice bath, etc. 
  • Place ice packs on the groin, neck, back, and armpits where the blood vessels are seen close to the skin, which reduces temperature fast. 
  • If the patient is not breathing or with no pulse then CPR has to be initiated.

Heatstroke/ thermic fever/ heat hyperpyrexia is due to the failure of the heat regulation center of the hypothalamus. It is caused by failure of cutaneous circulation and sweating. The predisposing factors include high temperature, increased humidity, minor infections, old age, lack of acclimatization, alcoholism.

Heatstroke can be:

  • Exertion-induced heat stroke is seen in people with prolonged exposure to or physical exertion in high temperatures, usually without adequate training.
  • Sedentary heatstroke is a disease of elderly or infirm people whose cardiovascular systems are unable to adapt to the stress of a hot environment and release sufficient heat such that body temperature rises.

All the signs of shock are present. Patients usually present with a sudden collapse accompanied by loss of consciousness. Typical vital sign abnormalities include tachypnea, tachycardias, hypotension, and a widened pulse pressure. Other specific signs include rapid Kussmaul type of breathing, the absence of sweating with dry, hot skin, delirium, coma, convulsions, rhabdomyolysis, multiorgan failure.

Although there is no single specific diagnostic test, clinical features of exposure to heat stress, CNS dysfunction, and core temperature >104.9-degree Fahrenheit (> 40.5 degrees Celsius) help establish the preliminary diagnosis. The body temperature must be measured rectally.

Treatment includes rapidly cooling the body with ice water till the rectal temperature falls below 1020F.

Autopsy findings include the presence of edema and reduction of Purkinje's cells in the cerebellum.

There is no role of antipyretics in the control of environmentally induced hyperthermia. They also exacerbate the complications (acute kidney injury, hepatic failure, DIC).

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man presents to you with features of anemia, fever, and recurrent nosebleeds. On examination there is hepatosplenomegaly,
Lab investigations revealed: Hb = 6 g/dL, TLC count = 40,000/ cu.mm with 10% blasts and platelet count = 12,000/cu.mm. 
On further investigation, t(8;21) was detected in the blasts. 
What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture suggests leukemia.

For the diagnosis of acute myeloblastic leukemia (AML), the blast cell count should be ≥20% either in the peripheral blood or bone marrow, as per WHO criteria.

However, there are three important exceptions. For cases with lower blast count (<20%), a diagnosis of AML can be made if there is the presence of any one of the following three cytogenetic abnormalities: 

  • t(15;17) 
  • t(8;21) 
  • Inversion 16 or t(16;16)

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presented with a 1-week history of yellow skin and sclerae but is otherwise asymptomatic. He gives a history of viral infection for 10 days which resolved 2 days back. There is a history of a similar episode of icterus 2 years back for a period of 2 weeks. On further questioning, he adds that he used to have long basketball practice hours 2 years back and he used to be physically drained during that period. The current serum bilirubin is 2.4 mg/dL, unconjugated bilirubin 2.1mg/dl, conjugated bilirubin is 0.3mg/dl. Serum AST and ALT levels are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Gilbert syndrome is the most likely diagnosis in this patient.

This patient's mild jaundice and its presence seen only during a period of stress PLUS increase in unconjugated bilirubin and normal AST, ALT levels strongly point towards a diagnosis of Gilbert syndrome.

Gilbert syndrome is a benign, familial disorder inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern characterized by mild intermittent jaundice usually seen during stress, illnesses, or any other precipitating factors. There is no hemolysis or underlying liver disease. The condition is recognized to arise from a mutation in the promoter region of the UGT1A1 gene, which results in mildly decreased UDP-Glucoronyltransferase production. UDP-Glucoronyltransferase is required for the conjugation of bilirubin.

Precipitating factors in Gilbert syndrome:

  • Dehydration
  • Fasting
  • Menstrual periods
  • Illness
  • Vigorous exercise.

Other options:

  • Crigler-Najjar syndrome is of two types with type 1 having absent/trace UDP-Glucoronyltransferase production and type 2 having <10% of the normal enzyme activity. Hence, type 1 is far more severe and leads to kernicterus and neurological damage in babies. Type 2 may also lead to kernicterus occasionally. Unconjugated bilirubin is elevated. Isolated unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia in a 25-year-old male is less likely to be due to Criggler Najar type 1 syndrome. It is because patients usually die in infancy or early childhood despite the best treatment.
  • Dubin-Johnson syndrome is a benign autosomal recessive disease that is characterized by chronic conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and conspicuous brown-black melanin-like pigment deposition in the liver. The disease is caused due to mutation in multidrug resistance protein 2 (MRP-2) in hepatocytes, which is required for the transport of non-bile salt organic anions at the canalicular membranes. Liver biopsy shows characteristic deposition of black-colored pigment.
  • Rotor syndrome: similar to Dubin-Johnson syndrome but with a milder presentation. Increased conjugated bilirubin levels. Liver biopsy does not show black colored liver

Related Pearl: Hereditary Hyperbilirubinemias

Disorder Inheritance Defects in bilirubin metabolism Clinical course

Crigler-Najjar syndrome type I

AR

Crigler-Najjar syndrome type II

occasional kernicterus

questions.text: A child presents with Hb 6.3 with a history of repeated blood transfusions. Investigations show MCV- 70 fl and the peripheral smear showed a hypochromic microcytic picture. Which of the following investigations should be done next in this child?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of repeated transfusions, low Hb, low MCV, and a hypochromic microcytic picture in the smear is suggestive of thalassemia and Hb electrophoresis should be done in this for diagnosis.

Hb Electrophoresis is used for newborn screening. High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) is the investigation of choice but is not as definitive as globin gene sequencing. 

Alpha- and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively. This leads to the precipitation of the excess (unpaired) chains, interfering with red blood cell (RBC) production and survival. Disease severity is inversely correlated with the number of functioning globin chains.

Each individual carries 2 beta-chain genes and 4 alpha-chain genes.

Haemoglobin levels:

  • Normal hemoglobin pattern- HbA=95%, HbA2=3.5%, HbF =1.5%
  • Beta-thalassemia trait- HbA=90%, HbA2=5%, HbF=5%
  • Beta-thalassemia intermedia- HbA=45%, HbA2=5%, HbF=50%

Clinical features in thalassemia:

  • Anaemia
  • Jaundice and pigment gallstones
  • Skeletal deformities including facial deformities, changes in body habitus, osteopenia/osteoporosis
  • Iron overload
  • Growth impairment
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Endocrine abnormalities including hypogonadism, hypothyroidism, diabetes mellitus
  • Heart failure and arrhythmias

Laboratory studies:

  • Peripheral smear is likely to show microcytic hypochromic anaemia with target cells, teardrop cells, and some coarse basophilic stippling in certain cases. These findings are non-specific. 
  • High RBC count 
  • Low reticulocyte count
  • High LDH, high indirect bilirubin, low haptoglobin, and negative Coomb's test
  • High transferrin saturation, normal serum iron levels, elevated ferritin levels

Other options:

Option A: Measurement of serum iron is necessary to monitor for iron overload in case of repeated blood transfusion. But in this case, the first step is to confirm the diagnosis by doing Hb electrophoresis.

Option B: Direct Coomb's test is used to test for AIHA- Autoimmune hemolytic anaemia. Given the history, AIHA seems unlikely and it usually occurs in adults and is unusual in a child.

Option C: Osmotic fragility test is a test done in the case of hereditary spherocytosis. It presents with splenomegaly, anemia, and hyperbilirubinemia. The MCV is decreased and MCHC is increased due to dehydration. It is unlikely to have a history of chronic blood transfusion.

Related Pearl: Thalassemia syndromes

Normally each individual carries 4 functional alpha chain genes and 2 functional beta chain genes. Alpha and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively.

  • Alpha thalassemia: Gene deletion is the most common cause of reduced α-chain synthesis.
  • Beta +- thalassemia: The most common cause is splicing mutation.
  • Beta 0- thalassemia: Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause.

The table below describes the features of typical thalassemia syndromes:

Alpha thalassemias  Hb Barts HbH disease  Minor Silent carrier
Genotype (- - / - - )

(α -/ - -)

or

(α* -/ - -)

(α -/α -)

or

(α α/- -)

Hemoglobin electro-phoresis Hb Barts (γ globin tetramers); Hb Portland (embryonic hemoglobin); no HbF, HbA, or HbA2 HbH (beta-globin tetramers -up to 30%); HbA2 (up to 4%) Hb Barts (3 to 8%) Normal

"-" denotes deletion of an alpha gene and "α" denotes normal alpha gene and "α* " refers to a mutant alpha chain gene.

Beta thalassemias Major (transfusion-dependent) Intermedia (non-transfusion-dependent) Minor (also called trait or carrier)

β0 refers to no beta-globin production; β+ refers to decreased beta-globin production.

Related Pearl: Differential Diagnosis of Microcytic Anaemia
