questions.text: A patient was admitted to the ICU 48 hours after the fracture of the femur. The saturation of oxygen in the rebreathing unit was 100% but his SpO2 remained at 60%. The patient is in a state of confusion. Chest radiograph showed lung fields to be clear. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of the above clinical scenario is a fat embolism. The presence of respiratory insufficiency and altered mental status following a long bone fracture (fracture of the femur) favors the diagnosis.

Fat embolism syndrome results from the presence of numerous fat emboli within the microcirculation. It most commonly occurs after the fracture of the long bone or pelvis. They present with non-specific symptoms like tachypnea, tachycardia, and fever that manifest within 24- 48 hours after the injury. Damage to the microvasculature of various organs leads to :

  • Mild hypoxia to rapidly progressing respiratory failure.
  • Depression of the central nervous system.
  • Petechial rashes
  • Hemorrhagic lesions of the retina.

Related Pearl: Gurd's criteria for diagnosing fat embolism syndrome

Major criteria
  • Axillary or subconjunctival petechiae
  • Hypoxemia with PaO2 <60 mmHg, FIO2 < 0.4
  • CNS depression disproportionate to the hypoxemia
  • Pulmonary edema

Minor criteria

  • Tachycardia (HR >110 beats per minute)
  • Pyrexia (temp >38.50C)
  • Emboli visible in retina
  • Fat globules in urine
  • Fat globules in sputum
  • Unexplanied drop in hematocrit or platelet count 
  • Increased ESR

 At least one major criterion and four minor criteria are required to make a diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome.

questions.text: A resident is evaluating a patient, who presented with acute onset of chest pain and dyspnea, for pulmonary embolism. Which of the following imaging test should be performed to confirm this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
CT pulmonary angiography should be performed as it is the principal imaging test for the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism (PE).

Option A: Most patients with acute PE have normal echocardiograms. However, echocardiography is a very useful diagnostic tool for detecting conditions that may mimic PE, such as acute myocardial infarction, pericardial tamponade, and aortic dissection.

Option C: Ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) scanning has become a second-line diagnostic test for PE, used mostly for patients who cannot tolerate intravenous contrast or in whom the CT results are inconclusive.

Option D: MR pulmonary angiography may detect large proximal PE but is not reliable for smaller segmental and subsegmental PE. It is used when neither CT angiography nor ventilation-perfusion scan can be done. 

The images below demonstrate a pulmonary embolus (marked by arrows). The image of the gross specimen shows saddle thromboembolism.

questions.text: A patient presents with severe pain and swelling in his knee joint since 10 days. He also complains of pain and discomfort during urination. He says that he had diarrhoea one month ago and he has been unwell since then. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes acute arthritis following an infection which is also associated with urethritis and generalized malaise. These features are suggestive of reactive arthritis.

Reactive arthritis is a seronegative spondyloarthritis that occurs as a consequnece of a recent enteric or urogenital infection. It is associated with HLA B27. It is also associated with extra-articular manifestations:

  • Urogenital- urethritis, prostitis, cervicitis
  • Ocular- conjuctivitis, anterior uveitis
  • Mucocutaneous- oral ulcers, keratoderma blennorrhagica, circinate balanitis

It presents as a triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis in some patients.

questions.text: A young male child was brought for psychiatric evaluation for intellectual disability. On examination, his IQ was 45. He has a long face, large ear, large testis and a cardiac murmur. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette along with the family history is suggestive of fragile X syndrome.

  • Fragile X syndrome is the second most common genetic cause of mental retardation (Down syndrome being the most common).
  • It is caused by a trinucleotide mutation in the familial mental retardation-1 (FMR1) gene.
  • When the cells were cultured in a folate-deficient medium, the cytogenetic alteration was discovered as a break in the staining in the long arm of the X chromosome. As it appeared that the chromosome was “broken” at this locale, it was named as a fragile site.
  • In fragile X syndrome, the affected males are mentally retarded, with an IQ in the range of 20 to 60.
  • The characteristic phenotypic features includes:
    • Long face with a large mandible
    • Large everted ears
    • Large testicles (macro-orchidism)
  • In some cases, hyperextensible joints, a high arched palate, and mitral valve prolapse may also be noted.

questions.text: Treatment of Grade I Meningioma?
questions.solution:
Treatment of Grade I Meningioma is Simple surgical excision.

Meningioma:

Meningiomas are predominantly benign tumors of adults, usually attached to the dura, that arise from the meningothelial cells of the arachnoid. Meningiomas may be found along any of the external surfaces of the brain as well as within the ventricular system, where they arise from the stromal arachnoid cells of the choroid plexus.

Meningiomas are usually rounded masses with well-defined dural bases that compress the underlying brain but are easily separated from it. The surface of the mass is usually encapsulated by thin, fibrous tissue and may have a bosselated or polypoid appearance.

They may also grow en plaque, in which the tumor spreads in a sheetlike fashion along the surface of the dura.

WHO grading of meningiomas:

  • Grade I - Most meningiomas fall under this category. For example - Syncytial, fibroblastic, transitional, psammomatous, secretory, microcytic.
    • Simple surgical excision is the treatment.
  • Grade II - They are also called atypical meningiomas. These have a higher rate of recurrence and more aggressive growth. For example- Clear cell and chordoid type of meningiomas.
    • These may require radiotherapy in addition to surgery.
  • Grade III - These are called anaplastic (malignant) meningiomas and are highly aggressive tumors - Papillary and rhabdoid meningiomas are examples. Surgical excision of the tumor and the tissue it has invaded is the mainstay.
    • Radiotherapy is an additional treatment. The recurrence rate is high even after tumor excision.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old male is brought to the ER after he was hit by a motorbike while he was crossing the road. He sustained injuries over his abdomen with visible bruising. His blood pressure is 88/60 and IV fluids are immediately instituted. A FAST was done and it was positive. Which of the following is the next step in the management of this patient?

FAST: (Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma)
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of blunt abdominal injury. In hemodynamically unstable patients with FAST positive, the next step of management is exploratory laparotomy. 

Blunt abdominal injury:

Primary assessment (i.e the primary survey) follows the ABCDE pattern: Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability (neurologic status), and Exposure. It is crucial to realize that the absence of abdominal pain or tenderness does not rule out the presence of significant intra-abdominal injury.

The following signs strongly correlate with intraabdominal injury

  • Seatbelt sign
  • Rebound tenderness
  • Hypotension 
  • Abdominal distension
  • Abdominal guarding
  • Concomitant femur fracture 

The management is as detailed in the protocol given below:

Bedside ultrasound (US) focuses on dependent intraperitoneal sites where blood is most likely to accumulate: the hepatorenal space (Morison's pouch), the splenorenal recess, and the inferior portion of the peritoneal cavity (including pouch of Douglas). These studies, when combined with an evaluation of the pericardium are referred to as the FAST exam (Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma).

questions.text: What is the most common cause of death in case of esophageal varices in a patient with liver cirrhosis:
questions.solution:
The most common cause of death in esophageal varices in a patient with liver cirrhosis is hypovolemic shock due to variceal bleed/hemorrhage.

Hypovolemic shock is the most common type of shock and to some degree is a component of all other types of shock.

Shock is defined as a systemic state of low tissue perfusion which is inadequate for normal cellular respiration.

Shock can be classified as follows:

Shock Inciting mechanism
Hypovolemic shock

Reduced circulating blood volume

(eg., hemorrhage, dehydration)
Cardiogenic shock

Failure of the cardiac pump

(eg., myocardial infarction, cardiac dysrhythmias)
Obstructive shock

Mechanical obstruction of cardiac filling 

(eg., cardiac tamponade, tension pneumothorax)
Distributive shock

Systemic vasodilation leading to organ hypoperfusion

(eg., anaphylaxis due to histamine release, sepsis due to the release of bacterial products, spinal cord injury due to sympathetic failure)
Endocrine shock

Combination of hypovolemic, cardiogenic or distributive shock.

(eg., hypo and hyperthyroidism, adrenal insufficiency)

questions.text: A 32-year-old male chronic smoker presents with pain in the fingers for a few months.  On examination, gangrenous ulcers were present in the fingers as shown below. Investigations showed blood glucose and lipid profile within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette along with the image is suggestive of Buerger's disease or thromboangitis obliterans (TAO). 

A young male smoker, presenting with chronic pain, with no history of diabetes and hyperlipidemia and gangrenous ulcers as shown in the image are points in favor of Buerger's disease.

Buerger's disease is a nonatherosclerotic segmental inflammatory occlusive vascular disorder involving small and medium-sized arteries of the upper and lower limb.

It is predominantly seen in young male smokers. Patients mainly present with claudication pain of extremities and later with ischemic rest pain and ulcers. Atherogenic conditions like diabetes and dyslipidemia should be excluded.

The following criteria must be met for the diagnosis of TAO:

  • Age younger than 45 years
  • History of tobacco use
  • Distal extremity ischemia like claudication pain or ulcer
  • Autoimmune diseases, hypercoagulable state, dyslipidemia, diabetes mellitus must be excluded
  • Consistent arteriographic findings in the limbs
  • A proximal source of atheroemboli must be excluded

Angiography shows segmental occlusions as skip lesions of the small and medium-sized vessels with the formation of extensive collaterals around the occlusions. These are called corkscrew collaterals. These represent dilated vaso vasorm of the occluded vessels. 

They may also present with pain, paraesthesia, and color changes of the digits of the hand and feet in response to cold and anxiety. The is called as Raynaud phenomenon. 

The image below shows the Raynaud phenomenon in the digits of the hand.

questions.text: An 80-year-old man developed right-sided calf muscle pain and swelling. He was bedridden following a right inter-trochanteric fracture. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of deep vein thrombosis. It occurs due to immobilization and venous stasis.

It most commonly occurs in the calf veins and less often in the proximal veins of the thigh and pelvis. It is caused due to Virchow's triad:

  • Hemodynamic changes (stasis or turbulence)
  • Hypercoagulabilty 
  • Endothelial injury/dysfunction

It is usually asymptomatic. Some patients may present with pain in the calf or thigh. There may be an increase in temperature and pulse rate. Calf swelling and tenderness may be noted. Increased pain on passive dorsiflexion of the foot (Homan's test), although frequently used is now regarded as an unreliable sign.

Related Pearl: Prophylaxis for DVT

Mechanical prophylaxis
Early ambulation

Acts by activating the calf pump mechanism
Pneumatic compression stocking

Prevents stasis by periodically compressing the calves
Pharmacological prophylaxis

Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) - Enoxaparin

Fondaparinux

 Prevent thrombus formation by inhibiting factor Xa

Apixaban

Rivaroxaban 

  Oral factor Xa inhibitors

Unfractionated heparin (UFH)

Prevents action of factors VIII - XII and production of thrombin/fibrin.

Used in renal insufficiency

Warfarin

Inhibits hepatic production of factors II, VII, IX and X

questions.text: A 30-year-old lactating mother presents with pain in her left breast and fever. On examination of the affected side, there is localized erythema, warmth, point tenderness, fluctuation test is positive. There is mild axillary lymphadenopathy on the affected side and the contralateral breast is normal. Repeated aspirations under antibiotic cover done were unsuccessful. A USG done showed fluid collection. What is the management plan for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario points towards a diagnosis of breast abscess. The latest guidelines for the management of breast abscess specify that multiple aspirations under antibiotic cover should be attempted before an incision and drainage are done. This often allows resolution without the need for an incision scar and also allows the patient to continue breastfeeding. But here aspirations have been unsuccessful and thus incision and drainage have to be the next step in the management of this patient.

Mastitis occurs due to the growth of staphylococcus or streptococcus due to breast milk stasis. This occurs secondary to blockage of lactiferous duct or due to incomplete emptying of breast milk or due to retracted nipple. Overgrowth of these bacteria results in the development of breast abscesses.

It is commoner in new mothers at the beginning of lactation who are inexperienced with breastfeeding or during weaning when nipple trauma occurs due to the infant's growing teeth. 

Signs and symptoms of this condition involve:

  • Fever and malaise
  • Localized pain and tenderness 
  • Redness and swelling of the affected breast
  • Fluctuation test positive due to pus in the abscess. It is a late sign.

The initial treatment should involve providing pain relief with analgesics. The abscess should then be localized preferably under USG guidance and percutaneous aspiration carried out. The pus should be sent for microbiological examination to find the organism and antibiotic sensitivity. Repeated aspirations may be carried out under antibiotics cover if needed.

In some conditions mentioned below, the breast abscess may be unresponsive to repeated aspirations and antibiotic cover. In such cases, incision and drainage are performed. The conditions include:

  • Presence of thick pus
  • Bacteria resistant to antibiotics
  • If just superficial part has been aspirated in the presence of a multiloculated abscess
  • A non-healing breast abscess due to tuberculosis of breast or Inflammatory carcinoma of the breast, or an immunocompromised host.

The below table summarises likely features to differentiate Bacterial mastitis from a Breast abscess

  Bacterial mastitis Breast abscess
Condition Localized inflammation
due to ascending infection 
or infection due to milk stasis 		 Occurs as a complication of mastitis
Pus formation
Symptoms Dull pain Throbbing pain
Signs (if any) Tenderness
Erythema		 Point tenderness
Erythema
Induration of skin(if chronic)
Lymphadenopathy
Fluctuation test +ve
Management Analgesics

Aspiration of Pus

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to the surgery out-patient with a left-sided breast lump which she noticed on self breast examination  3weeks ago. She has no other complaints. On palpation, the lump seems to be mobile and firm. Mammogram revealed a benign lesion. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis based on the clinical scenario is fibroadenoma and the best next step in the management of Fibroadenoma is to Reassure the patient and do regular follow-up.

Fibroadenoma is one of the aberrations of normal development and involution of the breast (ANDI). The most common age group affected is 15-25 years (early reproductive period) with a peak incidence in the second decade.

It arises from hyperplasia of a single lobule and presents as a well-circumscribed, smooth, firm, non-tender, freely mobile mass (mouse in the breast). It is a biphasic tumor consisting of fibroblastic stroma and epithelium-lined gland. Popcorn calcification is seen in mammography.

Option A : Biopsy is not required for Fibroadenoma unless there is a suspicion of Malignancy but based on the clinical and imaging findings the given lesion is benign.

Option C:Excision is not advised unless there is suspicious histology on fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC). Giant fibroadenomas are >5 cm in size, common in adolescent girls, and require excision by submammary incision.

Option D: Tamoxifen is a SERM-Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator used in the management of ER positive Breast carcinoma.

questions.text: The false statement about cystic masses of the neck is:

choices.text: Type 3 Branchial fistula has its internal orifice on cricopharynxgeus
Cystic hygroma is filled with clear lymph
Thyroglossal cyst moves upwards on swallowing and tongue protrusion
Fluctuation is positive in branchial cyst

questions.solution:
Branchial fistulas may be congenital or acquired. The external orifice of the Type 3 Branchial fistula is seen at the junction of the middle and lower third of the sternomastoid and the internal orifice is present on the pyriform sinus of the pharynx and the tract courses between internal and external carotid arteries . An acquired fistula is usually seen in cases of incomplete excision for the branchial cyst or spontaneous rupture, and it is seen at the same site as the cyst.

Treatment is complete excision of the cyst or fistula to avoid recurrence.

Branchial cysts are fluctuant.

The below image shows a large right-sided branchial cyst.

Cystic hygroma is a cystic swelling due to the sequestration of a portion of the jugular lymph sac. It usually presents in the early infancy or at birth which may obstruct labor. The cyst contains clear lymph and is lined by a single layer of epithelium with a mosaic appearance.  

Below is an image showing a child with cystic hygroma.

Thyroglossal cysts are persistent thyroglossal duct tracts and thus can be found anywhere along or adjacent to the midline from the base of tongue to the thyroid isthmus. The cyst moves upwards while swallowing or on tongue protrusion.  

Below is the image of a thyroglossal cyst.

questions.text: What is the preferred management of the condition given in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image shows a dermoid cyst and the preferred management of this condition is surgical excision.

A dermoid cyst is a benign developmental anomaly that arises from the entrapment of ectodermal elements along the lines of embryonic closure. They are lined by stratified squamous epithelium with mature skin appendages found on their wall and their lumens filled with keratin and hair.

They are considered to be congenital and usually present within the first year of life and grow slowly. They occur most commonly on the head and neck in the frontal, occipital, and supraorbital areas, with the outer third of the eyebrow being the most frequently affected region.

They present as a flesh-coloured, dome-shaped, firm, deep-seated, subcutaneous nodule. They are usually asymptomatic, non-pulsatile, and non-compressible. 

On ultrasound, they show a well-defined homogenous and hypoechoic cystic lesion. They have the potential to grow over time and extend intracranially or intraspinally. MRI is the preferred means of revealing evidence of intracranial or intraspinal extension. 

Because most dermoid cysts grow over time, complete surgical excision without disruption of the cyst wall is the recommended management.

questions.text: A young girl presents with the complaints of continuous dribbling of urine. However, she also voids normally. Her parents tell you that she had never been totally dry since her birth. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of an ectopic ureter.

Ectopic ureter is a congenital anomaly that occurs as a result of abnormal caudal migration of the ureteral bud during its insertion into the urinary bladder. The ureter normally drains via the internal ureteral orifice at the trigone of the bladder. 

In females, the sites for ectopic ureter insertion are outside the bladder, often into the vagina or distal urethra. 

They usually present with urinary incontinence characterized by constant urinary dripping all day, even though the child voids regularly.

In females, an ectopic ureter opens either into the urethra below the sphincter or into the vagina. A woman who voids normally but who has never been dry (constant urine dribbling) is called paradoxical incontinence which is seen in an ectopic ureteral orifice.

questions.text: A 1-month-old child is brought to the OPD for consultation regarding an empty scrotal sac. On examination B/L inguinal masses are palpable. What is the next step of management in this child?

choices.text: Wait and watch for spontaneous descent within the next 6months

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario the age of the child is 1month and the normal age till which testes can spontaneously descend is 6months , So the best next step of management would be to Wait and watch for spontaneous descent within the next 6months.

Orchidopexy is ideally performed before the boy reaches 12 months of age.

Orchidopexy is done before 12 months of age to avoid the following complications:

  • Infertility
  • Malignancy (Risk may still exist post surgery)
  • Hernia
  • Testicular torsion
  • Infection

Option A : Karyotyping is not necessary in case of undescended testes.

The management for undescended testes that are not palpable is:

questions.text: A patient presents with repetitive episodes of heartburn and chest pain. What is the most common condition that causes these symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient is most likely suffering from dyspepsia and the most common cause of dyspepsia among the given options is esophagitis.

Dyspepsia refers to symptoms of epigastric pain, burning, postprandial fullness or early satiety, sometimes with heartburn condition based on the symptoms is esophagitis. Gastroesophageal reflux which causes esophagitis is the common cause of dyspepsia.

Esophagitis is the most common cause of heartburn and non-cardiac chest pain. The reflux of gastric acid into the lower oesophagus is the most frequent cause of esophagitis. The most common cause of gastroesophageal reflux is transient lower oesophagal sphincter relaxation.

Clinical significance: Reflux esophagitis → chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) → Barrett oesophagus → adenocarcinoma

Related Pearl: The most commons in GIT

The most commons in GIT:

  • Most common congenital intestinal atresia: Imperforate anus
  • Most common true diverticulum: Meckel's diverticulum
  • Most common site of ischemia: Colon
  • Most common site of fistulization: Esophagus
  • Most common site of GI Polyp: Colorectum
  • Most common malignancy of GI tract: Adenocarcinoma colon
  • Most frequent cause of esophagitis: Acid reflux
  • Most common benign tumor of esophagus: Leiomyoma
  • Most common esophageal cancer in India and worldwide: Squamous cell carcinoma
  • Most common esophageal cancer in Western countries: Adenocarcinoma
  • Most common type of chronic gastritis: Type B gastritis (Helicobacter pylori gastritis)
  • Most common malignancy of the stomach: Adenocarcinoma
  • Most common site of extranodal lymphoma: Stomach
  • Most common mesenchymal tumor of the stomach: Gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST)
  • Most common tumor of the small intestine/appendix: Carcinoid

 

Related Pearl: Endoscopic Findings in Esophagitis

 

Conditions Endoscopic findings
Infectious esophagitis Diffuse and involve the proximal esophagus  
HSV esophagitis Vesicles and small punched-out lesions (volcano ulcers)
CMV esophagitis Serpiginous ulcers
Peptic esophagitis Solitary and distal  
Eosinophilic esophagitis Multiple esophageal rings, linear furrows, or white punctate exudates (feline esophagus)
Pill esophagitis Singular and deep at points of luminal narrowing with sparing of the distal esophagus
Candida esophagitis White friable plaques

HSV: Herpes simplex virus

CMV: Cytomegalovirus

questions.text: A baby playing unsupervised was brought with complaints of difficulty in swallowing for the last few hours.  The X-ray image is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of the child presenting with difficulty in swallowing and the given x-rays are suggestive of a foreign body lodged in the esophagus, most likely a coin/disc battery.

The given x-rays are anteroposterior and lateral views of the chest and neck. Coins, disk batteries, and small toy items are commonly ingested in children. In adults, it is usually a food bolus (mostly meat) that gets lodged.

The flat surface of a coin in the esophagus is seen on the anteroposterior view (AP view) i.e; they are oriented in the coronal plane. The edge is seen on the lateral view.

Initial symptoms are choking, gagging, and coughing followed by excessive salivation, dysphagia, food refusal, vomiting, or pain in the neck and throat. Respiratory symptoms such as stridor, wheezing, cyanosis, or dyspnea are seen if esophageal foreign body impinges on the larynx or tracheal wall.

Imaging with AP views of chest, neck, and abdominal x-rays and lateral views of chest and neck x-rays should be done. Chest CT is warranted if airway perforation is suspected.

Treatment:

  • Asymptomatic patients with blunt objects/coin ingestion can be observed for up to 24 hours to wait for the passage of the coin into the stomach.
  • Immediate endoscopic visualization must be done in symptomatic patients. Flexible endoscopy with suitable grasping forceps is used to remove the foreign bodies. Disc batteries need urgent removal as they rapidly corrode the GI tract.

Other options:

Foreign body in the trachea: For coins lodged in the trachea, the edge is seen anteroposteriorly and the flat side is seen laterally i.e; they are oriented in the sagittal plane. 

Foreign body in lungs and pleura would be shown down below in the intercostal area.

questions.text: A patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy and was discharged after removing the drain tube on the first postoperative day. On day two, the patient came back to the hospital with complaints of increasing abdominal pain and was febrile on examination. On ultrasound examination, there was a 5 x 5 cm collection in the subhepatic space. What is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation suggests a bile duct injury following laparoscopic cholecystectomy leading to a bile leak. 

Bile duct injury

  • Usually is manifested in the postoperative period
  • Clinical features
    • Fever
    • Increasing abdominal pain
    • Jaundice
    • Bile leakage from an incision

Diagnosis

Imaging: Ultrasonography

  • To assess for a fluid collection and to evaluate the biliary tree 

Treatment strategy

  • Control of infection, limiting inflammation
    • Percutaneous drainage of periportal fluid collections
    • Parenteral antibiotics
  • Clear and thorough delineation of the entire biliary anatomy
    • Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) or percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC)
    • Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), especially if a cystic-duct stump leak is suspected
  • Reestablishment of biliary-enteric continuity (surgery)
    1. Tension-free, mucosa-to-mucosa anastomosis
    2. Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy

 Option A: Infection is very unlikely to present in the immediate postoperative period with a pus collection of 5x5cms particularly after laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

Option B: Surgical site pain will not be severe and diffuse instead it is localized and bearable.

Option D: Retained gallstones are very unlikely.

questions.text: A 40-year old lady is found to have a gall bladder polyp of size 5 mm on abdominal USG with no associated gall bladder stones. She appears to be healthy and is asymptomatic. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Since the woman is asymptomatic with no risk factors and the size of the polyp is less than 10mm, regular follow-up with USG is only needed. 

Gallbladder polyps larger than 1 cm have an increased risk of malignancy and should be treated by performing an open cholecystectomy. 

Open cholecystectomy is preferred over laparoscopic cholecystectomy. This is because of the higher rates of port-site recurrence of malignancy and peritoneal dissemination caused by intraoperative perforation of the gallbladder in laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

Related Pearl: Indication for Cholecystectomy in Gallbladder Polyp

  • All symptomatic patients
  • All asymptomatic patients >50 years
  • Polyp of size >10 mm
  • Evidence of polyp growth on serial ultrasonography

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common side effect of cholecystectomy?
questions.solution:
The most common side effect of cholecystectomy is steatorrhea. Steatorrhea is fecal fat excretion of more than 7 g/24 hours or >6% /24 hours, when on a diet of 100 to 150 g of fat. Gall Bladder is the major source of Bile and Bile plays an important role in the absorption of fats/lipids. Hence Cholecystectomy can lead to steatorrhea.

Digestion of Lipids

  • Pancreatic lipase is the most important enzymes involved in lipid digestion. Main products of its action are FFA and 2-monoglycerides (2-monoacylglycerols
  • Colipase is an accessory factor secreted in the pancreatic juice that helps to stabilize pancreatic lipase in an active conformation
  • Bile acids emulsify the insoluble lipids and make them reach the surface of the mucosal cells. Bile acids also activate another pancreatic lipase called cholesterol esterase. 
  • Cholesterol esterase hydrolysis cholesterol esters, esters of fat-soluble vitamins, phospholipids, and triglycerides

questions.text: A young man presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe abdominal pain and 3 episodes of vomiting in the past 9 hours. He says that the pain radiates to the back and is partially relieved by bending forwards. The abdominal radiograph of the patient is given below which shows 'colon cut-off sign". What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinial scenario and thr image showing colon cut-off sign is seen in acute pancreatitis.

The colon cut-off sign refers to the abrupt termination of the gas filling of the colon on the left side. The inflammation of acute pancreatitis may extend to the phrenicocolic ligament via the transverse mesocolon. This causes functional spasm of the splenic flexure resulting in the colon cut-off sign.

 Acute pancreatitis:

Causes of pancreatitis -

  • Gallstones
  • Alcoholism
  • Post ERCP
  • Abdominal trauma
  • Following biliary, upper gastrointestinal or cardiothoracic surgery
  • Ampullary tumor
  • Drugs (corticosteroids, azathioprine, asparaginase, valproic acid, thiazides, estrogens)
  • Hyperparathyroidism
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Pancreas divisum
  • Autoimmune pancreatitis
  • Hereditary pancreatitis
  • Viral infections (mumps, coxsackie B)
  • Malnutrition
  • Scorpion bite
  • Idiopathic

Signs and symptoms of pancreatitis-

Symptoms:

  • Acute onset of epigastric pain, which is severe, constant, and refractory to usual doses of analgesics.
  • Typically radiates to back
  • Relieved in the sitting forward position
  • Nausea, repeated vomiting, retching, and hiccups

Signs:

  • Hypotension, tachycardia, and tachypnea
  • Grey Turner sign: bluish discoloration of the flanks
  • Cullen’s sign: bluish discoloration around the umbilicus
  • Pleural effusion (left > right): dullness on percussion, decreased breath sounds

Grey turner sign is given below:

Cullen's sign is given below:

Laboratory findings in acute pancreatitis: Elevated serum amylase and serum lipase

  • Serum amylase level lacks specificity.
  • Serum amylase levels do not correlate with the severity of pancreatitis.
  • Serum lipase is more specific, and it is more useful when the patient presents 24–48 hours later.

Other features include:

  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hypocalcemia, hypoalbuminemia
  • Leukocytosis
  • Elevated serum levels of hepatic enzymes like alanine aminotransferase (ALT).
  • Azotemia, due to prerenal acute renal failure in case of severe fluid loss

Management of acute pancreatitis: It involves nil per oral orders, providing fluid replacement and pain control. Antibiotics are rarely required if the infection spreads.

Related Pearl: X-Ray Findings in Acute Pancreatitis

Radiographic findings of acute pancreatitis are non-specific.

Sentinel loop sign: Generalized or local ileus, with isolated dilation of a segment of the gut (sentinel loop) consisting of jejunum, transverse colon, or duodenum adjacent to the pancreas

Colon cut-off sign: Functional spasm at the splenic flexure due to the extension of inflammation to phrenicocolic ligament via transverse mesocolon.

 

Renal halo sign: Edema around the kidney due to the involvement of paranephric fat resulting in:

  • Obliteration of psoas shadow
  • Localised ground-glass appearance

questions.text: A patient presents with chronic small bowel diarrhoea.Duodenal biopsy shows villous atrophy. Anti endomysial antibodies and IgA TTG antibodies are positive. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Villous atrophy on duodenal biopsy together with a positive serological test for anti-endomysial antibodies and IgA anti TTG antibodies suggests the diagnosis of celiac sprue.

The mainstay of treatment is a Gluten-free diet.

  Celiac Sprue Tropical Sprue Whipple's Disease
Site Proximal small intestine Distal small intestine Proximal+ Distal small intestine
Extraintestinal manifestation Present (most common is Dermatitis Herpetiformis) Absent Present (MC-Migratory polyarthritis, MC in CVS-Endocarditis, MC in CNS-Dementia)
Antibodies (Antiendomysial and IgA Anti TTG) Positive Negative Negative

questions.text: The most common type of renal stones are:
questions.solution:
The most common type of renal stone is calcium oxalate stone. 

Note:

Uric acid stones are more common than calcium oxalate stones in patients with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease.

Calcium carbonate stone is the most common type of stone formed in chronic pancreatitis.

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

  • Cystine stones: Hexagonal
  • Uric acid stones: Varying shapes (rhomboids or parallelograms)
  • Calcium oxalate
    • Monohydrate: Dumbbell shaped
    • Dihydrate: Octahedral or envelope shaped
  • Struvite stones: Rectangular or coffin lid

questions.text: Whitaker test is indicated for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Whitaker test is indicated for Hydronephrosis to compare the hydrostatic pressure between the renal pelvis and bladder.

Hydronephrosis is the aseptic dilatation of the kidney caused by obstruction. It is the most common urologic abnormality found on ultrasound evaluation.

WHITAKER TEST

The Whitaker test accurately detects the functional effect of upper urinary tract dilatation by measuring hydrostatic pressures in the renal pelvis and bladder while infusing a saline and contrast solution into the renal pelvis through a catheter.

The patient is positioned in the prone position on the fluoroscopic table with a bladder catheter in place, and a cannula is introduced percutaneously into the renal pelvis and attached to a pressure transducer. At a rate of 10 mL/min, a mixture of saline and contrast material is administered through the renal cannula, and pressures are monitored. The urinary tract is deemed nonobstructed if the renal pelvic pressure is less than 15 cm H2O, equivocal between 15 and 22 cm H2O, and obstructed if the pressure is greater than 22 cm H2O.

With the introduction of noninvasive imaging technology, the test should be used exclusively in the following situations to examine probable upper urinary tract obstruction:

  • equivocal results from less invasive testing,
  • suspected blockage with poor kidney function,
  • loin discomfort with negative diuresis renogram findings,
  • suspected intermittent obstruction,
  • extensive dilatation with positive diuresis renogram findings are all possibilities.

Related Pearl: Causes of Hydronephrosis

Unilateral hydronephrosis

Extramural obstruction

  • Tumor from adjacent structures, e.g., cervix, prostate, rectum, colon, or cecum
  • Retrocaval ureter
  • Aberrant renal vessels
  • Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis (Ormond’s disease)

Intramural obstruction

  • Congenital PUJ obstruction - most common congenital cause
  • Congenital stenosis
  • Ureterocele
  • Ureteric stricture - iatrogenic/ inflammatory
  • Neoplasm of the ureter or bladder involving the ureteric orifice

Intraluminal obstruction

  • Renal stones - most common acquired unilateral cause
  • Sloughed papilla in papillary necrosis (especially, in patients with diabetes, analgesic abuse, or sickle cell disease)

Bilateral hydronephrosis

Congenital

  • Posterior urethral valves (associated with pulmonary hypoplasia)
  • Urethral atresia
  • PUJ obstruction

Acquired     

  • Benign prostatic hypertrophy or carcinoma of the prostate
  • Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis (Ormond's disease)
  • Postoperative bladder neck scarring
  • Urethral stricture
  • Phimosis

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with diffuse abdominal pain. He has a known history of Crohn's disease . Physical examination reveals rigidity and guarding. On imaging Ileal Perforation is diagnosed. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with Ileal perforation and physical examination findings of rigidity and guarding suggests peritonitis due to perforation. The next best step in the management of this patient is urgent surgical exploration with an ileostomy.

Perforation of a viscus is a life-threatening condition that occurs following the rupture of the alimentary tract. Common causes include iatrogenic (surgery, scopes) blunt or penetrating injury, bowel obstruction, peptic ulcer disease, corrosive agents, or particular medications.

This leads to the leakage of the enteric contents, thereby leading to acute bacterial peritonitis. Peritonitis is the generalized or localized inflammation of the peritoneum either due to the free spillage of fluids into the peritoneal cavity or secondary bacterial infection.

Clinical features of hollow viscous perforation occur due to the developed peritonitis and the features include abdominal pain and distension, nausea, vomiting, tachycardia, tenderness, rebound tenderness, decreased or absent bowel sounds, and guarding on palpation. Fever may be present. Sometimes, features of septic shock can be seen at later stages.

Investigations include estimating the white blood cell count, urea, serum electrolytes, and an erect abdominal radiograph showing free gas under the diaphragm. A supine radiograph may show dilated gas-filled loops of the bowel, suggestive of paralytic ileus. The below image shows a hollow viscus perforation.

Management - Initial management includes intravenous (IV) fluid therapy, cessation of oral intake, and broad-spectrum antibiotics. Indications for immediate bowel exploration are

  1. Sepsis/diffuse peritonitis(as in this patient)
  2. Bowel ischemia
  3. Complete or closed-loop bowel obstruction

Resection or repair of the perforated site with or without drainage and diversion is usually undertaken. Duodenal perforations, on the other hand, are generally treated with omental patch repair without resection.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presented with a painless mass in the right inguinal region. On examination, there is a cough impulse on the index finger and the swelling reaches down to the scrotum and is reduced completely by pressing it through the deep inguinal ring with a gurgling sound. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A swelling that reduces when pressing through the deep inguinal ring suggests a case of indirect inguinal hernia.

Indirect inguinal hernias are by far the most common type of hernia. A femoral hernia passes through the femoral triangle whereas an umbilical hernia protrudes through the umbilicus.

A direct inguinal hernia emerges through Hesselbach's triangle. The boundaries of Hesselbach’s triangle are:

  • Lateral - inferior epigastric artery
  • Medial - lateral border of rectus abdominis
  • Inferior - inguinal ligament

The test being performed in the above image is 3 finger test or Zieman’s test which is used to differentiate groin hernias.

After reducing the hernia, The examiner places his index finger on the deep inguinal ring, middle finger on the superficial inguinal ring, and ring finger over the saphenous opening. Now the patient is asked to cough or to hold the nose and blow.

Interpretation: When the impulse is felt on the,

  • Index finger: The given case is one of the indirect herniae.
  • Middle finger: The given case is one of the direct herniae.
  • Ring finger: The given case is one of the femoral herniae.

Related Pearl: Difference between direct and indirect inguinal hernia:

  Indirect hernia Direct hernia
Age Young Elderly
Herniation Through the deep inguinal ring Through the posterior wall of the inguinal canal
Shape Pyriform/oval Globular/round
Descent Obliquely and downwards Directly forwards
Descent to scrotum Complete – descends till the bottom of the scrotum Rarely complete
Neck Narrow Wide
Sac Lateral to the inferior epigastric artery Medial to the inferior epigastric artery

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents with scrotal swelling. On examination, one can feel the testis separate from the scrotal swelling and the swelling shows transillumination. The fluid aspirated from the swelling resembles barley water in appearance. The most probable diagnosis is ______
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Spermatocele.

Points in favor: If one can feel the testis separate from the scrotal swelling then the swelling is not a hydrocele but maybe a cyst of the epididymis or spermatocele. Transillumination is present. The barley water appearance of the fluid is seen in spermatocele due to the presence of spermatozoa.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man was referred to the surgery OPD from the infertility clinic. On inspection, the scrotum appeared as in the image. On palpation, a bag of worms sensation was felt. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of a varicocele.

Varicocele may present with a dull aching scrotal pain and enlargement. Additionally, patients may have infertility. A bag of worms, which gets prominent on Valsalva’s maneuver is palpated due to the engorged pampiniform plexus.

Often, patients may be asymptomatic and do not require treatment.

Grades of varicocele
Grade 1 Varicocele only palpable on Valsalva’s maneuver
Grade 2 Varicocele palpable without Valsalva’s maneuver
Grade 3 Varicocele is seen on inspection of the testis

Left-sided varicocele is more common. Isolated right-sided varicocele should always raise suspicion of renal cell carcinoma. 

Treatment of young patients includes surgical ligation of the gonadal vein. It may be achieved through embolectomy or varicocelectomy. Approaches to varicocelectomy are:

  • Inguinal ( Ivanisevic method )
  • Retroperitoneal (Palomo procedure) 
  • Natural orifice transluminal endoscopic surgery through the transvesical route

In older patients, NSAIDs and scrotal support are adequate.

questions.text: An elderly male patient presented with purulent discharge from an opening located in the perianal region. The patient is put in a lithotomy position and the opening is located at the 11 o'clock position, 4 cm from the anal margin. What will be the likely position of the internal opening and where does the internal opening start?

choices.text: 12 o'clock and at external anal spinchter
11 o'clock and at internal anal spinchter
6 o'clock and crypt of the dentate line

questions.solution:
The likely location of the internal opening is at 6'O clock position which is the posterior midline of the anal canal and the opening starts at the crypt of the dentate line.

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of fistula-in-ano with the external opening located at 11’O clock position, 4 cm from the anal margin. This means that the anal margin is located anterior to the coronal midsection. The location of the internal opening of the fistula can be identified based on Goodsall's rule.

Goodsall’s rule:

  • Fistulas with an external opening anteriorly connect to the internal opening by a short, radial tract.
  • Fistulas with an external opening posteriorly tract in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline.

However, exceptions to this rule often occur. Fistulas with an anterior external opening greater than 3 cm from the anal margin usually track to the posterior midline.

Thus, according to the exception to Goodsall's rule, this patient likely has an internal opening at the 6'O clock position as the external opening is located more than 3 cm from the anal margin track. 

A fistula-in-ano is a chronic abnormal hollow tract or cavity that is lined with granulation tissue. It has a primary internal opening in the anorectal lumen and a secondary external opening in the perianal skin. An anal fistula may also be present if the patient has Crohn's disease, tuberculosis, malignancy, foreign body, lymphogranuloma venereum, or actinomycosis. Patients usually present with intermittent discharge and pain. 

Intersphincteric fistulas are the most common type. Other types of anal fistulae are transphincteric fistula, suprasphincteric fistula, and extrasphincteric fistula.

A fistula-in-ano is a chronic abnormal hollow tract or cavity that is lined with granulation tissue. It has a primary internal opening in the anorectal lumen and a secondary external opening in the perianal skin. An anal fistula may also be present if the patient has Crohn's disease, tuberculosis, malignancy, foreign body, lymphogranuloma venereum, or actinomycosis. Patients usually present with intermittent purulent discharge and pain. 

Intersphincteric fistulas are the most common type. Other types of anal fistulae are transphincteric fistula, suprasphincteric fistula, and extrasphincteric fistula.

questions.text: What is the minimum external pressure that leads to the formation of pressure sores?
questions.solution:
The minimum external pressure that leads to the formation of pressure sores is 30 mm of Hg.

Pressure sores also known as bedsores, pressure ulcers, or decubitus ulcers are defined as tissue necrosis with ulceration due to prolonged pressure. When the external pressure exceeds the capillary occlusive pressure, blood flow ceases leading to tissue anoxia, necrosis, and ulceration. Thus an external pressure of >30mmHg leads to the formation of pressure sores.

The common sites of pressure sores in decreasing frequency are:

  • Ischium
  • Greater Trochanter
  • Sacrum
  • Heel
  • Malleolus (lateral followed by medial)
  • Occiput

A staging system for the description of pressure sores devised by the American National Pressure Ulcer Advisory Panel.

Stage 1 - Non-blanchable erythema without a breach in the epidermis
Stage 2 - Partial-thickness skin loss involving the epidermis and dermis
Stage 3 - Full-thickness skin loss extending into the subcutaneous tissue but not through underlying fascia
Stage 4 - Full-thickness skin loss through fascia with extensive tissue destruction, maybe involving muscle, bone, tendon, or joint

Prevention is the best treatment for pressure sores. It can be done through good skincare, the use of air-fluidized beds, special pressure dispersion cushions, or foams. The position of the bedridden patients should be changed once every 2 hours and wheel-chair bound patients should be taught to get off their chairs for 10 seconds every 10 minutes.

Surgical treatment of pressure sores mainly involves wound management. The pressure sores should be adequately debrided and vacuum-assisted closure (VAC).VAC is done by applying intermittent negative pressure of approximately -125mmHg to hasten debridement and promote granulation tissue formation in chronic wounds and ulcers. Negative pressure decreases edema, removes interstitial fluid, and increases blood flow. This decreases bacterial growth and increases cell proliferation.

Large skin flaps that have muscle with sensory innervation are best for reconstruction(example-extensor fascia lata flap with the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh). Faecal or urinary diversion can be considered in special cases depending on the site of the ulcer, being prone to urine or faecal contamination.

Related Pearl: Staging of Pressure Sores

 

Stage

Description
1 Non-blanchable erythema without a breach in the epidermis
2

Partial thickness skin loss involving the epidermis and dermis
3

Full thickness skin loss extending into the subcutaneous tissue but not through underlying fascia
4 Full thickness skin loss through fascia with extensive tissue destruction, maybe involving muscle, bone, tendon or joint

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma is found to have a tumor that is 10 cm in size, situated at the lower pole of the kidney with negative regional lymph nodes. Which of the following is the preferred management for this patient?
questions.solution:
A tumor that is 10 cm in size, confined to the kidney with negative metastasis is classified as T2bN0M0. A tumor greater than 7 cm is managed by radical nephrectomy. RCC is a radio and chemoresistant tumor.

Radical Nephrectomy :

  • Classic radical nephrectomy consists of the removal of the kidney, perirenal fat, adrenal gland, and regional lymph nodes.
  • In patients with a tumor <5 cm in size, located at the inferior pole, the adrenal gland can be spared. 
  • Regional lymph node dissection is done for patients with clinically positive nodes detected by CT or during surgery.

Partial nephrectomy :

  • For tumors less than or equal to 4 cm in size and limited to the kidney (T1a), partial nephrectomy is performed.
  • Partial nephrectomy is also increasingly being performed in tumors >4cm in size but less than or equal to 7 cm, and limited to the kidney (T1b). If partial nephrectomy is not feasible in T1b tumors, then a radical nephrectomy is done.
  • Other indications for partial nephrectomy are bilateral renal cell carcinoma and carcinoma affecting a solitary functioning kidney.

Radical nephrectomy is performed in patients with large tumors and for patients in whom a partial nephrectomy is not technically feasible.

 

TNM staging for renal cell carcinoma:

T: Primary tumor

T1: Limited to the kidney, <7 cm

T1a: Tumor confined to the kidney,<4 cm

T1b: Tumor confined to the kidney, >4 cm, but <7 cm

T2: Limited to the kidney, >7 cm

T2a: Tumor confined to the kidney, >7 cm but < 10 cm

T2b: Tumor confined to the kidney, >10 cm

T3: Tumor extension into major veins or perinephric tissues, but not into the ipsilateral adrenal gland or beyond Gerota's fascia

T3a: Tumor grossly extends into the renal vein or its segmental (muscle-containing) branches, or tumor invades perirenal and/or renal sinus fat but not beyond Gerota's fascia

T3b: Spread to infra-diaphragmatic IVC

T3c: Spread to supra-diaphragmatic IVC or invades the wall of the IVC
T4: Involves ipsilateral adrenal gland or invades beyond Gerota's fascia

 

 

 

N: Regional Lymph Nodes
N0: No nodal involvementN1: Metastatic involvement of regional lymph node(s)
M: Metastasis
M0: No distant metastasesM1: Distant metastases
Stage groupings
Stage I: T1 N0 M0Stage II: T2 N0 M0Stage III: T3 or N1 with M0Stage IV: T4 or M1

questions.text: A patient with a left-sided scrotal mass is being evaluated and on examination the mass is found to be hard in consistency with irregular margins with no reduction on lying down or on manipulation and no cough impulse but with fullness in para-aortic lymph nodes . What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is metastasising testicular tumor. Hard scrotal mass with irregular margins and no change is size of mass or reduction of mass with manipulation or lying down should raise suspicion for testicular tumor and para-aortic lymph node fullness should raise suspicion for metastasis.

Testicular tumors metastasize first to the retroperitoneal nodes. Right-sided tumors metastasize primarily to the interaortocaval nodes. Left-sided tumors metastasize primarily to the left para-aortic nodes.

Option A : Hydrocele does not have hard consistency with irregular margins.

Option B,C: Inguinal hernias will be reducible on lying down or with manipulation and there will be positive cough impulse.

questions.text: Best prognosis among the following  breast cancer subtypes is for
questions.solution:
Luminal A is the most common subtype and has the best prognosis among all subtypes. It has high expression of ER genes and low HER-2 cluster genes.

Luminal B : Low ER and variable HER-2 expressions and high degree expression of proliferative cluster.

Almost all breast malignancies are adenocarcinomas and based on the expression of estrogen receptor and HER2 can be divided into three major biologic subgroups:

  • ER-positive HER2-negative tumors (50% to 65% of tumors) – range from well-differentiated cancers with low proliferative rates and few chromosomal changes to poorly differentiated cancers with high proliferative rates and large numbers of chromosomal rearrangements. All of these cancers express ER.
  • HER2-positive cancers - 10% to 20% of tumors, which may either be ER-positive or ER-negative.
  • ER-negative, HER2-negative carcinomas (triple-negative or basal-like)- are characterized by genomic instability, a high proliferative rate, and expression of many proteins typical of myoepithelial cells (e.g., basal keratins).

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents with abdominal pain, proptosis, features of ataxia, and abnormal bursts of unusual eye movements as shown below. The child is found to have an intra-abdominal mass. What is the most likely diagnosis in this boy?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this boy is neuroblastoma. 

The clinical case shows a young child with abdominal pain, proptosis, ataxia, and abnormal eye movement. All these features point to a diagnosis of neuroblastoma, an intraabdominal tumour. 

Neuroblastoma is a malignant tumour seen in young children (<5 years). It is derived from neural crest cells of the adrenal medulla or the paravertebral sympathetic chain and is most commonly found in the abdomen. Most children have metastatic disease at the time of diagnosis.

The common clinical features are:

  • Intra-abdominal mass
  • Proptosis, periorbital bruising (raccoon eyes) 
  • Painless blue skin lesions (blueberry muffin syndrome)
  • Opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome (rapid nystagmus + involuntary limb spasms)

The diagnosis can be made with a combination of biochemical tests (vanillylmandelic acid [VMA], homovanillic acid [HVA], dopamine, noradrenaline) and imaging studies (CT/MRI). This tumour often crosses the spine in the midline(different from Wilm's tumour which is mostly unilateral in nature).

Neuroblastoma:

  • Neuroblastoma is an embryonal tumour of the sympathetic nervous system. These tumours arise during fetal or early postnatal life from sympathetic cells derived from the neural crest. There­ fore, tumours can originate anywhere along the path which neural crest cells migrate, including:

    • Adrenal medulla
    • Paraspinal sympathetic ganglia
    • Sympathetic para­ ganglia such as the organ of Zuckerkandl.

    Neuroblastoma is the most common extracranial solid tumour of childhood. While brain tumour is the most common solid tumour of childhood.

  • Neuroblastoma is a malignancy of neuroblast cells in the adrenal medulla or sympathetic ganglia and typically presents as an abdominal or paravertebral mass.
  • Raccoon eyes (periorbital ecchymoses) are seen in neuroblastoma due to orbital metastasis.
  • Blue subcutaneous nodules represent skin dissemination of tumour-associated with the "Blueberry Muffin Syndrome".
  • Shimada classification is used for classifying neuroblastoma.

questions.text: An elderly male on digital rectal examination was found to have a rectal mass raising the suspicion of rectal carcinoma. His bowel habits are normal and he visited the outpatient department for a routine check-up. Which of the following should be recommended as the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
As the patient is elderly with a rectal mass, presenting to an outpatient department, colorectal carcinoma has to be ruled out and the investigation of choice is a colonoscopy along with a biopsy.

A colonoscopy can be used to view 100–160 cm from the anal verge while a sigmoidoscopy can only see up to 60 cm from the anal verge. Colonoscopy rules out any associated proximal lesions as well.

Moreover, a rigid sigmoidoscopy procedure requires the rectum to be empty and thus a barium enema has to be given prior to the procedure. 

Colonoscopy can also be therapeutic in the case of proximal adenomas which are snared via the colonoscope. In case of sensing cancer, a CT colonography or barium enema can be used.

The other investigations used in rectal cancer include:

  • Digital rectal examination - for assessing the depth of penetration
  • Endorectal ultrasound or MRI - provides an accurate assessment of the extent of invasion of the bowel wall
  • MRI with an endorectal coil - is the investigation of choice to assess the 'T' and 'N' stages
  • CECT - for evaluation of metastasis.

Screening for colorectal malignancy:

  • Start screening at 50 years of age in an average risk patient
  • Yearly stool occult blood testing
  • Colonoscopy every 10 year
  • Flexible sigmoidoscopy every 5 year

questions.text: The usage of the given device in the picture is?

choices.text: Measure the length of the uterus

questions.solution:
The instrument given in the image is Karman’s cannula which is used for menstrual regulation or aspiration.

Menstrual regulation or aspiration is the aspiration of the endometrial cavity 1-3 weeks after a missed period in a woman with a previous normal cycle and a positive urine pregnancy test. It is performed using Karman's cannula.

Procedure -

  • Under aseptic precautions, the cervix may be gently dilated using 4-5 mm size dilators.
  • Then 5-6mm Karman’s cannula is inserted and attached to a 50ml syringe for suction.
  • The cannula is rotated, and pushed in and out with gentle strokes.

This procedure is contraindicated in advanced pregnancy and in the presence of local pelvic inflammation.

The drawback of the procedure - an implanted zygote , and an ectopic pregnancy can be missed.

Other options:

Option A:  Hysterosalpingography is done using a Rubins cannula.

 

Option B:  The length of the uterus is measured using Simpson's uterine sound.

Option C: Retraction is done using Doyen's retractor

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: While performing the USG assessment of a woman at 28 weeks of gestation, you note her amniotic fluid index to be 12.8. When does this parameter reach its maximum value in a normal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The amniotic fluid index (AFI) is a measure of the amniotic volume which is maximum at 34 weeks of gestation.

The volume of amniotic fluid each week is variable. The volume gradually increases till 32-34 weeks of gestation. At 34 weeks, it is maximum and thereafter it starts declining till term. 

Amniotic fluid volume is a passive reflector of the fetal condition. Its volume is determined by the following:

Pathway  Volume in ml
Fetal urination +1000 
Fetal swallowing -750
Fetal lung fluid secretion +350
Intramembranous flow across fetal vessels on the placental surface -400

Early in pregnancy, amnionic fluid arises mainly from a transudate of plasma either from the fetal skin or across the uterine decidua and placenta. Fetal urine production becomes a major component in the second trimester.

Any alteration in fetal homeostasis, caused by fetal and maternal conditions, affects the amniotic fluid volume. Thus, AFI is measured as a part of the biophysical score.

questions.text: A woman presented in her 8th week of pregnancy seeking MTP. What is the appropriate dosage of Misoprostol administered by the mucosal route?
questions.solution:
The dosage of Misoprostol administered by mucosal route in this case, is 800 mcg.

Mucosal misoprostol administration has increased efficacy and minimizes gastrointestinal side effects and is now preferred over the prior oral administration. The mucosal route includes buccal, sublingual, and vaginal.

Medical management protocol for induced abortion for < 12 weeks of gestation (As per WHO 2018 guideline):

  • Combined Regimen (Recommended): 200 mg of oral Mifepristone followed 1-2 days later by 800 mcg of buccal, vaginal or sublingual Misoprostol
  • Misoprostol-only regimen (Alternative): 800 μg misoprostol administered vaginally, sublingually, or buccally.

Outpatient medical abortion is an acceptable option for pregnancies with a menstrual age < 63 days (9 weeks)

Various regimens for medical termination of pregnancy

First trimester

  • Mifepristone/Misoprostol Combined Regimen (Recommended)
  • Misoprostol-only regimen (Alternative)

Second Trimester

  • Mifepristone/Misoprostol Combined Regimen (Recommended): 200 mg of oral Mifepristone followed 1-2 days later by 400 mcg of buccal, vaginal or sublingual Misoprostol every 3 hours
  • Misoprostol Alone(Alternative): 400 mcg of buccal, vaginal or sublingual Misoprostol every 3 hours
  • Dinoprostone- 20 mg vaginal suppository every 4 hr
  • Concentrated Oxytocin- 50 units of oxytocin in 500 mL of normal saline infused in an incremental fashion through 150, 200, 250, and finally 300 units of oxytocin each in 500 mL of normal saline

Related Pearl: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act with 2021 amendments 

Indications:

  • Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother
  • Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure
  • Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest
  • Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

  • Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.
  • MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.
  • The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

  • Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)
  • At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.

questions.text: The ultrasound finding of a 24-year-old primi with 3 months of amenorrhoea is shown below.  What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Multiple Renal Cysts in the fetus

questions.solution:
The USG shows the characteristic snowstorm appearance which is seen in hydatidiform mole.

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterised by partial degenerative or partial proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has some malignant potential and hence requires follow-up.

It is of 2 types

  • Complete mole - grossly appears as a mass of clear vesicles.
  • Partial mole - has fewer hydatidiform changes and contains some fetal tissue.

questions.text: A patient with carcinoma endometrium is treated with pelvic external beam irradiation to the ​whole pelvis. Which of the following organs is most radiosensitive in the pelvic region?
questions.solution:
Among the options most radiosensitive organ is ovary> rectum> bladder> vagina.

The radiation tolerance dose for the ovary is 2-3 Gy whereas the vagina 90 Gy.

The radiation dose necessary to induce ovarian failure is age-dependent. A single dose of 3-4 Gray can induce amenorrhea in almost all women >40 yrs of age. In young women, oogenesis is much less sensitive to radiation as compared to the elderly.

Most radioresistant organ: Vagina

The most commonly affected organ by radiation is the skin and the layer of skin affected by radiation: Stratum basalis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for expectant management in unruptured ectopic gestation?

choices.text: Initial serum beta hCG level < 200 mIU/mL

questions.solution:
Gestational sac > 4cm is an indication for surgical management of ectopic pregnancy.  

Management of ectopic pregnancy: 

Expectant management is where only observation is done hoping for spontaneous resolution.

Indications:

  • Asymptomatic 
  • No evidence of bleeding or rupture on TVS
  • Initial serum hCG level <200 mIU/mL
  • Gestational sac size less than 4 cm 
  • No fetal heartbeat on TVS

Medical management with intramuscular methotrexate injection, which can be done in single-dose or multidose protocols. The dose for single-dose therapy is 50 mg/m2.

Indications

  • Low initial serum beta-hCG level 
  • Small gestational sac size- 4cm
  • Absent fetal cardiac activity
  • Hemodynamically stable

Surgical management of ectopic pregnancy includes laparoscopic salpingostomy/ salpingectomy and microsurgical laparotomy. 

Indications

  • Criteria for expectant and medical management are not met
  • Significant pain and hemoperitoneum 
  • Gestational sac ≥4cm
  • Fetal cardiac activity present
  • Beta-hCG >5000 mIU/mL
  • Failure of expectant or medical management

questions.text: A patient presents to you with complaints of mass descending per vaginum for the past 6 months.  On examination, you notice a grade 3 uterovaginal prolapse and a decubitus ulcer over the prolapse. Which of the following is a cause for this decubitus ulcer and treatment?

choices.text: Venous congestion and reduction of the prolapsed part into the vagina and daily packing with glycerine and acriflavine

questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of pelvic organ prolapse with a decubitus ulcer. It is due to venous congestion and local circulatory changes. 

Friction, congestion and circulatory changes in the dependent part of prolapse cause keratinization and pigmentation of the vaginal mucosa, as well as ulceration of the prolapsed tissue with a clean edge.

Treatment includes the reduction of the prolapsed part into the vagina and daily packing with glycerine and acriflavine. Acriflavine is an antiseptic agent while glycerine is a hygroscopic agent. This helps in the healing of the ulcer within a week or two.

Complications of prolapse:

  • Kinking of the ureter with resulting renal damage can occur in procidentia and enterocele.
  • Chronic Urinary tract infection due to retention of urine in a cystocele, and can lead to upper renal tract infec­tion and renal damage.
  • Decubitus ulcer due to venous congestion and local circulatory changes.
  • Stress incontinence occurs when the internal urinary meatus and neck of the bladder descend below the level of pelvic floor muscles.
  • Cancer of the vagina can rarely occur over the decubitus ulcer and if the ring pessary is left in over a long period.

questions.text: Cardiac output returns back to prepregnant levels by
questions.solution:
Cardiac output usually remains elevated for 24 to 48 hours postpartum and declines to non-pregnant values by 10 days.

  • Heart rate changes follow this pattern
  • Systemic vascular resistance and blood pressure rise
  • Systemic vascular resistance remains in the lower range characteristic of pregnancy for 2 days postpartum and then begins to steadily increase to normal nonpregnant values.

questions.text: What dose of folic acid is recommended for a woman who wants to become pregnant but has a history of pregnancy complicated with a neural tube defect?
questions.solution:
In a pregnancy complicated with a history of neural tube defect, 4 mg/day of folic acid is recommended.

Supplementation with folic acid is standard practice before and during pregnancy to reduce the incidence of neural tube defects and for as long as a woman is breastfeeding. 

Option A: In a normal pregnancy, folic acid is given at a dose of 400-500 mcg/day.

Options B and C: In adults with conditions having a high cell turnover like hemolytic anemia, supplementation of folic acid at a dose of 1-2 mg/day is recommended.

In hyperhomocysteinemia, folic acid is given at a dose of 1 mg/day.

 

Related Pearl: Folic Acid in Pregnancy
