questions.text: Marsupialization is an ideal treatment of choice for condition X involving the female reproductive tract, the lesion responsible for condition X is located at?
questions.solution:
Marsupialization is an ideal treatment of choice for Bartholin cyst/abscess. The given clinical vignette is suggestive of leison of the Bartholin gland.  

Bartholin glands:

Bartholin glands are the homologs of the male bulbourethral or Cowper glands. The ducts of these glands open in the groove between the hymen and the labia minora at approximately 5 and 7 o’clock positions. These glands are stimulated by sexual arousal. Bartholin glands are the homologs of the male bulbourethral or Cowper glands. 

Clinical conditions :

  • Bartholin cyst: Caused by obstruction of the Bartholin ducts by proteinaceous material or by inflammation from infection. Symptomatic or recurrent cysts may require marsupialization or gland excision.
  • Bartholin abscess: An infected Bartholin cyst can lead to an abscess. It usually requires surgical drainage.

Pathology:

  • These commonly involve the duct and are most commonly sexually transmitted. Infection is generally polymicrobial.

Clinical features:

  • If the size is big, it might cause abdominal and vaginal discomfort with dyspareunia. 
  • A vulval cleft of 'S' shape is usually noted on inspection.
  • It is fluctuant swelling and transillumination can be positive as the fluid collected is generally clear.

Treatment:

  • Analgesics for pain
  • Antibiotic for combating infections.
  • Specific treatment include Marsupialization, Incision and drainage with word catheter placement and Bartholinectomy.

Notes:

In any woman above the age of forty with recurrent Bartholin cyst, a suspicion of Bartholin gland cancer should arise and the cyst wall should be sent for biopsy.

questions.text: During your internship, you notice the following instrument being used by the senior resident. The uses of this instrument include all of the following except______

choices.text: To differentiate between chronic inversion and fibroid polyp
It is used to diagnose cervical stenosis
It is used in Fallopian Tube Recanalization
It is used to measure the uterine cavity and the cervical length

questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the above image is Simpson’s uterine sound. It is not used in the Fallopian Tube Recanalization procedure.

The instrument is held like a pencil with the thumb and the first 2 fingers and introduced into the uterine cavity by keeping it in the midline and ensuring it is not forced.

Uses include:

  • To measure uterine cavity and cervical length
  • To diagnose cervical stenosis
  • To sound a polyp, IUCD or uterine septum
  • To break uterine adhesions in Asherman syndrome
  • To differentiate between chronic inversion and fibroid polyp

questions.text: A 56-year-old multiparous woman presented with grade II/III uterine prolapse with cystocele. She complains of passing urine on coughing and sneezing. What is the type of urinary incontinence seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The type of urinary incontinence present in a patient with prolapse and cystocele experiencing urination on coughing and sneezing is stress incontinence.

Stress incontinence refers to the involuntary leakage of urine when there is increased intraabdominal pressure (eg, coughing, sneezing, laughing, Valsalva maneuver). There is an absence of detrusor muscle contraction, seen in urodynamic studies.

Causes:

  • Age and menopause - due to estrogen deficiency
  • Multiparity - due to loss of pelvic muscle tone
  • Obesity
  • Smoking
  • Constipation, chronic cough
  • Pelvic organ prolapse
  • Pregnancy - due to the effect of progesterone and pressure of the gravid uterus on the bladder neck.
  • Puerperium - due to descent of the bladder neck, loss of urethro-vesical angle, and reduced pelvic muscle tone 
  • Surgical repair of vesicovaginal fistula

Grading of genuine stress incontinence (GSI) :

  • Grade I: Incontinence with only severe stress, such as coughing, sneezing, and jogging.
  • Grade II: Incontinence with moderate stress, such as fast walking, and going up and down the stairs.
  • Grade III: Incontinence with mild stress such as standing.

Investigations are only done prior to surgery to confirm the diagnosis. They include the stress test, cotton swab or Q tip test, Marshall and Bonney’s test, urethroscopy, and urodynamic studies. These are not required prior to conservative management.

Conservative management includes Kegel's pelvic exercises, electric nerve stimulation, devices like pessaries, vaginal cones, and artificial sphincters. Medical treatment with estrogen creams, anti-adrenergic, venlafaxine, and imipramine may be useful.

Other options:

Option A: Overflow incontinence is an old term that refers to the inability to empty the bladder, with involuntary, continuous urinary dribbling. Currently, it refers to another presentation of urge incontinence. 

Option B: Urge incontinence is the involuntary escape of urine when there is an imminent need to urinate. It occurs due to detrusor muscle overactivity or detrusor instability. It is seen more commonly in old women with decreased bladder capacity, decreased sensation, and central nervous system (CNS) inhibition. 

Option D: Neurogenic bladder occurs in patients with neurogenic dysfunction leading to detrusor hyperreflexia. Conditions such as multiple sclerosis, stroke, Parkinson's disease, and spinal injury give rise to this. They present with urgency or urge incontinence.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old primigravida at 10weeks gestation comes to the ER with nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. Nausea and vomiting began one day back and now the patient is unable to tolerate fluids. She complains of pain in the right upper quadrant which started a few hours back. On examination, her temperature is 100.2 F, the pulse is 118 bpm and her BP is 110/70 mm of Hg. She has swelling of her lower limbs up to the ankles bilaterally. Abdominal examination shows a gravid uterus corresponding to 10 weeks of gestation and tenderness in the right upper quadrant, with mild guarding and is diagnosed as acute appendicitis. What is the next step of management?

Complete blood count

  • Hemoglobin: 11g/dL
  • Leukocytes: 13,000 cells/μL
  • Platelets: 150,000 cells/μL

Liver function tests

  • Aspartate transaminase (AST): 40U/L
  • Alanine transaminase (ALT): 48U/L

Urinalysis

  • Protein: negative
  • Pus cells: 1-2/HPF
  • Bacteria: none

USG Abdomen:

Reveals a 7mm diameter, aperistaltic, non-compressible, dilated, blind-ending structure arising from the base of the caecum
questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical vignette, the next step of management is Laparoscopic appendicectomy at the earliest. Laparoscopic appendicectomy can be done before 28 weeks of gestation. 

Acute appendicitis is the most common surgical non-gynecological cause of acute abdomen in pregnancy.

The diagnosis of acute appendicitis in pregnancy is difficult due to

  • Nausea and vomiting may be considered normal, especially in the first trimester of pregnancy
  • Leukocytosis is a physiological finding in pregnancy
  • A gravid enlarging uterus can push the appendix upward and outward, causing the pain to localize in the right flank or right upper quadrant.

Acute appendicitis in pregnancy is associated with miscarriage, preterm delivery, increased risk of peritonitis, perinatal and maternal mortality.

USG abdomen is used to confirm. MRI abdomen can be done if USG is inconclusive.USG Abdomen would reveal a >6mm diameter, aperistaltic, non-compressible, dilated appendix seen as a blind-ending structure arising from the base of the caecum

Other options:

Option B,C,D are not appropriate because they do not treat the urgent cause of the pathology.

questions.text: Which filter is used in a colposcope?
questions.solution:
The filter used in a colposcope is green. 

A colposcope is used to perform colposcopy where the cervix is visualized at a distance of around 20 cm with the patient in the lithotomy position.

This instrument provides binocular vision with a magnification of 6x-15x. A green filter is used to study vascular patterns as the vessels appear black. Abnormal areas can be identified by their peculiar vascular pattern such as mosaic, reticular, and punctate.

questions.text: Which serotype of HPV is responsible for Ca Cervix?
questions.solution:
HPV – 16, 18, 31, 33, 35, 39, 45, 52, 56, 58, 59, 68 are associated with Ca Cervix.

Human Papilloma Virus (DNA Virus):

  • The most common serotype of HPV responsible for Ca.Cervix: HPV 16
  • The most malignant serotype of HPV for Ca.Cervix: HPV 18
  • HPV serotype most specific for Ca. Cervix is HPV 18.
  • The most common serotype of HPV associated with Squamous Cell Carcinoma is HPV 16
  • The most common serotype of HPV associated with Adenocarcinoma is HPV 18
  • Viral proteins required for malignant transformation are E6 and E7 oncoproteins.
  • The E6 gene acts through the p53 gene, and E7 acts through the Retinoblastoma gene.
  • Viral proteins required for replication are E1 and E2.
  • Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) or southern blot or Hybrid capture technique is used for HPV DNA detection.

As per the December 2022 WHO Position on HPV vaccines, WHO recommends the following schedule:

  • A one or two-dose schedule for girls aged 9-14
  • A one or two-dose schedule for girls and women aged 15-20
  • Two doses with a 6-month interval for women older than 21

A minimum of 2 doses and when feasible 3-doses remain necessary for those known to be immunocompromised and/or HIV-infected.

Note: Cervavac is India's first indigenously prepared quadrivalent HPV (qHPV) vaccine.

  • Targeted strains: 6, 11, 16, and 18.
  • Targeted group: 9-26 years of age
  • Dose and route of administration: 0.5 ml, IM.

Related Pearl: Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) and Associated Lesions

HPV serotype Lesions
HPV 6 and 11
  • Condyloma acuminatum (genital warts)
  • Sinonasal papilloma
  • Squamous papilloma of the larynx
HPV 16
  • LSIL, HSIL, carcinoma cervix
  • Vulval carcinoma
  • Bowen disease (Carcinoma in situ of male external genitalia)
  • Oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma
HPV 18
  • LSIL, HSIL, Carcinoma of the cervix
  • Carcinoma of the anogenital region
HPV 5 and 8
  • Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin in epidermodysplasia verruciformis patients
   

 

LSIL: Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

HSIL: High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

questions.text: A woman with a history of infertility is on treatment with HMG. She presented with the following finding in the USG. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the USG findings are suggestive of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome.

Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome is characterized by mul­tiple ovarian follicular cysts accompanied by increased capillary permeability. It most often is a complication of ovulation­ induction therapy for infertility, although it may rarely develop in an otherwise normal pregnancy. It has also been reported with a partial molar pregnancy. Its etiopatho­genesis is thought to involve the stimulation of vascular endo­thelial growth factor (VEGF) expression in granulosa-lutein cells by hCG.

Human menopausal gonadotropin (HMG) is a medication that is composed of FSH and LH. It is used to stimulate the release of ova in women who do not ovulate spontaneously. It can lead to ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome.

Related Pearl: Management of female infertility for different causes are as follows

Etiology Investigations Management  
Tubal cause
  • Hysterosalpingography or sonosalpingography
  • Falloscopy
  • Salpingography
  • Laparoscopic chemotubation
  • Laparoscopic adhesiolysis
  • Tuboplasty
  • Hysteroscopic cannulation and balloonplasty
  • If all the above procedures fail or not feasible go for IVF/GIFT 
Ovulation related           
  • Ovulation monitoring by ultrasound (BBT, BBI) And  Endometrial Biopsy for tuberculosis done    
  • If the above steps are abnormal, do a hormonal study
  • FSH, LH, Prolactin
  • E2, P level
  • Thyroid and diabetes
  • Clomiphene and letrozole
  • If it fails, give FSH, LH, GnRH
  • Check for a response; if there is no response do IVF Donor egg.
  • If all the above measures fail, the final option is to adopt  
Other causes   Ultrasound, MRI, SSG, hysteroscopy   Treat the cause

questions.text: Serial monitoring of serum beta hCG is required for which of the following conditions?

choices.text: Pregnancy associated with Neural tube defects

questions.solution:
Serial monitoring of serum Beta hCG testing is done for a molar pregnancy.

Follow-up after the termination of molar pregnancy is done with serum β hCG levels. During the follow-up period, pregnancy must be avoided as it might interfere with the β hCG levels. The initial β-hCG level is obtained 48 hours after evacuation and used as a baseline. It is measured weekly till it becomes negative, and three consecutive normal values are obtained.

All patients should be followed-up for 2 years because choriocarcinoma if it occurs, develops within this period of the evacuation of the mole. Commonly, the circulating levels of βhCG decrease or becomes negative within 4 to 8 weeks post-evacuation. Once negative, the patient is usually followed up monthly for 6 months, then 3 monthly in the first year, and 6 monthly in the second year.

After beta HCG levels have become normal, subsequent conception must be avoided for one year(preferably 2 years). Pregnancy should also be avoided for 1 year after the stoppage of chemotherapy because of the teratogenic effect of drugs.

Other options:

Options A and B: Downs syndrome and Pregnancy associated with Neural tube defects require Maternal serum AFP testing.

Option D: Rh-negative pregnancy requires Coombs antibody testing.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with malodorous vaginal discharge that began a week ago. On examination, the Whiff test is positive, and a Gram stain reveals the presence of clue cells. Which of the following is the most common treatment for this infection?
questions.solution:
Foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge and a positive whiff test with clue cells in the gram staining suggest bacterial vaginosis and it is treated with metronidazole.

Bacterial vaginosis is caused due to the alteration in the normal vaginal flora. There is a decrease in the number of lactobacilli. These lactobacilli reduce the pH and release hydrogen peroxide which is antibacterial. Therefore, a decrease in the number of lactobacilli leads to an increase in the number of other organisms like Hemophilus vaginalis, Gardnerella, Mobiluncus, and Mycoplasma hominis. 

According to Amsel's criteria, the discharge has the following characteristics:

  • White milky non-viscous discharge, adherent to the vaginal wall.
  • The pH of the discharge is >4.5.
  • Fishy odor when mixed with 10% KOH. This is called the Whiff test.
  • Presence of clue cells-the epithelial cells have a fuzzy border due to the adherence of bacteria.
  • Decrease in the number of lactobacilli and increase in the number of Gardnerella and other bacteria.

It is treated with 500 mg of metronidazole twice daily for 7 days.

The below image shows the presence of clue cells.

Other options:

Option B: Nystatin pessary is used in the treatment of candidal vaginitis. They present with severe itching, dysuria, and passage of thick curdy discharge. On examination, the vagina is congested and thick curdy discharge can be seen at the vulval mucocutaneous junction and posterior fornix.

Options C and D: Tetracycline and azithromycin are used in the treatment of chlamydial infection. They usually present with vaginal discharge, dysuria, increased urinary frequency, and sometimes cervicitis. 

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

  Bacterial vaginosis Trichomonas vaginalis

Candida albicans
Causative organism  Altered vaginal flora- increased concentration of Gardnerella vaginalis Trichomas vaginalis-parasitic infection Fungal infection
Etiology Increased vaginal pH Sexually transmitted Decreased immunity
Sexual trans-mission No Yes No
Discharge Fishy, thin, yellow Frothy, green Curdy, white
Symptoms Fishy odor, no itching Itching and burning Itching, burning
pH >4.5 >4.5 <4.5
Speculum No vaginal epithelium inflammation Strawberry cervix Inflamed-epithelium
KOH Positive Whiff test Whiff test can be positive. Pseudohyphae seen.
Wet mount Clue cells. No WBCs seen Motile trichomaonads, WBCs seen WBCs seen
Treatment Metronidazole or Clindamycin Metronidazole, treat partner also Oral or vaginal azole, no need to treat partner.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presented with cyclical abdominal pain and a midline hypogastric lump. She has not achieved menarche yet. The per vaginal examination is shown below and a bluish swelling is seen along with it. What is the likely cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of an imperforate hymen, which has led to cryptomenorrhoea. This is a condition where menstruation occurs but is not visible due to an obstruction of the outflow tract.

The menstrual fluid gets collected in the reproductive tract. When this collection occurs in the vagina, it is known as hematocolpos. If the collection extends to the uterus, it is known as hematometra. The collection of blood in the fallopian tubes is called hematosalpinx.

The most common causes of cryptomenorrhea are:

  • Intact/imperforate hymen - a bluish convex bulge is seen.
  • Transverse vaginal septum - a pinkish concave covering is seen

Ultrasound pelvis confirms the diagnosis.

Management:

Imperforate hymen - A simple cruciate incision of the hymen allows the free drainage of the collected menstrual blood, and leads to normal reproductive function.

Transverse vaginal septum - Extensive dissection and vaginoplasty is required.

Option A: Bartholin's cyst appears as a swelling on the inner side of the labia majora. Larger cysts can bulge across the introitus. Small cysts can remain asymptomatic.

Option D: Endometriomas are endometriotic lesions seen on the ovary. They present as adnexal masses. Endometriosis is a complication in cryptomenorrhea, due to retrograde menstruation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding vasectomy?

choices.text: The procedure is done under local anesthesia.
Sterility is achieved 3 weeks after the procedure.
A no-scalpel technique is being widely used now.
The vas deferens is the structure that is divided in the procedure.

questions.solution:
Option B is incorrect as sperms can remain in the reproductive tract for up to 3 months and thus sterility is not immediate. It can take up to 3 months after the procedure and during this time period, the couple must abstain from intercourse or use other methods of contraception.  

Vasectomy:

Vasectomy is done under local anaesthesia. A small incision is made in the scrotum. The vas deferens are divided on both sides which disrupts the passage of sperms.

The no-scalpel technique has been now adopted. One single incision is made with special forceps and skin stitch is not required. Clips and plugs can be applied over the vas instead of cutting.

Approximately, 20 ejaculates clear the semen of all sperms. Two semen analysis reports must confirm the absence of sperms before the man can be declared sterile.

questions.text: Which of the following peaks marked in the image below is responsible for ovulation ?
questions.solution:
The label marked 2 represents the LH surge ,which is responsible for ovulation.

Phases of the menstrual cycle :

Follicular phase (days 0–14)

  • A primordial follicle develops to the Graafian stage, with atresia of neighboring follicles.
  • LH and FSH receptors are up-regulated in theca and granulosa cells.
  • Estradiol levels increase and cause proliferation of the uterus.
  • FSH and LH levels are suppressed by the negative feedback effect of estradiol on the anterior pituitary.
  • Progesterone levels are low.

Ovulation (day 14)

  • Occurs 14 days before menses, regardless of cycle length. Thus, in a 28-day cycle, ovulation occurs on day 14; in a 35-day cycle, ovulation occurs on day 22.
  • A burst of estradiol synthesis at the end of the follicular phase has a positive feedback effect on the secretion of FSH and LH (LH surge).
  • Ovulation occurs as a result of the estrogen-induced LH surge.
  • Estrogen levels decrease just after ovulation (but rise again during the luteal phase).
  • Cervical mucus increases in quantity; it becomes less viscous and more penetrable by sperm.

Luteal phase (days 14–28)

  • Progesterone levels are high.
  • The corpus luteum begins to develop, and it synthesizes estrogen and progesterone. Vascularity and secretory activity of the endometrium increase to prepare for receipt of a fertilized egg.
  • Basal body temperature increases because of the effect of progesterone on the hypothalamic thermoregulatory center.
  • If fertilization does not occur, the corpus luteum regresses at the end of the luteal phase. As a result, estradiol and progesterone levels decrease abruptly.

Menses (days 0–4)

  • The endometrium is sloughed because of the abrupt withdrawal of estradiol and progesterone.

A schematic diagram of the menstrual cycle and the changes occurring are shown below:

Related Pearl: Hormonal Regulation of Menstrual Cycle

questions.text: The CTG tracing of a woman in labor at 38 weeks gestation is shown in the image below. Which among the following is commonly associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
The given CTG shows late decelerations. The fetal heart rate begins to drop after the end of uterine contraction. It is mostly associated with uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia.

Causes of late decelerations:

  • Placental pathologies like- post maturity, hypertension, diabetes, placental abruption
  • Excessive uterine contractions
  • Excessive use of oxytocin
  • Epidural anesthesia

Other options:

Option A: The CTG given below shows early decelerations. The deceleration coincides with the uterine contractions. It seen in fetal head compression.

Option B: The CTG given below shows variable decelerations as seen in umbilical cord compression.

Option D: The CTG given below shows a sinusoidal pattern. It resembles a sine wave. It is often associated with fetal anemia, fetomaternal hemorrhage, and fetal acidosis.

Related Pearl: Deceleration patterns on cardiotocography (CTG)

Early deceleration: seen in head compression

Late deceleration: Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency, foetal hypoxia.

Variable deceleration: Seen in umbilical cord compression.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents for an antenatal check-up and is currently on lithium for her bipolar disorder. This drug must be stopped, due to the risk of development of which of the following conditions in the fetus?
questions.solution:
Lithium should be stopped as it can cause an Ebstein anomaly in the newborn.

Ebstein anomaly is characterized by the downward displacement of the tricuspid valve into the right ventricle, which results in a thin-walled, low-pressure, “atrialized” segment of the right ventricle due to the anomalous attachment of the tricuspid leaflets.

Lithium can also cause macrocephaly as a teratogenic effect. 

Lithium use in early pregnancy causes Ebstein anomaly in the fetus. Fetal lithium exposure is associated with neonatal goiter, CNS depression, hypotonia (floppy baby syndrome), and cardiac murmur.

Related Pearl: Teratogenic drugs and the birth defects

Drugs Adverse effects
Penicillamine Cutis laxa syndrome
Lithium Ebstein anomaly
Isotretinoin Facial-ear anomalies, heart disease, CNS anomalies
Progesterone Masculinization of the female fetus
Quinine Abortion, thrombocytopenia, deafness
Topiramate Cleft lip
Valproate Spina bifida, limb defects, autism spectrum disorder, facial and cardiac anomalies, Coarctation of the aorta, Aortic stenosis, Pulmonary atresia, Ventricular Septal Defect. 
Vitamin D Supravalvular aortic stenosis
Warfarin Fetal bleeding, hypoplastic nasal structures
Statins Vertebral, anal, cardiac, tracheoesophageal fistula, renal, arterial, limb (VACTERAL) defects
Phenytoin Ventricular septal defect, Atrial Septal Defect, Coarctation of the aorta, Patent Ductus Arteriosus
Alcohol Atrial Septal Defect, Ventricular Septal Defect

questions.text: Which of the following options is not correct regarding the USG criteria for PCOD?

choices.text: At least 10 follicles should be present for diagnosis
Each follicle should be 2 to 9 mm in size
The ovarian changes are not applicable if the woman is on OCPs

questions.solution:
In polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD),at least 12 follicles each measuring 2 to 9 mm should be seen on an ultrasound.

 USG Criteria: 

  • Increased ovarian stroma 
  • 12 follicles each measuring 2 to 9 mm arranged in a necklace pattern
  • Ovarian volume >10 ml
  • These ovarian changes are not applicable if the woman is on combined oral pills, as these pills alter the ovarian morphology.
  • Single ovary meeting these criteria is enough to diagnose PCOD.

Rotterdam criteria is used to diagnose polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS.

Rotterdam criteria (ASRM/ESHRE- European society of human reproduction and embryology, 2003):

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism
  • Oligo/anovulation
  • Polycystic ovaries

Other criteria for diagnosing polycystic ovarian syndrome:

National Institute of Health (NIH, 1990):

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism
  • Oligo/anovulation

Androgen excess and PCOS society (AE-PCOS):

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism
  • Oligo/anovulation/polycystic ovaries

Necklace appearance of right ovary on USG in PCOD:

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

questions.text: The least common route of spread of vulval cancer is _____.
questions.solution:
The vascular route of spread is rare in vulval cancer.

  • Most common type of spread in vulval cancer: Lymphatic
  • First lymph node involved: Superficial inguinal lymph node > Deep inguinal lymph node > Femoral group of lymph nodes
  • The sentinel lymph node biopsy is helpful for evaluating the spread of vulval cancer.
  • The sentinel lymph node for vulval cancer is the superficial inguinal lymph node.
  • Most important prognostic factor: Lymph node status

Related Pearl: Treatment Modality in Vulval Cancer

Stage Treatment
1A
  •  Radical wide local excision
     
1B
  • Partial vulvectomy + ipsilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection
II
  • Tumor 2-4cm – total vulvectomy + B/L groin lymph node dissection
  • Tumor >4cm or poorly differentiated – radical vulvectomy + B/L lymphadenectomy + pelvic lymph node dissection
 
III
  • Megavoltage radiotherapy
  • Local surgical excision - Radical vulvectomy + B/L lymphadenectomy + pelvic lymph node dissection
  • Local recurrence – chemotherapy
 
IV
  • Chemotherapy or radiotherapy
  • Local excision on residual tumor
  • ipsilateral inguinofemoral lymph node + ve – contralateral node removed
  • Femoral lymph node +ve – pelvic lymph node removed

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with post-coital bleeding. On per vaginal examination, the following lesion is seen which bleeds on touching. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image with the history of post-coital bleeding in a woman of childbearing age is suggestive of a cervical polyp.

Endocervical polyp:

  • They arise from the mucous membrane of the cervical canal and form a swelling about the size of a pea.
  • The mucous polypi are regarded as being produced by hyperplasia of the mucous membrane of the cervical canal which becomes thrown into folds and finally one of the folds, which projects into the cervical canal, assumes the characteristics of a polypus.
  • The lesion is red and vascular which bleeds easily on the touch and is covered by smooth glistening epithelium with clear mucus.
  • The polypus is pedunculated, the pedicle being attached to the mucous membrane of the cervical canal.
  • Histologically, the surface epithelium is the high columnar type similar to that of the endocervical canal. Glands found in the stroma are lined by tall columnar epithelium. The stroma is extremely vascular, containing a large number of dilated capillaries with round-celled infiltration near the lower pole of the polypus.
  • Occur in women during the childbearing period of life, but may occasionally develop in menopausal and postmenopausal women.
    Treatment- avulsion or by torsion and specimen should always be sent for microscopic examination as malignant changes may be seen.

questions.text: A 25-year-old 26-week pregnant woman was diagnosed with gestational diabetes. Which of the following is not a likely cause for it?

choices.text: Increasing demand for insulin as the pregnancy advances
Degradation of the insulin by the placenta
Recurrent vaginal candidiasis in present pregnancy
Increased production of the human placental lactogen

questions.solution: Presence of recurrent vaginal candidiasis is a sign of diabetes, not a cause for it.

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication for breastfeeding?

choices.text: Infants born to an HbsAg positive mother

questions.solution:
Breastfeeding is absolutely contraindicated if the infant has classic galactosemia. 

Infants born to an HbsAg positive mother routinely receive hepatitis B immunoglobulin and hepatitis B vaccine. So, a delay in the initiation of breastfeeding is not required.

Contraindications of breastfeeding:

Do not Breastfeed

Do not give expressed breastmilk

Infant factors:

  • Classic galactosemia

Maternal factors:

  • Human T-cell lymphocyte virus (HTLV) infection
  • Ebola virus infection
  • PCP/cocaine abuse

Do not Breastfeed (Temporarily)

Do not give expressed breastmilk  (Temporarily)

Maternal factors:

  • Brucellosis
  • undergoing diagnostic imaging with radiopharmaceuticals
  • Active herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection with lesions on the breasts

Do not Breastfeed (Temporarily)

Can give expressed breastmilk

Maternal factors:

  • Untreated, active Tuberculosis
  • Active Varicella infection

Alcohol consumption and smoking are NOT contraindications of breastfeeding. However, smoking and alcohol consumption should be discouraged.

Note: In a mother with untreated, active tuberculosis:

  • Temporarily withhold breastfeeding but can feed with expressed breastmilk
  • Resume breastfeeding once she has been adequately treated for 2 weeks and is no longer contagious.

WHO recommendations on breastfeeding in HIV infection:

  • Start mothers on antiretroviral therapy (ART)
  • Exclusive breastfeeding for 6 months
  • Continue breastfeeding for at least 12 months, with the addition of complementary feeds.

questions.text: Vitamin K supplementation is given to neonates to prevent ___.
questions.solution:
Intramuscular injection of 0.5-1 mg of phytonadione(Vitamin K)  is given to all newborn infants to prevent hemorrhagic disease of the newborn. 

Hemorrhagic disease of the newborn is caused by a transient deficiency of vitamin K–dependent factors, factors II, VII, IX, and X.

Causes include:

  • Lack of free vitamin K from the mother
  • Absence of the bacterial intestinal flora normally responsible for the synthesis of vitamin K.

It is responsive to and prevented by vitamin K therapy (0.5-1 mg of phytonadione).

However, for newborns with vitamin K deficiency, the dose of vitamin K administered is 1–5 mg intravenously.

questions.text: Tetralogy of Fallot is most commonly associated with which of the following:
questions.solution:
Tetralogy of Fallot is most commonly associated with Downs syndrome among the given options.

Children with tetralogy of Fallot are more likely to have chromosome disorders, such as Down syndrome, Alagille syndrome, and DiGeorge syndrome (a condition that causes heart defects, low calcium levels, and poor immune function).

Tetralogy of Fallot: It is the most common cyanotic congenital heart disease.

  • The primary defect is an anterior deviation of the infundibular septum (the muscular septum that separates the aortic and pulmonary outflows).
  • The primary defect gives rise to the 4 anatomical components of TOF which are:
  • Ventricular septal defect (VSD) ( NOT ASD)
  • Obstruction to right ventricular outflow - Pulmonic stenosis (PS)
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH)
  • Overriding (or dextroposition) of the aorta
  • Obstruction to pulmonary arterial blood flow is usually at both the right ventricular infundibulum (subpulmonic area) and the pulmonary valve.
  • The degree of pulmonary outflow obstruction determines the degree of the patient’s cyanosis and the age of first presentation.

The heart is typically enlarged and is classically “boot-shaped” due to marked right ventricular hypertrophy.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presented with dark-colored urine as shown below, oliguria, hypertension, and facial puffiness for 3 days. The urine test is positive for albumin. He had a history of throat infection 2 weeks back. On microscopic examination, enlarged, pale glomeruli and epithelial humps are seen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario given in the question is suggestive of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN).

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis(PSGN) is characterized by the sudden onset of gross hematuria, oedema, hypertension, and renal insufficiency. It usually occurs following a throat infection by nephritogenic strains of group A β-hemolytic streptococci. It can also occur after streptococcal skin infection or pyoderma.

The typical patient develops an acute nephritic syndrome following 1 to 2 weeks after antecedent streptococcal pharyngitis or 3 to 6 weeks after streptococcal pyoderma. The pathogenesis involves circulating antibodies elicited by streptococcal antigens reacting with normal glomerular antigens, and complement activation by directly deposited streptococcal antigens causing the immunologic injury.

In this immune complex-mediated APSGN, we see a decrease in the serum complement (C3) level (levels normalise in 6 to 8 weeks), and ASO titer is increased (the titers decrease to low levels within 4 to 6 weeks).

Microscopic Findings in PSGN include
  • Light microscopy: Enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli with diffuse mesangial proliferation and leukocyte infiltration.
  • Immunofluorescence: Granular deposits of IgG and complement C3 along the glomerular basement membrane(GBM)and in the mesangium. 
  • Electron microscopy: Electron-dense deposits, or humps, are observed on the epithelial side of the GBM.

Below is the image showing light microscopy findings of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

Other options:

Option A: Post-staphylococcal glomerulonephritis is a kidney condition that occurs after a Staphylococcus infection, leading to immune complex deposition in the glomeruli. It presents with hematuria, proteinuria, oedema, and hypertension, often seen in adults with underlying health conditions.

Option C: Nephrotic syndrome is a kidney disorder characterized by massive proteinuria (>3.5 g/day), hypoalbuminemia, oedema, and hyperlipidemia. It results from increased glomerular permeability, leading to fluid retention and other systemic complications.

Option D: IgA nephropathy (Berger's disease) is the most common type of glomerulonephritis worldwide. It is characterized by recurrent hematuria/ nephritic syndrome and the presence of prominent IgA deposits in the mesangium. Clinically, children and young adults present with gross or microscopic hematuria within 1-2 days of onset of an upper respiratory (synpharyngitic presentation) or gastrointestinal infection.

The below image is an immunofluorescence study of IgA nephropathy showing the characteristic IgA deposition in the mesangial regions.

Related Pearl: Nephrotic and nephritic syndromes

 

Nephrotic Syndrome

Nephritic Syndrome (Glomerulonephritis)

Primary pathology

Damage and dysfunction of glomerular filtration barrier, causing significant leakage of plasma proteins without much glomerular inflammation

Significant inflammatory injury of the glomerulus resulting in passage of RBCs, inflammatory cells & plasma proteins

The principal site of glomerular injury

Hallmark:

Hypertension

Hypercoagulability

Varying degrees of proteinuria and pyuria

Renal dysfunction

Hypertension

Associated Glomerular pathology

Minimal change disease (Primary and secondary)

Membranous-nephropathy (Primary and secondary)

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis

These syndromes, however, are not mutually exclusive. Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythromytosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy has non-blanching rashes on the legs and buttocks as seen in the picture. He also complains of joint pains, abdominal pain, vomiting, and blood in the stool. Lab investigations revealed normal platelet count and urine analysis shows haematuria +++ and proteinuria +. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario describes Henoch Schonlein purpura. 

Features of Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP):

  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is a common small vessel vasculitis in childhood.
  • It is characterized by a purpuric rash and commonly accompanied by arthritis and abdominal pain.
  • About half of the patients with HSP develop renal manifestations, which vary from asymptomatic microscopic hematuria to severe, progressive glomerulonephritis: The pathogenesis of HSP nephritis appears to be mediated by the deposition of polymeric immunoglobulin A (IgA) in glomeruli.
  • Laboratory studies generally show a mild leukocytosis, a normal platelet count, and occasionally eosinophilia. Serum complement components are normal.

questions.text: A newborn baby presents with irritability and cyanosis which subsides on crying. On examination, you are unable to pass a nasogastric tube and no mist formation is noted on the laryngeal mirror test. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of choanal atresia, the best next step would be to provide an oropharyngeal airway.

Choanal atresia is the persistence of the bucconasal membrane, unilateral is more common and may remain undiagnosed until adult life, bilateral atresia will present as a respiratory obstruction in the newborn. The initial clinical evaluation consists of placing a large laryngeal mirror under each nostril and checking for fogging, this is known as the laryngeal mirror test.

Diagnosis can be made by:

  • Presence of mucoid discharge in the nose
  • Absence of air bubbles in the nasal discharge
  • Failure to pass a catheter from the nose to the pharynx
  • Putting methylene blue dye into the nose and checking its passage to the pharynx
  • Putting a radio-opaque dye into the nose and taking a lateral radiograph
  • CT in the axial plane 

Management: In bilateral atresia, emergency treatment is to provide an airway, which is done by McGovern's technique- (a feeding tube with a large hole that provides a good oral airway), this removes the need for tracheostomy. Definitive treatment is correcting the atresia either by transpalatal or transnasal approach, which is usually done at one and a half years of age.

Related Pearl: Choanal atresia

  • It is due to the persistence of bucconasal membrane which separates primitive oropharynx from the primitive nasopharynx
  • Unilateral > bilateral
  • 30% of cases are bony and 70% are mixed
  • Unilateral cases may be asymptomatic and present in adult life
  • Bilateral cases are life-threatening and present with respiratory distress
  • Associated with CHARGE syndrome
    • C- Coloboma of the eye
    • H- Heart defects
    • A- Atresia of choana
    • R- Retarded growth and development
    • G- Genital anomalies
    • E- Ear anomalies and hearing loss.
  • CT scan is the best investigation

Image: Membranous, bilateral choanal atresia in a newborn

 

 

  • McGoverns technique- A feeding nipple with a large hole provides a good oral airway
  • Definitive treatment consists of correction of atresia by a trans-nasal or trans-palatal approach.

questions.text: A 10-month-old child undergoes treatment for diarrhoea with hypokalemia but the child does not respond to the treatment appropriately and on examination muscular weakness is noted, What is the most likely cause of treatment failure?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with diarrhea, muscular weakness, and hypokalemia not responding to treatment is most likely due to hypomagnesemia.

The major cause of hypomagnesemia in this scenario is severe diarrhoea/gastrointestinal loss which in turn worsens the hypokalemia. In such cases, hypokalemia can not be corrected unless the underlying hypomagnesemia is addressed. 

Treatment failure in hypokalemia due to hypomagnesemia is mediated by two mechanisms:

  • ↓ Magnesium → inhibits Na+/ K+ - ATPase activity → ↓ influx of potassium into the cell → secondary kaliuresis.
  • ↓ Magnesium → decreased block of ROMK (renal outer medullary K+ channel) potassium efflux channels → increased potassium secretion by distal nephron

Therefore in the presence of hypomagnesemia, hypokalemic patients are clinically refractory to potassium supplementation therapy.

Hypokalemia is defined as a plasma concentration of K+ <3.5 meq/L. The following are various causes of hypokalemia:

  • Inadequate intake
    • Diet, potassium-free intravenous fluids, potassium deficient TPN
  • Excessive potassium excretion
    • Hyperaldosteronism
    • Medications 
  • Potassium losses
    • Direct loss of potassium from GI fluid (diarrhea)
    • Renal loss of potassium (to conserve sodium in response to gastric losses) 
  • Metabolic
    • Intracellular potassium shifts from metabolic alkalosis or insulin therapy

Clinical features 

  • Weakness and paralysis
  • Intestinal ileus
  • Risk of atrial and ventricular arrhythmias
  • Broad flat T waves, ST depression, and QT prolongation are most marked when serum K+ <2.7 mmol/L
  • Sodium chloride and bicarbonate retention lead to metabolic alkalosis

Management includes potassium supplementation with concurrent cardiac monitoring. Treat hypomagnesemia by supplementation. High dose propranolol if due to excess sympathetic activity

Other options:

Option B: The clinical features of hyponatremia are predominantly neurological as a result of the development of cerebral edema. Patients usually present with nausea, headache, vomiting, seizure, brainstem herniation, and coma.

Option C: The clinical features of hypermagnesemia are dose-dependent. 

  • >2 mmol/L - vasodilation and neuromuscular blockade.
  • >4 mmol/L - refractory hypotension, progressive weakness leading to respiratory paralysis and coma. Although hypermagnesemia causes muscle weakness, the question asked is the cause of treatment failure in hypokalemia.
  • >10mmol/L - dilated pupils, bradycardia, PR, QRS, and QT prolongation.

Option D: The clinical features of hypernatremia are neurological. The most frequent manifestation is altered mental status ranging from confusion and lethargy to deep coma.

questions.text: A 5-year-old  male with known history of asthma developed sudden onset breathlessness, and wheezing . He was rushed to the emergency, where the preliminary assessment was done. The pulse is 140/min, respiratory rate 28/min, and the FEV1 is 40% of the predicted value. Which of the following is the best next step in treatment in this case?

choices.text: A high concentration of oxygen should be given by a face mask + Salbutamol nebulisation
High doses of SABA to be given by a nebulizer only
Sedatives should be added to alleviate anxiety
Nebulized anticholinergics to be added immediately as the mainstay of treatment

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario given above is suggestive of severe, acute attack of asthma. The best next step in the treatment would be to give a high concentration of oxygen should be given by a face mask + Salbutamol nebulisation . 

Management of acute attack of asthma:

  • A high concentration of oxygen should be given by face mask and oxygen saturation should be maintained at >90%.
  • The mainstay of treatment are high doses of SABA given either by nebulizer or via a metered-dose inhaler (MDI) with a spacer.
  • In severely ill patients with impending respiratory failure, IV β2-agonists may be given.
  • A nebulized anticholinergic may be added if there is not a good response to β2-agonists alone.
  • In patients who are refractory to inhaled therapies, a slow infusion of aminophylline can also be given.

Features of Acute severe attack of asthma include:

  • Inability to speak a complete sentence in one breath
  • Pulse >120/min
  • Respiratory rate >25/min
  • FEV1 between 33 to 50% of predicted
  • Pulsus paradoxus of >10 mmHg

Classification of severity of asthma exacerbations:

  MILD MODERATE SEVERE IMPENDING RESPIRATORY FAILURE
SYMPTOMS    
Breathlessness With activity With talking At rest At rest
Speech Sentences Phrases Words Mute
SIGNS    
Body position Able to recline Prefers sitting Unable to recline Unable to recline
Respiratory rate Increase Increase Often >30/min >30min
Accessory respiratory muscle use Usually not Commonly Usually Paradoxical thoracoabdominal movement
Breath sounds Moderate wheezing at mid to end expiration Wheeze throughout expiration Loud inspiratory and expiratory wheezes Air movement very less without wheezes
HEART RATE <100 100-120 >120 Relative bradycardia
Pulsus paradoxus <10 10-25 Often >25 Often absent
Mental status Maybe agitated Agitated Agitated Confused and drowsy
PEF   (% PREDICTED) >80 50-80 <50 <50
PaO2(mm hg,room air) Normal >60 <60 <60
PaCo2(mm hg) <42 <42 >42 >42
 PEF - peak expiratory flow

 Classification of Asthma treatment is based on Global Initiative for Asthma (GINA; 2021)

questions.text: A child who was fed only on rice water presents with a swollen belly and dull face. His appearance is of a 'fat sugar baby' and is found to have low serum protein and low albumin. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A swollen belly with a dull face,appearance of 'fat sugar baby',low serum albumin, and protein are suggestive of Kwashiorkor.

Kwashiorkor is a form of severe acute malnutrition (SAM) characterized by oedema and apathy.

Related Pearl: Differences between Marasmus and Kwashiorkar

Marasmus Kwashiorkor
Seen in infants less than 1 year of age

Seen in older children

(6 months to 3 years of age)
Total calorie deficit Protein deficit
No edema Edema is prominent

Voracious appetite

No apathy

Loss of appetite

Apathy
Severe muscle wasting Muscle wasting mild or absent
Prominent ribs Protuberant abdomen

No Fatty liver

No subcutaneous fat

Fatty liver

Subcutaneous fat preserved

Special features:

  1. Alert
  2. Loose wrinkled skin 
  3. Baggy pant appearance

Special features:

  1. Moon face
  2. Flaky paint dermatosis
  3. Flag sign

The image below shows Flag sign characterised by alternating bands of hypopigmented and normal pigmented areas on the hair strand.

 

The image below shows a child with an old wrinkled old man appearance.

 

The image highlights the differentiating clinical features between marasmus and kwashiorkor

questions.text: A child is brought to the pediatrician with short stature. On evaluation, growth hormone levels are found to be high and Insulin-like growth factor(IGF-1) levels are low. Which among the following could be the abnormality here?
questions.solution:
The presence of high growth hormone levels and low Insulin-like growth factor(IGF-1) levels point towards Laron syndrome/dwarfism. It is caused by end-organ resistance to growth hormone(GH insensitivity) due to the mutation of the growth hormone receptor.

Here, growth hormones are produced, but not able to act on the target tissues as growth hormone receptors in the target tissue are not responding to growth hormones. So, the resting and stimulated growth hormone levels are high and insulin-like growth factor (IGF-1) levels are low.

It is an autosomal-recessive disorder with clinical features that are the same as those seen in pituitary dwarfism. The primary clinical symptom associated with this condition is short stature. 

Treatment is by subcutaneous injections of insulin-like growth factor 1 (a growth-promoting hormone), often called IGF-1.

questions.text: A 3-day old male neonate who has not yet passed meconium developed abdominal distension. There is no history of fever. On rectal examination, forceful expulsion of stool was observed. A barium enema is performed and the findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following is the gold standard for the diagnosis of the above condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a newborn presenting with failure to pass meconium, abdominal distension, forceful expulsion of stools on rectal examination, and barium enema showing dilated right colon with a transition zone in the mid-descending colon is suggestive of Hirschsprung's disease. The gold standard for the diagnosis of Hirschprung's disease is a rectal biopsy.

Hirschsprung disease or congenital aganglionic colon is characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the myenteric (Auerbach) plexus and submucosal (Meissner) plexus of the distal intestinal segment. This is because of the premature arrest of normal migration of neural crest cells from the cecum to the rectum.

 

They are predominantly seen in boys and are associated with Down syndrome. Most cases present during the neonatal period with abdominal distension, bilious vomiting, and failure to pass meconium. Later they may also have poor feeding and severe constipation. Forceful expulsion of stools is observed on rectal examination as the stools accumulate in the distal colon.

A barium enema is obtained on all suspected cases. This demonstrates the location of the transition zone between the dilated ganglionic colon and the distal aganglionic rectal segment.  In older children, anorectal manometry shows a high internal sphincter pressure due to the absence of normal inhibitory reflex.

 Rectal biopsy is the gold standard investigation shows the following:

  • Absent ganglia
  • Hypertrophied nerve trunks
  • Positive immunostaining for acetylcholinesterase
  • Calretinin immunostain­ing (superior to acetylcholinesterase staining)

The definitive surgeries are the Swenson procedure, Duhamel procedure, and Soave's procedure

The most common cause of death in uncorrected Hirschprung's disease is enterocolitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the first-line drug used to control seizures in a child presenting with febrile seizures?
questions.solution:
The first-line drug to control the seizures in febrile seizures is a benzodiazepine like midazolam or lorazepam.

Febrile seizures occur in children of the age of 6-60 months with a high-grade fever of 38°C (100.4 F) or higher without underlying CNS infections, metabolic abnormality, or prior afebrile seizures.

Risk factors:

Major:

  • Age  less than 1 year
  • Duration of fever  less than 24 hr
  • Fever range: 38-39°C (100.4-102.2°F)

Minor:

  • Family history of epilepsy
  • Daycare
  • Male gender
  • Complex febrile seizure
  • Family history of febrile seizures
  • Lower serum sodium at the time of presentation

Types of febrile seizures:

Simple febrile seizures Complex (atypical) febrile seizures
Occurs within 24 hours of the onset of fever Can occur at any time during a fever
Generalized seizures Focal seizures
Duration is <15 min Prolonged (>15 min)
No recurrence within 24 hrs of seizures Recurrent within 24 hours
Chances of going into epilepsy 1% Chances of going into epilepsy 6%

 Investigations:

  • Lumbar puncture should be performed in the first episode of seizures with fever, for all infants <6 months age (to exclude meningitis).
  • EEG and neuroimaging are advised for children with atypical febrile seizures.

Acute treatment of febrile seizures includes lorazepam and midazolam for seizures lasting more than 5 minutes. Rectal diazepam is prescribed to use at home as rescue medication if febrile seizures last more than 5 minutes. The use of antipyretics can decrease the discomfort of the child but does not reduce the risk of having a recurrent febrile seizure.

Prophylaxis:

  • Intermittent prophylaxis includes oral clobazam for 3 days during the fever episode, if the febrile seizures recur at the rate of ≥3 seizures in 6 months, or ≥4 in 1 year.
  • Continuous prophylaxis with sodium valproate and phenobarbitone can be used for failed intermittent prophylaxis and in recurrent atypical febrile seizures.

Note:

  • Intermittent oral nitrazepam, clobazam, and clonazepam have also been used. Such therapies help reduce, but do not eliminate, the risks of recurrence of febrile seizures.
  • Future epilepsy does not change with or without antiepileptic therapy.
  • Iron deficiency is associated with an increased risk of febrile seizures, and thus screening and treating it would be appropriate.

questions.text: A 31-year-old lady with diabetes mellitus delivers a term neonate. Which of the following problems is associated with a baby born to this lady?
questions.solution:
The condition associated with an infant born to a mother with diabetes mellitus is hypoglycemia.

In pregestational diabetes and gestational diabetes mellitus, maternal hyperglycemia causes a higher amount of blood glucose to pass through the placenta into the fetal circulation. It results in fetal hyperglycemia leading to fetal hyperinsulinism. These increased insulin levels continue to persist after delivery which leads to hypoglycemia. Extra glucose in the fetus is stored as body fat causing macrosomia. These newborns are at risk of developing various complications due to fetal hyperglycemia. They are:

  • Gastrointestinal: These infants may demonstrate abdominal distention caused by a transient delay in the development of the left side of the colon due to fluctuations in maternal and fetal glucose resulting in small left colon syndrome.
  • Metabolic: Hypoglycemia, hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia
  • Neural: Neural tube defects like caudal regression syndrome, encephalocele, anencephaly 
  • Respiratory: Respiratory distress syndrome, transient tachypnea of newborn, persistent pulmonary hypertension
  • Cardiac: Cardiomegaly, cardiac malformations like a ventricular or atrial septal defect, transposition of the great vessels(most specific), truncus arteriosus, double-outlet right ventricle, tricuspid atresia, coarctation of the aorta
  • Haematological: Polycythemia, renal vein thrombosis
  • Others: Hyperbilirubinemia, insulin resistance, diabetes, sudden intrauterine death

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about colostrum?

choices.text: It is the breastmilk that is seen in the initial 3-4 days.
Contains high amount of lactose and low amounts of protein.

questions.solution:
Option D is incorrect as colostrum is the milk secreted in the initial days which has high amounts of protein and less amount of lactose. 

Various transitional forms of breastmilk:

Colostrum

  • In the initial 3 to 4 days
  • Small quantity, thick, and yellow in colour
  • A large number of antibodies, immune component cells like secretory IgA, lactoferrin, leukocytes, and vitamins like B12, A, D, E, and K.
  • High in protein and low in lactose

Transitional milk

  • Secreted after 3 to 4 days until 2 weeks
  • Immunoglobulin and protein content decreases, while the fat and sugar content increases.

Mature milk

  • Follows transitional milk.
  • Thinner and more watery.
  • Contains all the nutrients essential for the optimal growth of the baby. 

Foremilk

  • Secreted at the start of the feed
  • Watery and rich in proteins, sugar, vitamins, minerals, and water that quenches the baby’s thirst.

Hindmilk 

  • Comes towards the end of the feed
  • Provides more energy and a sense of satiety and it is richer in fat.

Preterm milk 

  • Milk of mother who delivers before 37 weeks.
  • Contains more proteins, sodium, iron, immunoglobins, and calories as per the requirement of the preterm infant.

questions.text: Dystrophin protein is absent completely in which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Dystrophin protein (a sarcolemmal protein), is absent in patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) due to a mutation in the dystrophin gene. Lack of dystrophin leads to cellular instability, which leads to progressive leakage of intracellular components.

Dystrophin connects actin filaments to the transmembrane protein β-dystroglycan in the sarcolemma by the smaller proteins syntrophins in the cytoplasm.

Duchenne muscular dystrophy:

  • Most common hereditary neuromuscular disease
  • It is an X-linked recessive disorder, and the causative gene is located at Xp21.
  • Clinical features
    • Progressive weakness with developmental delay occurs.
    • Pseudohypertrophy of calves and wasting of thigh muscles is seen.
    • Trendelenburg gait or hip waddle is characteristic.
    • Gower’s sign: Indicates weakness of proximal muscles: The patient has to use hands and arms to "walk-up" their own body from a squatting position.
    • Dilated cardiomyopathy
  • Diagnosis
    • Elevated serum creatine kinase levels
    • Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) analysis for the dystrophin gene
    • If PCR is normal, but clinical suspicion is high, muscle biopsy with dystrophin immunocytochemistry is done.
  • Treatment: Treatment of cardiac decompensation, nutritional management, physiotherapy, and glucocorticoids.
  • Prognosis: Death occurs usually at about 18 to 20 years of age due to respiratory failure, intractable heart failure, pneumonia, or aspiration.

Other options:

Option A: Becker's muscular dystrophy(BMD) leads to abnormal dystrophin formation, whereas the dystrophin gene mutation in DMD leads to dystrophin deficiency.

Option C: Myasthenia gravis (MG) is a neuromuscular disorder that is characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles, due to a decrease in the number of available acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at neuromuscular junctions as a result of antibody-mediated autoimmune attack.

Option D: Lambert Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome is a neuromuscular junction disorder associated with the reduced acetylcholine (Ach) release from the presynaptic nerve terminals, despite normal ACh vesicle numbers, ACh presynaptic concentration, and postsynaptic ACh receptors.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child was brought to her pediatrician for routine well-child care. Her physical examination is normal except for a systolic murmur and a widely split-second heart sound that does not vary with respiration. She has no family history of heart disease. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The age of the patient, normal physical findings except for a systolic murmur, and wide and fixed (does not vary with respiration) splitting of S2 are all in favor of a diagnosis of Atrial septal defect.

ASDs are abnormal, fixed openings in the atrial septum caused by incomplete tissue formation that allows communication of blood between the left and right atria. The ASD creates a left to right shunt that increases the blood flow to the right side of the heart. This causes the pulmonary valve to close later than the aortic valve. Since the two atria are linked, inspiration does not produce any net pressure changes between them abolishing respiration-related changes in venous return hence causing fixed S2. 

Other options:

Option A: TAPVC patients usually present with cyanosis and congestive cardiac failure around 4-10 weeks of age. This is when the fetal pulmonary vasculature regresses and there is increased pulmonary blood flow which results in early-onset cardiac failure. The physical findings are identical to ASD.

Option B: Ventricular septal defect (VSD) is typically associated with a pan-systolic murmur best heard in the left lower sternal border.

Option C: Pulmonic stenosis is an acyanotic heart disease and physical findings include an ejection systolic murmur and a thrill in the left second intercostal space and a wide and variable split S2 because of delayed closure of P2.

questions.text: A young male who had a road traffic accident is brought to the emergency department. His left leg is shortened, internally rotated, and adducted. On examination, femoral artery pulsation is not felt. A plain radiograph of his hip was taken which is shown below. What is your diagnosis?

choices.text: Fracture neck of femur with injury to femoral vessels
Anterior dislocation of hip with femoral artery injury

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of posterior hip dislocation. In this condition, the leg will be in flexion, adduction, and internal rotation. 

This injury is seen in patients as a result of a motor vehicle accident. In a patient that is sitting in a car, the hip is flexed and the knee is pushed posteriorly by an impact on the dashboard.

Radiographically, in a patient with a posterior dislocation, the femoral head is displaced, posterior, superior, and slightly lateral to the acetabulum.

The femoral artery pulsation is usually felt against the neck of the femur. Due to the posterior dislocation of the hip joint, the femoral vessels fall backward and the pulsation of the femoral artery cannot be felt. This is called the vascular sign of Narath.

Related Pearl: Anterior and posterior dislocation of the hip

Radiological findings
  • Femoral head may be seen inferior to the acetabulum
  • Femoral head appears larger than normal 
  • Lesser trochanter is prominent
  • Femoral head is displaced superiorly and laterally
  • Femoral head appears smaller than normal
  • Lesser trochanter is not visualised

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
The image shows the middle two toes being fused together which is a condition called 'Syndactyly'.

Syndactyly is the fusion of digits that can involve either the fingers or toes. It is a congenital malformation and can be of various degrees based on the extent of fusion of the tissues involved:

  • Simple-only soft tissue
  • Complex- skin and bone fused
  • Incomplete- only part of the web
  • Complete- entire web is affected

Pathophysiology: due to lack of apoptosis during development of the digits. 

Treatment: Mild or incomplete syndactyly of central digits need no treatment.

If it disrupts the function of the handthen surgical separation of the conjoined structures and reconstruction is needed.

Note: 

Syndactyly of border digits can cause progressive deformity with growth and thus this needs early surgical correction. 

Care is taken not to injure the digital arteries when multiple digits are involved by separating only one side of a digit at a time.  

Other options:

Symphalangism: congenital stiffness of the proximal interphalangeal joints of the fingers.

Polydactyly: extra digits are present in fingers or toes.

Brachydactyly: undergrowth of a digit seen in syndromes like Turner's syndrome.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the hospital with complaints of pain and limping. The symptoms started 6 months back and gradually worsened. The child appears to be healthy with normal height and weight. On examination, there is mild wasting on the right side, abduction ( especially in flexion ), and internal rotation is limited due to pain. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A young male patient with normal height and weight and complaints of pain and limping gradually progressing over 6 months and examination findings of limited abduction and internal rotation is likely to have Perthes's disease. The image shows a mushroom-shaped femoral head that is laterally displaced in a dysplastic acetabular socket. 

Between 4 and 7 years of age, the femoral head may depend on the lateral epiphyseal vessels for its blood supply and venous drainage almost entirely. These vessels situated in the retinacula make them susceptible to stretching and to pressure from an effusion.

The disease is characterized by the disruption of blood flow to the head of the femur. Due to which the bone goes for osteonecrosis and stops growing. Over time, healing occurs by new blood vessels infiltrating the dead bone and removing the necrotic bone which leads to a loss of bone mass and a weakening of the femoral head.

Clinical features include a boy of 4-8 years complaining of pain and limping. Symptoms continue for weeks on end or recur intermittently. The hip looks deceptively normal. Although initially, all movements are painful; with time, abduction with internal rotation is always limited.

Xray findings depend on the stages 

  • Necrotic phase: Radiographically dense areas which indicate new bone formation is soon followed by bone necrosis.
  • Fragmentation phase: Alternating patches of density and lucency. Sometimes a crescentic subarticular fracture is often seen in lateral view
  • Re-ossification phase: Epiphyseal density increases in this phase
  • Healing phase: Normal femoral head or mushroom-shaped femoral head which is laterally displaced in a dysplastic acetabular socket.

There are different 'head at risk signs' described by Catrell which include:

  • lateral subluxation of the femoral head
  • speckled calcification in the lateral epiphysis
  • Epiphysis being horizontal
  • Gage's sign: V-shaped osteoporotic segment in the lateral epiphysis and adjacent metaphysis.

Guidelines to treatment are derived from the review by Herring,

Children under 6 years - symptomatic treatment including activity modification is appropriate

Children aged 6-8 years - Bonge age and Catterall Staging determines the modality of treatment. Options include abduction brace or osteotomy.

For children aged 9 and above - operative containment is the choice.

Note:Salter's extrusion angle helps to assess the femoral head extrusion. Normal is 50 degrees or more.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man presented with low back pain that was radiating to his legs. On examination of the spine, a palpable step was felt in the lumbosacral region. The X-ray of the spine is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the patient most likely has spondylolisthesis. A palpable step in the lumbosacral spine, called a step sign is a classic clinical feature of this condition. Moreover, in the X-ray given, there is a break in the pars interarticularlis of the L4 vertebra, which appears like a beheaded Scottish terrier. Hence, it is known as the beheaded Scottish terrier sign and it is diagnostic of spondylolisthesis. 

Spondylolisthesis is the anterior displacement of one segment of the spine upon another. It is caused as an end result of spondylolysis. 

Normally, the spinous processes of the adjacent vertebrae are aligned with each other. They can be palpated on the back in a smooth way.

In spondylolisthesis, one vertebra has moved over the other. Therefore, a step-off or step sign can be felt over the spinous process at the affected level. 

Note: The step-off sign is also used to describe the radiographic appearance of Lisfranc injury of the foot. There is a dorsal displacement of the tarsal bones with respect to the metatarsal bones.

 A diagram showing spondylolisthesis and spondylosis is given below:

Spondylolysis refers to defects or stress fractures in the pars interarticularis of the vertebral arch. The most common site for spondylolysis is L5.

questions.text: What is the type of splint shown in the image called as?
questions.solution:
The image shows a cock up splint which is used for radial nerve palsy. 

Other options:

 Wrist splint - 

The wrist splint is used in the management of carpal tunnel syndrome. it can be worn at night to prevent bending of the wrist which typically happens when patients sleep and leads to increased symptoms.

 

Knuckle bender splint -

In cases of ulnar claw hand where ulnar nerve recovery is anticipated the knuckle bender splint can be used to correct and prevent MCP(metacarpophalangeal) hyperextension.

Dynamic finger splint -

questions.text: A patient sustained a fracture as depicted in the image, following a fall from height. What is this fracture known as?
questions.solution:
The fracture shown in the image is known as Open book fracture.

Open book fractures are associated with pubic diastasis and/or a fracture of the pubic rami with a posterior pelvic disruption of the sacro-iliac joint.

 

Other options:

Malgaigne's fracture(image shown below)  involves the pubic rami anteriorly and the sacroiliac joint (SI joint) or ilium near the SI joint on the same side posteriorly. 

Bucket handle fracture refers to a vertically orientated fracture through ipsilateral superior and inferior pubic rami with contralateral sacroiliac joint disruption.

Chauffeur's fracture refers to fracture of the radial styloid process in the forearm.

questions.text: While examining a patient with a right forearm fracture, you ask him to make a fist. The following finding is noted during this procedure. What is the sign called as ?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the pointing index sign and is associated with median nerve injury at the forearm or elbow.

The pointing index sign is seen in supracondylar fractures of the humerus.

This finding occurs as a result of injury to the anterior interosseous nerve, a branch of the median nerve. It results in the loss of function of both flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) and flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS). Hence, the index finger sticks out when the patient is asked to clasp their hand. 

Other options:

Option A:  In Froment's sign, due to the weakness of the adductor pollicis muscle, the adduction of the thumb is lost. When asked to hold an object, the patient tries to hold the object by using the flexor pollicis longus muscle. This produces flexion at the interphalangeal joint while holding the book.

Option C:  Paralysis of flexor pollicis brevis can occur in median nerve injury at the arm and elbow. Benediction hand sign (attempt to make a fist gives pointed index and middle finger) and Ochsner's clasping test (attempt to clasp both hands show pointing index finger) are used to test such injuries.

Option D:  Policeman tip deformity, also known as waiter's tip hand or porter's tip hand, is a finding of Erb's palsy due to injury of the upper trunk of the brachial plexus involving C5 and C6. The hand is adducted, medially rotated, and hangs by the side with the elbow extended and pronated.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented with complaints of a gradually progressive swelling around his wrist joint for 3 months. Given below is the image of the swelling and the X-ray film. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and the X-ray showing an eccentric expansile lesion with a soap bubble appearance are suggestive of osteoclastoma or giant cell tumor(GCT).

Osteoclastoma usually affects young adults in the age group of 20-40 years. The most common location of the tumor is the distal femur followed by the proximal tibia. Involvement of the distal end of the radius is also seen and the tumor is more aggressive in this location.

Radiographic findings in GCT:

  • A solitary, possibly loculated, lytic lesion in the epiphysis
  • Eccentric location, most often subchondral
  • Expansion of the overlying cortex
  • Soap bubble appearance - The tumor is homogeneously lytic with trabeculae of the remnants of bone traversing it, giving it a loculated appearance called soap bubble appearance
  • No calcification within the tumor
  • No or minimal reactive sclerosis around the tumor.

Treatment :

  • Extended curettage and bone grafting. 
  • En-bloc wide resection and reconstruction are done for advanced stages, local recurrence, and tumors not responding to other methods.
  • Resection without reconstruction is done for lesions in expandable bones like distal ulna, clavicle, etc.
  • Irradiation and/or embolization are used for inoperable lesions in the spine and pelvis.
  • Bisphosphonates have been shown to reduce the proliferation of osteoclasts and hence have been shown to stabilize local and metastatic disease.
  • Denosumab is approved for use in unresectable tumors in skeletally mature patients.

Other options:

Ewing's sarcoma:

It is a primary malignant tumor of the bone commonly involving the age group of 4-25 years. It commonly involves the diaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, fibula, and humerus. 

Radiographic findings: Onion-peel appearance due to deposition of periosteal reaction in layers is the typical finding.

 

Osteosarcoma:

It is the most common non-hematologic primary malignancy of bone. It occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. It is typically metaphyseal. The distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus are the common sites. 

Radiographic findings: The periosteal reaction is the typical finding and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance on X-ray.

 

Osteochondroma:

Osteochondromas are common benign bone tumors. The lesions consist of a bony mass, often in the form of a stalk, produced by endochondral ossification of a growing cartilaginous cap. The common sites of involvement are the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus.

Related Pearl: Classical radiological appearance of bone tumors

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with supraspinatus tendinitis. What degree of movement of the shoulder would be painful for this patient?
questions.solution:
Supraspinatus tendinitis seen in shoulder impingement syndrome is due to repeated rubbing of the tendon (mainly supraspinatus) under the coraco-acromial arc. The patient complaints of increased pain when the arm traverses an arc between 60 and 120 degrees when greater tuberosity negotiates the subacromial space.

Shoulder impingement syndrome:

It is also called supraspinatus syndrome, painful arc syndrome, and swimmer's shoulder and occurs when the tendons of the rotator cuff muscles become irritated and inflamed as they pass through the subacromial space. This can result in pain, weakness, and loss of movement at the shoulder.

Causes of impingement syndrome:

  • Supraspinatus tendinitis (Common)
  • Complete or partial rupture of the rotator cuff
  • Osteoarthritis of the acromioclavicular joint

Clinical features:

  • Subacute tendinitis or painful arc syndrome: Anterior shoulder pain after vigorous activity. Treatment is with avoidance of initiating activity, NSAIDs, and physiotherapy.
  • Chronic tendinitis: Recurrent attacks of subacute tendinitis and pain is worse at night. 
  • Cuff disruption: There is progressive fibrosis and disruption of the cuff leading to a partial or full-thickness tear. Treatment includes acromioplasty and repair of rotator cuff.
