questions.text: The characteristic appearance of oesophagus on barium swallow, as shown in the image below,  is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The corkscrew appearance of the esophagus is seen in diffuse esophageal spasm.

  • Diffuse/distal esophageal spasm (DES) is a motility disorder of the esophagus.
  • On barium swallow, DES may appear as a corkscrew or rosary bead esophagus, but this is uncommon.
  • Manometry is the gold-standard diagnostic test.

Achalasia is a primary esophageal motility disorder characterised by the absence of esophageal peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) in response to swallowing.

In achalasia single contrast esophagogram shows, dilatation of the esophagus with a bird beak deformity near the gastroesophageal junction.

In esophageal carcinoma barium study will show irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction and shouldered margins.

Double-contrast esophagram shows a large, flat ulceration (arrow) in the distal esophagus in a patient with CMV esophagitis.

questions.text: Identify the heart chamber marked in the given CT image.
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the above CT image is the left atrium.

Transverse CT images are to be observed from the foot end of the supine patient, as if we are sitting at the patient's feet. So the right-hand side of the observer corresponds to the left-hand side in the CT.

questions.text: What are the imaging modality being used and the diagnosis in the given image below of the kidneys?
questions.solution:
As the bones and vertebrae appear white in a CT image while in an MRI the bones are seen as black, this is an MRI image. The given image is of an MRI with multiple cysts in the kidney and is suggestive of Polycystic kidney disease, mostly ADPKD( Adult polycystic kidney disease).

ADPKD is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait with mutations in the PKD1(chromosome 16) and PKD2 genes (chromosome 4). 

The disease does not usually manifest before 30 years of age, and in some patients, it is never diagnosed. The progression of renal failure in this disease is faster in males.

Hypertension is the most common presentation. Renal manifestations of ADPKD include:

  • Flank/loin pain -  either due to hemorrhage inside cysts or due to renal stones (most commonly uric acid stones)
  • Irregular upper quadrant renal mass
  • Hematuria
  • Renal failure (seen in 10-15% of the patients who receive hemodialysis)

It is associated with a number of extrarenal manifestations like polycystic liver disease, where cysts are usually asymptomatic but symptoms may occur due to mass effect of cysts, intracranial berry aneurysms are seen in approximately 10% of patients with ADPKD and mitral valve prolapse, the most common valvular abnormality observed in patients with ADPKD can be diagnosed by echocardiography.

Intravenous pyelography shows a characteristic spider leg pattern, as a result of narrowed and stretched calyces and elongated, compressed renal pelvis. 

Treatment includes management of hypertension using ACE inhibitors like lisinopril or angiotensin receptor blockers like telmisartan. Narcotic analgesics should be limited to episodes of acute pain. V2 receptor antagonists like Tolvaptan have been observed to slow the decline in renal function over a 3 year period.

USG-guided CT aspiration is both diagnostic and therapeutic; surgical unroofing of multiple or large cysts may alleviate symptoms of pain. Nephrectomy is indicated for symptomatic patients with end-stage renal disease (ESRD).

Note:

Horseshoe kidney is a common congenital anomaly in which there is a fusion of the inferior poles of both kidneys. It is common in patients with Turner's syndrome. Stone disease and hydronephrosis can occur as complications due to blockage of the ureteropelvic junction. 

The image shown below shows the appearance of the horseshoe kidney on a CT scan.

questions.text: In which condition is popcorn calcification seen ?
questions.solution:
Popcorn calcification is seen in pulmonary hamartoma.

Popcorn calcification is defined as a pattern of calcification in rings and arcs that resembles popped corn kernels. 

The presence of fat in a well-circumscribed solitary pulmonary nodule which does not demonstrate significant growth is pathognomonic of a pulmonary hamartoma.

Chest x-ray showing pulmonary hamartoma:

Amorphous calcifications with rings and arcs which resemble popped corn kernels in appearance are known as pop-corn calcification. 

It may be seen in 

  • Chondroid lesions like chondrosarcoma
  • Fibrous dysplasia
  • Pulmonary hamartomas
  • Fibroadenoma breast
  • Calcified uterine fibroid
  • Metaphyses and epiphyses of long bones of children with osteogenesis imperfecta.

questions.text: Identify the investigation shown below which is the investigation of choice in distal small bowel tumours.
questions.solution:
Enteroclysis, which is the investigation of choice in patients with small bowel tumors.

Enteroclysis is a barium study in which the contrast agent is put directly into the duodenum through a nasogastric tube.

Continued infusion of 500 to 1000 mL of thin barium sulfate and methylcellulose suspension is done and then viewed continuously with the use of either fluoroscopy or radiographs taken at frequent intervals. This technique is a double-contrast procedure that allows detailed imaging of the entire small intestine.

Enteroclysis has a sensitivity of over 90% in the detection of small bowel tumors and is the investigation of choice, particularly for tumors located in the distal small bowel.

Advantages of enteroclysis:

  • The contrast is administered at a controlled rate directly in the small bowel, bypassing the regulatory action of the pylorus.
  • The entire small bowel is demonstrated in a distended state, allowing better diagnosis. As a result of the dilatation, the following can be visualized:
    • Mild strictures
    • Small sinus tracts and fistulas
    • Minimal extrinsic compressions
    • Skip lesions
    • Proximal and distal extent of diffuse diseases.
  • The examination can be completed in 15–30 minutes, thus reducing patient waiting time.

Related Pearl: Barium Studies

Barium swallow: Used to assess the pharynx, esophagus, and stomach.

The image below is a barium swallow showing eosinophilic esophagitis and associated stricture:

Barium meal: Used to assess stomach and duodenum.

Barium meal followthrough: Used to assess the small intestine

Barium enema: Used to assess the large intestine

questions.text: A patient stopped alcohol consumption for 3 days and presented with irritability, disorientation, paranoid delusions, agitation, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient who has not consumed alcohol for the past 3 days with disorientation, paranoid delusions, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium is suggestive of delirium tremens.

Delirium tremens is a medical emergency that occurs during alcohol withdrawal. It is an acute condition and usually develops within 72 hours after the last drink. It has symptoms of both delirium and alcohol withdrawal. The clinical features of delirium tremens are:

  • Altered sensorium with disorientation
  • Perceptual distortions, most frequently tactile or visual hallucinations
  • Autonomic hyperactivity with tachycardia, fever, anxiety, insomnia, hypertension. And sweating
  • Fluctuating levels of psychomotor activity, ranging from agitation to lethargy
  • Altered sleep-wake cycle

Other options:

Option B - Wernicke’s encephalopathy (alcoholic encephalopathy) is associated with thiamine deficiency. Alcohol abuse may lead to thiamine deficiency because of poor nutritional habits, or malabsorption. It is an acute neurological disorder characterized by:

  • Global confusion
  • Ocular abnormalities like horizontal nystagmus, gaze palsy, anisocoria, and sluggish pupillary reflex
  • Ataxia - mainly affecting the gait
  • Vestibular dysfunction

It may resolve with thiamine therapy or progress to Korsakoff's syndrome.

Option C - Korsakoff’s psychosis can follow Wernicke’s encephalopathy due to thiamine deficiency. It is a chronic amnestic syndrome that is characterized by the following clinical symptoms in an intact and responsive patient:

  • Impaired mental syndrome, especially recent memory
  • Anterograde amnesia
  • Confabulation

Option D - Alcohol-induced psychosis is characterized by the development of auditory hallucinations or paranoid delusions in the context of a heavy drinking or alcohol withdrawal. These patients have a clear sensorium, unlike the patients having delirium tremens.

Note: Tremulousness is the first alcohol withdrawal symptom.

questions.text: A 20-year-old lady presents with sudden palpitations, sweating, breathlessness, and a feeling like she is being choked. She had a history of a COVID-19 infection 1 year ago and fears she might die because she was positive for COVID-19. Physical examination, ECG, and laboratory workup were unremarkable. This is the first time she is experiencing an episode like this which lasts normally for around 20 minutes. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette describes a classic panic attack as she has symptoms of palpitations, sweating, breathlessness, feelings of choking and fear of dying although her examination and lab findings are normal. 

A panic attack is an abrupt surge of intense fear or intense discomfort that may last from minutes to hours. Recurrent panic attacks are termed panic disorders.

Panic attacks can occur in other disorders, particu­larly in specific phobias, social phobias, and post-traumatic stress disorder. 

Unexpected panic attacks occur at any time and are not associated with any identifiable situational trigger. Attacks in patients with social and specific pho­bias are usually expected in response to a specific stimulus.

Some panic attacks do not fit into unexpected or expected attacks, and these attacks are referred to as situationally predisposed panic attacks. They may or may not occur on exposure to a specific trigger, or may occur immediately after exposure or after a considerable period of time.

Four or more of the following should be present to label it a panic attack:

  • Palpitations, pounding heart, or accelerated heart rate.
  • Sweating.
  • Trembling or shaking
  • Sensations of shortness of breath or smothering
  • Feelings of choking
  • Chest pain or discomfort.
  • Nausea or abdominal distress.
  • Dizziness, unsteady, light-headed, or faint
  • Chills or heat sensations
  • Paresthesias
  • Derealization (feelings of unreality) or depersonalization (feeling detached from oneself)
  • Fear of losing control or "going crazy."
  • Fear of dying

Related Pearl: Anxiety disorders

Disorder

Panic disorder
Recurrent and unexpected panic attacks with ≥ 4 of the following:
  • Dyspnea
  • Tachypnea
  • Palpitations
  • Sweating
  • Dizziness
  • Chest pain
  • Tightness
  • Paresthesias
  • Emotional and cognitive
    symptoms
  • Feeling that something catastrophic is
    about to happen.
Occur spontaneously without overt precipitants.
 
They often avoid situations/ places in which panic attacks have occurred.

Treatment is with benzodiazepines or SSRI/ SNRI and cognitive behavioural therapy

during exposure to relatively innocuous stimuli or situations.

a variety of topics (job, health, finances, etc.) > 6 months.

  • Fatigue
  • Difficulty concentrating
  • Irritability
  • Muscle tension
  • Sleep disturbance

Treatment:

First line: CBT, SSRIs or SNRIs

Second-line: Benzodiazepines, Buspirone

questions.text: A 43-year-old man presents to the emergency department accompanied by police. He came to the police station accusing his daughter of wanting to kill him. The police on investigating the family and the neighbors understood that it was a false accusation. His physical examination is not remarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis here?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario the patient thinks that his daughter wants to kill him which is not true. Since the patient appears normal apart from the delusion, the clinical scenario is likely to be of a delusional disorder, more specifically delusion of persecution. 

Delusions are false belief, that is firmly held despite objective and obvious contradictory proof. Other members of the culture do not share this belief. It can be present in conditions like schizophrenia, mania, major depressive disorders, and delusional disorders.  Important types of delusion are

  • Delusion of persecution- The patient thinks that he or she is being conspired against, cheated, spied on, followed, poisoned or drugged, maliciously maligned, or harassed.
  • Delusion of Grandeur- The person thinks that he has great power, importance, or identity.
  • Delusion of control- The patient thinks that his thoughts are being controlled by some external forces.
  • Delusion of infidelity: The patient falsely believes that one’s lover is unfaithful.
  • Delusion of reference- The patient believes that events, objects, or behavior of others have a special significance. They might also feel that others are talking about them.
  • Delusion of self-accusation- Feeling of remorse or guilt
  • Erotomania- This is also called de Clérambault syndrome and is more common in women. The patient feels that someone is deeply in love with them.
  • Cotard syndrome- This is also called nihilistic delusional disorder. Patients feel that they have lost their possessions, status, strength, their body organs have stopped functioning, and the world around them will come to an end. 

Other options:

Option B: Illusion is an incorrect perception or misinterpretation of a sensory stimulus. Eg: There is a rope in front of you but you see it as a snake.

Option C: Hallucination: Perception in the absence of any stimulus. Eg: There is nothing in front of you but you can see a snake.

Option D: Cotard syndrome is a condition in which an individual feels like they have lost all possessions and status, including their entire being and all internal organs.

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman was brought to the psychiatric OPD by her friend. The patient claims that her boss is in love with her and stalks her. The woman’s friend refutes her claims. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Erotomania is a delusional disorder where the patient believes someone is in love with him/her, against evidence to the contrary. It is also known as De Clérambault syndrome.

The lover in the delusion is often a person of higher social status. It is more common in women.

questions.text: The mask given below works on which of the following principles?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Venturi mask and it works using the Bernoulli principle in delivering a predetermined and fixed concentration of oxygen to the patient.

In the Venturi mask ,the size of the constriction present in the device determines the final concentration of oxygen for a given gas flow. This is achieved in spite of the patient's respiratory pattern by providing a higher gas flow than the peak inspiratory flow rate.

Patients with COPD require greater FiO2 than those provided by low-flow devices and are ideal candidates for the use of a Venturi mask.

In the Venturi mask system, oxygen inflow is connected to a specific color-coded entrainment device at the base of the mask that provides a set Fio2 at a set oxygen inflow rate. Various entrainment devices can provide a Fio2 of 0.24 to 0.5, with an oxygen inflow of 4 to 15 l/min and a delivered total flow of 35 to 45 l/min.

questions.text: During the pre anaesthetic evaluation of a patient, the oral cavity examined is depicted in the image given below. The image shows _________
questions.solution:
Since soft palate, the base of the uvula and hard palate are seen, this is graded as mallampati class III.

Mallampati classification: Here the size of the tongue in relation to the oral cavity is assessed. The greater the tongue obstructs the view of the pharyngeal structures, the more difficult is the intubation.

Mallampati class III and class IV are considered difficult airway.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

  • Class I: soft palate, fauces, entire uvula, pillars;
  • Class II: soft palate, fauces, the portion of uvula;
  • Class III: soft palate, the base of uvula;
  • Class IV: hard palate only.

questions.text: While doing a subclavian venous catheterization, the patient suddenly desaturated and on examination of the chest, there was hyper resonance in the apical area of the right lung. What is the most likely diagnosis here?
questions.solution:
A common complication of subclavian vein catheterization is pneumothorax and it is the diagnosis in this case as there is hyper resonance and sudden desaturation. 

However, the most common complication of a central line insertion is an arterial puncture.

Complications of central vein catheterization are

  • Arterial puncture- this is the most common complication. 
  • Cardiac tamponade is the most important life-threatening complication. It occurs as a result of puncture of intrapericardial superior vena cava, right atrium, or right ventricle.
  • Pneumothorax- injury to the underlying pleura may lead to pneumothorax. This is more common in subclavian vein catheterization.
  • Chylothorax can occur particularly in left subclavian vein catheterization. But it is not the most common.
  • Injury to the associated nerves like brachial plexus, stellate ganglion, phrenic nerve, or vocal cords.
  • Thromboembolism leading to venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism is more common with femoral veins.
  • Infections

Central venous catheterization is the insertion of the catheter into a large central vein. The veins preferred largely depend on the underlying disease in the patient, the clinical setting, and the expertise of the doctor. 

The internal jugular vein is preferred when the patient has:

  • Bleeding diathesis- Bleeding from this vein can be easily detected and can be controlled with pressure. 
  • Pneumothorax- The lesser risk of injury to the lung
  • Needs cardiac pacing- right internal jugular vein is used.

Femoral or subclavian veins can be used in patients when the neck is immobilized using a cervical collar.

The below image shows central vein catheter

The below image shows subclavian vein catheterization.

The below image shows catheterisation into jugular vein

Below image shows radiograph of subclavian vein catherisation

questions.text: Which of the following induction agents is most appropriate for a patient with cardiac disease?
questions.solution:
Etomidate is considered to be the most appropriate induction agent for cardiac patients. 

Etomidate has minimal effect on cardiovascular function due to its lack of effect on the sympathetic nervous system and on the function of the baroreceptors. They act on alpha 2 adrenoreceptors and increase blood pressure which helps to maintain cardiovascular stability after the induction. 

Etomidate is the induction agent of choice in patients with cardiovascular disease, reactive airway disease, and intracranial hypertension,

Due to its unique hemodynamic stability, it is used as a short-term sedative in hemodynamically unstable patients like patients requiring cardioversion or in patients with unstable angina for minor operative procedures.

Long-term use of etomidate in trauma or terminally ill patients will cause a reversible inhibition on 11 beta-hydroxylase which decreases cortisol production and increase 11 deoxycorticosterone. This results in adrenocortical suppression.

Other options:

Option A- Ketamine has a stimulatory effect on the sympathetic nervous system and results in increased blood pressure, heart rate, and cardiac output. This leads to an increase in myocardial oxygen consumption and so it is contraindicated in ischemic heart disease.

Option C- Propofol is a myocardial depressant agent. It reduces sympathetic activity, leading to vasodilatation that results in a reduction of blood pressure and a decrease in cardiac output.

Option D- Thiopentone is also a myocardial depressant agent. It causes peripheral vasodilatation, reduction in the ventricular filling, negative inotropic effect, and reduction in a sympathetic outflow from CNS. this results in a reduction in blood pressure and a decrease in cardiac output.

questions.text: Which of the following features are not associated with the condition shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image shows characteristic lesions of Lichen Planus and Munro microabscesses are not a feature of Lichen Planus but seen in Psoriasis. 

Lichen planus (LP) is an idiopathic inflammatory disease affecting the skin and mucous membrane. 

Patients present with pruritic, purple, polygonal, papules. The lesions have thin white lines on their surface known as Wickham’s striae. They are commonly seen on the volar aspect of the wrists, the lumbar region, and around the ankles.

The mucosal involvement is also seen. The commonest mucosal sites are buccal mucosa and tongue, rarely it can also be found on the buccal mucosa, anus, genitalia, etc. 

Nail involvement can be seen as thinning of nail plate leading to an exaggeration of longitudinal lines, and linear depressions. The nails can also be destroyed leading to anonychia. Involvement of nail bed may give rise to longitudinal melanonychia, hyperpigmentation, subungual hyperkeratosis, or onycholysis.

Microscopy will show acanthosis of the epidermis, irregular thickening of the granular layer, and compact hyperkeratosis.  Degenerating basal epidermal cells are transformed into colloid bodies. The rete ridges may have the sawtooth appearance, and focal separation from the dermis may lead to Max Joseph spaces. In active LP a band‐like infiltrate of lymphocytes and histiocytes is seen near the dermo-epidermal junction.

Other options:

Munro microabscess is the accumulation of neutrophils in the stratum corneum. The lesions present as red scaly plaques which are well demarcated with the surrounding normal skin. They might have a circle of clear zone around it which is known as the Woronoff ring. 

Related Pearl: Nail changes in lichen planus

Nail involvement in lichen planus occurs in up to 10% of the cases but is usually a minor feature of the disease.

Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

The most frequent nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to a slight thinning of the nail plate.

Pup-tent sign - elevation of nail in shape of tent

Trachonychia - 20 nail dystrophy

Subungual Hyperkeratosis and Onycholysis

Longitudinal Melanonychia in Lichen Planus of the nail bed

Permanent destruction of several toenails with ulceration of soles (rare variant)

Image shows  Nails in Lichen planus presented with irregular longitudinal grooves and ridges .

Image : Dorsal Nail Pterygium

Image : Pup-tent sign 

Image : Trachonychia

questions.text: Which of the following side effects are seen most commonly with Isotretinoin (13-cis-retinoic acid)?
questions.solution:
Isotretinoin is a vitamin A derivative which is highly teratogenic when orally administered. It is commonly used to treat cystic nodular acne. It inhibits the migration of neural crest cells during embryogenesis and affects the development of multiple organs. These defects are collectively termed retinoic acid embryopathy.

Embryopathy or developmental disorder of an embryo comprises a large variety of abnormalities and is more common than any individual defect. Specific anomalies may include ventriculomegaly, maldevelopment of the facial bones or cranium, microtia or anotia, micrognathia, cleft palate, conotruncal heart defects, and thymic aplasia or hypoplasia.

Isotretinoin also increases the risk of spontaneous abortions and stillbirths up to 40% in pregnancies exposed in the first quarter of this medicine. Presenting with pregnancy during treatment with isotretinoin is a failure of prevention strategies.

The guidelines for isotretinoin usage are as follows:

  • Isotretinoin is a teratogenic drug that should not be taken during pregnancy and nursing.
  • Patients should take 2 pregnancy tests before starting isotretinoin and take a monthly pregnancy test while on the medication, and another test 1 month after stopping the medication.
  • Two forms of birth control should be simultaneously used starting 1 month before treatment, during the entire course of treatment, and for 1 month after ceasing treatment with isotretinoin.
  • Isotretinoin should be reserved for the treatment of severe, nodulocystic acne and should not be used for milder forms of acne.

Other options:

Option B: Lithium is used in the treatment of bipolar disorder. It is a teratogen associated with Ebstein's anomaly which is a rare cardiac condition characterized by severe tricuspid regurgitation and right atrial enlargement.

Option C: Valproic acid is the anti-epileptic which confers the greatest risk to the developing fetus while used in pregnancy. It is associated with an increased risk of neural tube defects in the fetus.

Option D: Tetracyclines are associated with yellowish-brown discoloration of deciduous teeth when used after 25 weeks of gestation.

questions.text: A patient presented with lesions as shown in the image below and later developed arthritis also.  What is the treatment of choice for a patient who presented with the following findings?
questions.solution:
The patient has right knee effusion, dactylitis of multiple digits, sharply demarcated red papulosquamous lesions on both knees all of which point towards a diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis. 

Methotrexate and apremilast are the first-line drugs for the treatment of moderate to severe psoriasis associated with psoriatic arthritis.

Features of psoriatic arthritis are :

  • Asymmetrical oligoarthritis
  • associated with nail pitting/ onycholysis, or
  • dactylitis, enthesitis 
  • Inflammation is prominent in the distal interphalangeal joints 
  • There is dactylitis with pronounced telescoping.
  • Nail dystrophy (hyperkeratosis and onycholysis) affects each of the finger
  • Axial involvement may occur

Radiological features:

  • Pencil-in-cup deformity of DIP joint
  • marginal erosions with adjacent bony proliferation "whiskering"
  • small joint ankylosis
  • Ray distribution of lesions

Note :

Indications for methotrexate (inflammatory conditions) include:

  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Psoriasis 
  • Psoriatic arthritis
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Polymyositis
  • Dermatomyositis
  • Wegener’s granulomatosis
  • Giant cell arteritis 
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Other systemic vasculitis
  • Graft versus host disease associated with organ transplantation.

Related Pearl: Drug of choice for different types of psoriasis

Type Drug of choice
Chronic Plaque Psoriasis Methotrexate
Erythrodermic Psoriasis Methotrexate 
Psoriatic Arthritis Methotrexate / Apremilast
Pustular Psoriasis Acitretin
Psoriasis in HIV patients Acitretin
Impetigo Herpetiformis

1. Systemic Corticosteroids

2. Cyclosporine
Erythrodermic Psoriasis in Pregnancy Systemic Corticosteroids

questions.text: A 7-year-old intellectually disabled boy was brought with large warty crusts on the trunk, hands, and feet as shown below. Severe fissuring and scaling of the skin are present over the soles. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Norwegian scabies or human-crusted scabies.

Individuals who are intellectually challenged, suffering from dementia, or with Down's syndrome are frequently associated with Norwegian scabies.  Lack of appreciation of pruritus could be a reason for this.

Crusted scabies (Norwegian or hyperkeratotic scabies) is seen in individuals who are immunocompromised due to any underlying disease or therapy, patients with HIV infection, and in people who use topical steroids and pimecrolimus. 

Crusted scabies occurs in people with an inadequate immune response to the mite, allowing them to multiply. It is called 'Norwegian' because it was first described in lepers of Norway.

Large warty crusts form on the hands and feet. Palms and soles may be irregularly fissured and thickened. Horny debris get accumulates beneath the thickened and discolored nails. Erythema and scaling occur in the scalp face and seborrheic area. The itching will be absent often.

Scrappings teeming with mites and eggs confirms the diagnosis. 

All patients should be hospitalized and isolated due to the risk of transmission due to physical contact. Treatment includes oral ivermectin, topical scabicide, and keratolytic agents for the crusting.

The images given below show hands in Norwegian scabies.

Other options:

Option A- If topical steroids are used on scabies lesions, the clinical picture modifies to mimic other conditions. This is termed as scabies incognito.

Option B-  Animal scabies transmission to humans is rare. Lesions are similar to human scabies with itchy papules except for the burrows. It is rare. 

Option D-  Nodular scabies presents as violaceous, pruritic localized nodules over the groin, axilla, and genitalia. They represent a hypersensitivity reaction to the mite antigens and can persist after treatment.
